PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Discrimination against Women

To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Cadman,Mr Cowan,Mr Hicks,Mr Lusher,Mr McVeigh and Mr Millar.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the requirement that pensioners and health care cardholders fill in a complex declaration when presenting prescriptions is causing distress to beneficiaries and inefficiencies in the distribution of medicines by pharmacists .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will immediately abolish the requirement that a declaration be completed by the pensioner and health care cardholder.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell and Mr O'Neil.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia,
And this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the current intention of Telecom Australia to increase the International Particular Person Fee and introduce a charge on the Ring Back Price service will :
Substantially affect the ability of the manual assistance area of Telecom's operations to compete effectively with STD and ISD.
Such pricing discrimination in favour of direct dialling and away from operator assisted calls will affect the future viability of a personalised, reliable manual assistance service
The ramifications of such a pricing policy will also ultimately affect the employment of thousands of Telephonists and Supervisors currently working in this area
Contravene the spirit of the current Prices and Incomes Policy which Telecom as a public authority should be a party to

We the undersigned believe that the provision of a personalised telephone service is an essential component in any Telecommunications system. Australia has a long history of service from the manual assistance area and we cannot now allow Telecom's pricing policies to endanger the continuation of this service.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed charges increase and so ensure the future viability of Australia's manual assistance telephone network.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government Will act to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Student Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the introduction of a comprehensive student loans scheme will:

1. Restrict Access to Education-People from poorer backgrounds will be deterred from studying by the prospect of incurring large debts. These people, if they enrol, will be forced to amass loan debts. Richer students do not face this handicap.

2. Undermine the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme-TEAS should cover the basic living costs of students. Currently the scheme only assists 38% of full- time students and the maximum level of TEAS is a mere $49.47. Government statements indicate TEAS will be further downgraded if loans are introduced.

3. Disadvantage Women-Women students would be disadvantaged by a loans scheme as they have a lesser ability to repay loan debts, because on average women earn less and have a higher unemployment rate.

4. Disadvantage Mature-Age Students-Usually mature age students forgo income to study and already have large financial commitments. They could not return to study if it meant incurring substantial debts.
5. Distort Educational Choices-Mounting loan debts would force students into studying shorter courses or not continuing with post-graduate study.

6. Result in Massive Attrition Rates-Students will attempt to undertake extensive part-time work or overload courses to minimise their loans. Increased failure rates will result forcing students to 'drop-out' rather than continuing study and increase their debts.

7. Cause Administrative & Financial Difficulties-Overseas experience shows high default rates will occur on student loans. Government money will be channelled away from TEAS to paying off banks. The government will also bear the administrative burden of pursuing defaulters.
Therefore, the proposed student loans scheme will have disastrous effects on tertiary education, which we believe benefits the whole community, not just the individual student.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The House of Representatives will reject the introduction of a student loans scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

That Federal funding of children's services which is currently almost 50% reduced in real terms should be restored forthwith to at least the 1975/76 level in real terms so that children's services are distributed more equitably throughout Australia.

That current plans to impose a standardised means test throughout Australia on users of children's services does not recognise the differences of local areas with the potential to disadvantage the bulk of users in areas of economic need such as Marrickville and should be dropped forthwith.

That the stated intention to use public funds to supplement private sector children's services which operate for profit conflicts with the community orientation of the Children's Services Program and should not be implemented.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Construction of Railway Overpass, Port Augusta, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the railway crossing situated approximately 5 kilometres east of Port Augusta on highway one (the main highway between Adelaide and all northern and western centres of South Australia and continuing through to Western Australia) has once again been the sight of an horrendous accident.
This accident has caused two, possibly three fatalities.

Previous requests have been made by the City Council of Port Augusta for the construction of an overpass, so that this section of the highway no longer presents a danger to the motoring public and those involved in driving trains over this crossing.
Permission for construction of this overpass has previously been refused and the situation has now become critical.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and approve construction of an overpass at this fatally dangerous railway crossing to avoid further loss of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatry Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of podiatry service for lower fixed income members of the community.

Podiatry is an essential health service especially in preventing greater dependency of older people. It would be much more cost effective to maintain the mobility of older people through adequate and effective services than to force them into premature institutional care.

The fees for repeated podiatry consultations to provide essential ongoing care are well beyond the means of pensioners. Considering that Department of Veterans ' Affairs pensioners are entitled to podiatry care, and this scheme is already operating successfully, we strongly urge that this service be extended to cover all pensioners.

We believe this could be best achieved through including podiatry along with the existing concessions on the health care cards. This would enable a flexible system of care through private practice, community health or rehabilitation services. It would also be essential in negotiations with the Podiatry Association to ensure assistance would be available to the housebound and those in institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mackay Directory Assistance Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mackay respectfully showeth:
That the intention of Telecom Australia to close the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre will:
Downgrade telephone services to Mackay and district.
Deprive customers of a personalized reliable telephone service.
Reduce job opportunities in the area.
Increase the likelihood of the eventual closure of the exchange.
We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia has a social responsibility to provide a sound, reliable, personalized telephone system.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed closure of the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
Alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
Alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
Alcohol advertisements are glamourous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Grey respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
(1) planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin,
(2) closing country telegraph offices,
(3) increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service,
(4) withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices,
(5) generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff,

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the citizens of the city of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holden's, respectfully show:
1. That the management of General Motors-Holden's has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
2. That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:
''the overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site.''
This statement has not been refuted.
3. That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holden's to retain its operations at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The erosion of public confidence because of the growing list of broken Government promises.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this Government stumbles through its first three months of office, along a tortuous and crisis ridden path, there is a growing perception that the group of men and women opposite who now form this administration do not espouse the policies with which they went to the Australian people a few weeks ago. That perception is based on many manifestations that this Government has no intention of fulfilling the promises that it so clearly made at that time. One could say, if one were charitable, that it was simply a matter of incompetence. One could say to them or the Australian people that the Australian Labor Party had no idea of the responsibilities it was about to assume.

SPEECH.PARA: However, if one looks at the performance of Labor around Australia one sees a real plan behind the system of simply promising the world in order to gain office. In fairly recent times the Government of Victoria changed. Mr Cain promised the earth to the citizens of that State. His policy speech contained many promises of a nature similar to that of those that we have seen made in the Federal sphere recently.

Yet, when he got to office his first actions were to deny the validity of his promises on the basis that he could not perform under the conditions he found. One would have expected, therefore, that at the election at which the next State government changed the Labor leader of the day would have learned the lesson, that he would have looked to Victoria and said: 'I must be cautious because Mr Cain was unable to fulfil his promises'. Did Mr Bannon adopt a different attitude? No, he went to the South Australian people promising the earth. When he was elected he said: 'I cannot find the resources to fulfil my promises'.

The very same thing occurred in the Federal election prior to March. The Hawke Labor Government promised the earth. When he got in he said that he could not find the resources. I am not so charitable as to say that the people opposite are simply incompetent. I believe that they are in government by design and deceit by promising to the Australian people those things that they full well knew they were unable to fulfil. This short record shows clearly that this is the fact. This party, which at the last Budget said to the then Government: 'You are not spending enough, you should spend more on a range of items across the Australian community', has, therefore, no base on which to say now that it cannot find the resources.

The first major defect in the Government's program surrounds the National Economic Summit Conference, that height of political ascent at which the Prime Minister found the air so rarefied that it affected his judgment and at which he found the height so great that there was no one there with him. Certainly his main partner in making the Summit work, Mr Dolan of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, yesterday walked away from the Summit. He clearly walked away from the major promise that the Prime Minister made to the Australian people when he said that we will 'bring Australians together in a united effort until victory is won'. He went on to say:

We of the Labor Party have already-well before the election, and well before the proposed summit-established the firmest possible basis for the necessary three-sided co-operation between governments, business and unions.

In this House during the Summit he detailed his expectation of increases in wages in future years. Yesterday Mr Dolan made remarks which were reported in newspapers this morning, especially in the Australian. The Australian said:
The decisions taken at yesterday's meeting of the ACTU Executive have put an end to consensus and to the prospect of a new era of employer-employee relations envisaged by the economic 'summit'.

Worse than that, Mr Dolan has simply run away from the Summit back to the accord , the agreement reached between the ACTU and the Government before the election. One of the key provisions at page 9 of the accord clearly sets out the objective of the accord. It states:
To protect the purchasing power of wages and salaries the adoption of a system of full cost of living adjustments will be strongly supported in tripartite consultations before industrial tribunals.

There is no intention in the accord to support the arrangements and the proposals put forward by the Summit. So the first major promise to the Australian people by the Hawke-led Government has been disposed of by one of its partners in setting it up.

One of the other major promises to the Australian people surrounds the matter of taxation. How well we remember the covering paragraph in the Prime Minister's election speech in regard to taxation in which he said:
I believe the Australian people have had enough of election promises made only to be broken. I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.
A few days after Mr Hawke made that statement he said that immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australian taxpayers would be made. Three days after he was elected he said:
We will have to reconsider the whole of our program.
Sixteen days later he said:
If there has to be some delay of the tax cuts, it will not be because Bob Hawke has decided so.

That is an example of his running away immediately from his responsibility in relation to tax cuts. Tomorrow, Australians will be treated to the spectacle not simply of the Government's failing to fulfil these tax cuts but to its increasing the taxation load on the Australian people. That is what they get for trusting the Government in relation to its promises a short three months ago. Then there is the asinine statement regarding the health plans of the Government , specifically Medicare. In Labor's program it is said:
. . . Medicare . . . involves the replacement of the present crippling health fund contributions . . . It will mean, that nine out of ten Australians will pay less for . . . health . . .

That statement was undercut a little later when the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), I think, reduced the figure to three out of four. If we listen carefully tomorrow to the exposition of the Medicare plan when it is presented to Parliament we will find that that is an absolute fiction. It is not possible to load up on one-tenth of the users of health care in Australia the cost of allowing nine-tenths of the population to have a lower health care cost. Any statistician or student of the Budget will tell honourable members opposite, if they do not know, that that is a mathematical nonsense.
I refer now to another promise made by the Government, one relating to petrol. We remember clearly how the Australian public was deeply impressed by the Labor Party's election promise that:

Labor will reduce the price of petrol by cancelling the January 1 oil price increase of $3.23 per barrel. This will have the effect of reducing the price of petrol by the order of 3c a litre. It will also reduce the Consumer Price Index by half of one point.

Twelve days after he was elected the Prime Minister cut his promise in half by reducing the price of Australian crude by $2 a barrel. That was one of the early rejections of promises in which the Labor Party had used as its excuse for the devaluation of the Australian dollar. What did it say about devaluation prior to the election? It made a simple statement saying: 'We will not be devaluing'. How does it stand before our criticism of its failure to reduce petrol prices when it was its own action in breaking another parallel promise that resulted in its inability to reduce petrol prices?

I turn now to the matter of retreaded tyres-perhaps a small matter for some people but one of great moment to those involved in the transport industry and those servicing the motor vehicle industry in Australia. Prior to the election the promise was made that the sales tax would be removed. Yet now we find that the promise has been rescinded. In fact, the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) when he was a member of parliament in Opposition wrote a letter to Mr Woodward, executive director of the Commercial Vehicle Industry Association of Australia, saying:
In the interim we would continue to require that the Commissioner of Taxation takes no action to enforce payment of increased sales tax on retreaded tyres.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Opposition that needs a retread.

—I turn now, especially for the benefit of the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), to the matter of the Fleet Air Arm which the Prime Minister mentioned when he spoke to those people of north Queensland who have a particular interest in surveillance of the coastal areas of Australia. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will ask the Royal Australian Navy to retain its fixed wing capability . . .

What went wrong? The Prime Minister obviously forgot to ask the Navy to do so. In fact, he took the opposite view again. Having made that promise to the Australian people to secure some support for a defence policy, he embarked upon a defence policy that is exactly the opposite of that put to the Australian people. It is not just a broken promise; it is a 180-degree turn in direction. I turn to another statement in the policy speech concerning unemployment. It stated:

For the sake of the one million and more Australians who face unemployment unless there is a change, those policies must be changed, and will be changed-by the Australian Labor Government after 5 March.

Certainly policies were changed by the Australian Labor Party. They were changed in relation to development. There are thousands of people in South Australia and in other parts of Australia who would get jobs now and in the future who are to be denied jobs because of Labor's policy on uranium development in this country. The refusal of the State Labor Government in South Australia, with the full approval of the Federal Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), to deny the development of Beverley and Honeymoon in South Australia is a deliberate blow at the heart of the industrialisation of my State. But further than that, it is the death knell of uranium enrichment in Australia. At a time when we find that important customers around this world are turning to Canada and other countries for their supplies of uranium it is the most asinine and deliberately anti-development policy that any government could pursue in this matter.

We come to the matter of fixed term parliaments, something that will be dealt with quite soon. This Government does not believe in frequent elections but what is it going to do? It will have a referendum, before the next Budget, that will cost $21m. It does not like taking people to the polls, does it? Within six or seven months the people will go back to the polls and it will cost $21m. Why does the Government not put that question at the next election? Why does it not do that if it meant what it said in relation to reducing the number of elections in Australia.

I turn now to the matter of tourism. In its policy speech the Australian Labor Party said that it was going to increase expenditure on tourism, tourist promotion and low cost tourist accommodation. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) does not believe that there should be an airport terminal in Adelaide. He undersold the fauna of Australia internationally in his recent statements to such a degree that he has been carpeted by his leader. This is the Government which was going to promote tourism. One essential part of the election speech of the Government referred to probity. It stated:
Labor in office will be committed to restoring probity in government, cutting away extravagance and self indulgence in public office, and establishing clear- cut decision making procedures.
It said it would establish a clear-cut decision-making procedure. This morning's newspapers state:
Uproar in Caucus as junior Ministers demand say.

Is that clear-cut? Is it clear-cut that Richard Farmer was briefed about three or four days before the full Cabinet was briefed on the Combe affair? This Government has lurched from one crisis to another. Of course, the Australian public is becoming aware that it is not simply a crisis-prone government, it is a government which deceitfully misled the public in an election document which it had no intention of honouring. It gained a support in this community which it is now rapidly losing. I say to the Australian people that they must wait. As time goes by these broken promises will mount and will be counted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last person who accused me of doing anything about airline tickets lost his seat. I suggest that if the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) carries on like that the same will happen to him. What has happened today is that parliamentary debate has been reduced to the lowest satire that Australia has ever seen. Obviously John Cleese is now the new official speech writer for the Opposition and the front bench is crammed full of the complete Monty Python cast. Just look at them-30 of them. All the 30 brilliant, new, talented, front bench members of the Opposition can come up with in this period of alleged crisis is the fact that there have been broken promises on behalf of this Government which is not even 70 days old. Today's exercise comes right on top of the spectacular debacle of yesterday. Members of the Opposition came in here hairy-chested, about to move a censure motion against this Government, and fell to pieces like the pack of cards that they really are. Why did they not have the guts to move a censure motion yesterday? Because they realised their case was based on a tissue of lies. And now they have come in here in a pathetic attempt to gain the political initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: What does it come down to? I listened intently to the speech of the honourable member for Boothby. All it comes down to is a question of retreaded tyres. Here we have this new Opposition, which is also only 70 day old, and it is completely worn out. No one is more in need of a retread than the Opposition that sits in this Parliament today. If the only thing that is holding it back from having a retread is the fact that it might have to pay sales tax on it, I will talk to the Commissioner of Taxation to see whether he can waive the sales tax so that the Opposition can have the retread that it so desperately needs.

We have had accusations about broken promises from the broken promise experts of Australian politics. There is one promise that we have not broken; there is one compact which we have kept intently with the Australian people, and that is to exorcise from this Parliament the most divisive government and the most divisive Prime Minister that this country has ever seen. The people of Australia will forever thank us for that great achievement of bringing to this country a government that can be trusted, a government that is going to set about achieving full employment in this country, a government which will be happy to be judged on its record. It will not have to explain year after year a deplorable record of lies and deceit, which was the hallmark of the last seven years of government in Australia. Let me remind the forgetful members of the Opposition of some of the promises which the broken promise experts made to the people of Australia. Let us remember that on 12 September 1978 the former Government said:
Inflation at an annual rate of 5 per cent is within our reach by mid-1979. It will go on falling under the policies of this government.
Then in 1980 it said:
The Government's success in winding back inflation has been a pre-condition for the substantial progress in reducing interest rates.

But what in fact happened? In June 1978 inflation was at a rate of 8.8 per cent. By 1979 it was 10.7 per cent and when the former Government was finally kicked from office the inflation rate had increased to 11.5 per cent or twice the average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries . So there we have a promise of 5 per cent inflation, and what did we get? We got 11.5 per cent inflation. We were told in December 1977 that there would be a 2 per cent reduction in interest rates in the next 12 months. We were told this:
. . . is a target that can and will be achieved--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about tomorrow? You are talking about six years ago.

—Oh, no. I know the Opposition does not like it but it is going to hear it anyway. Interest rates did fall tentatively by one per cent but then continued to rise. After the former Government promised to reduce them by 2 per cent they rose by 4 per cent. The greatest achievement of this Government, in 70 short days, has been to reduce interest rates already. If that is not the greatest mark of the confidence which the commercial community has in this Government then nothing else is. Then we have the great promise:

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment will fall from February and keep on falling.
That was said in 1977. Unemployment continued to rise, until it has now reached 10.3 per cent, or over 700,000 people. And these people want to talk to us about broken promises!

Let us get into something a bit more contemporary. Let us talk for a moment about last year's Budget. The Budget was one which was conceived in absolute deceit. The only problem for the former Government was that the gestation period was far too long. What the Budget of 1982-83 was supposed to do was to just hang together for one or three months in order that that Government could crawl back into office on the basis of either a September or a November election. That was the plan. The Budget was only ever supposed to last for one or three months in order that it could get the former Government over the election which it so desperately feared. What happened is that by early this year the Budget strategy began to crumble and the deceit on which it was based was exposed for all to see .

What were we told in the Budget? We were told that the 1982-83 deficit would be $1.7 billion. What do we now know? We now know that the deficit for 1982-83 will end up being $4.7 billion-an increase of $3 billion in the deficit from Budget night until now. We were told that unemployment benefits would cost $1,567m. In fact they will end up costing us this year $2.27 billion. That represents an increase of $700m in the cost of unemployment benefits. That was a bit of deceit which was transparently clear on Budget night itself and was exposed for all to see by the present Prime Minister.

The Budget of 1982-83 also included a home loan interest rebate which cost $ 100m in 1982-83 and would cost $230m in 1983-84. But that is just one of the absolute time bombs which was included in that Budget, a Budget which was not expected to last, which was calculated and designed to ensure that, whilst it looked attractive on Budget night, the cost of providing those promises was to be transferred into 1983-84 at least. The home loan interest rebate introduced on Budget night was to cost $55m in that year and $185m in the next year. Family allowance increases were to cost $250m this year and $375m next year. The tax cuts which were supposed to be the lure to con the Australian people into re- electing the former Government were to cost $1,500m in 1982-83 and $2.5 billion in 1983-84.

The former Government had no intention of keeping with the Australian people the compact of the 1982-83 Budget. It was perfectly clear from Budget night on that it intended to abrogate the undertakings that were included in that Budget. What it hoped was that the Budget would be sufficient to get it over the election that it so much feared, and it would then have an opportunity, early in this year, to abrogate it and to recast it in a way more to its liking and a way more capable of proper achievement. I mentioned yesterday the sort of devices to which the former Liberal-National Party Government would have resorted if it had been given the task of sorting out the absolute economic shambles that it had created as a result of that Budget. What we would been presented with, at least at this time, had there been an election late last year, would have been tax increases of $15 a week for every taxpayer in Australia. That is the only way which would have been consistent with the approach which was followed by the former Government in relation to balancing the Budget. When there was a need to reduce the deficit, a need to bring the Budget more into balance, it resorted to increased taxes and year after year we were confronted with continual increases in taxes. Punishing rates of taxes were visited upon the Australian people by the former Government despite the fact that in November 1975 it said:
Our reforms will give back to people money they earned by their own hard work and which Labor has taken away from them.

In fact, in the seven dark Fraser years, total tax increased from 23 cents in the dollar in 1975-76 to 26c in the dollar by 1982-83. In the tax field, it said it would do something about tax avoidance. It said:
We will move to close loopholes which permit tax avoidance.
In 1980 it said:
We are clamping down on tax avoidance.

We have only to recall the disastrous sequence of last year with the presentation of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The report stated:
This industry-
It referred to the tax avoidance industry-

has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years, at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush . . . The amounts involved are very large indeed, amounting to many hundreds of millions of dollars per year or more . The impact on the community has been very serious.

This occurred under a government which promised to end tax avoidance loopholes, a government which pretended that it was clamping down on tax avoidance. We have had to wait for the new Labor Government to fulfil that particular promise and end forever the scourge of tax avoidance in this country. It will be with a great deal of pleasure that later today I will introduce into this House measures which will clean up the dreadful mess of the bottom-of-the-harbour scandal which prospered under the neglect of the former Government.

I find it extraordinarily difficult to take seriously these sorts of allegations by the Opposition. What is being proposed to us in this matter of public importance is something which absolutely defies explanation. It is the most banal farce that we have ever seen in the Parliament. The case presented by the honourable member for Boothby absolutely defies any sort of reasonable explanation. He did not have a case. The Opposition is desperate for an issue to debate, it is desperate to find any vulnerability in this great Government that is managing the affairs of this country. I can tell honourable members that there are some very important promises which the Australian people do care about . They care about our promise to create 500,000 jobs in the next three years. They care about our promise to restore some sort of sanity to industrial relations. They care about the prices and incomes accord which will provide the basis for sustained economic recovery in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just listened to a very weak defence on behalf of the Government by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). Once again, of course, the Government is attempting to blame the former Government for the problems which it is creating and the promises which it, as a government is breaking in this country day by day. This is a very important matter of public importance, if only to serve to remind the Government of the promises that it made prior to 5 March and the number of promises it is breaking day by day. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) has listed a great number of them . The Government's record of broken promises has already unnerved many sections of the community which were led to believe that a Hawke Government would carry out its promises. As the honourable member for Boothby so aptly said, the Australian Labor Party's promises were given a degree of credibility when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), prior to the election, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.

The Hawke Labor Government was elected after promising, on 16 February, immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australian taxpayers. Yet, three days after the Labor Government was elected the Prime Minister said:
we will have to reconsider the whole of our program.
Then on 21 March the Prime Minister said on the Mike Walsh Show:

If there has to be some delay of the tax cuts, it will not be because Bob Hawke has decided so. It will be because the community, through their representative bodies essentially agree that it is part of what has to be done.

Then, of course, we had the National Economic Summit Conference. It was used as a forum to tell the Australian people we were in a recession-as if they did not know-and used to excuse the Hawke Government from any of the promises it cared to break. Do honourable members remember the promise to cut fuel prices by 3c a litre? What happened to that bold promise? What happened to the 3c a litre price cut? We were told that Labor is committed to the maintenance of family allowances. On 16 February the Labor Party leader made that commitment in his policy speech. He said that Labor was committed to the maintenance of family allowances. yet, less than three weeks after the election the Prime Minister said:
I've said to all my Ministers that everything has got to be examined.

He refused to say whether family allowances would be retained or would not be means tested. Press reports now indicate that taxation allowances for certain sectors of the community are likely to be abolished. We have been told that the investment allowances are to be axed. If that Government wants to create more unemployment in this country I cannot think of a better way to achieve it.

Press reports indicate that the farmers are to be singled out by having some of their taxation concessions removed after having suffered one of the longest and worst droughts this century. These hard-won concessions are supposed to offset the disabilities that have been occasioned to the primary industries of this country as a result of the tariff structure which we are told is designed to protect manufacturing industry and to protect jobs. I think the feeling was summed up this morning in the Australian Financial Review which indicated that farmers are likely to be the victims of the min-Budget cost restraints. What about the promises that were made to the farmers of this country during that election campaign? In the great election speech which was made at Griffith in New South Wales we were given an assurance that the farming community of this country would not be attacked. Of course it will be attacked as it was by the Whitlam Government in those three dreadful years.

We are warned that the taxation rebates on housing interest rates presently enjoyed by millions of Australian home buyers will be axed. What about the Government's housing bond policy? There are already indications that Cabinet is about to renege on this policy. Then, of course, there is the classic case of the promised removal of sales tax on retreaded tyres. On 23 February the new Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) informed Mr Woodward, the Executive Director of the Commerical Vehicle Industry Association, that a Labor government, recognising the disruptive potential of a sales tax on retreaded tyres, would support appropriate legislative action to restore the previous taxation position for retreaded tyres. Now the Prime Minister quite blatantly has walked away from this promise. He blandly blames the deficit he has inherited from the previous Government. On 11 February the Age newspaper captioned an article, 'ALP 500,000 job offer. Hawke pledges tax cuts on lower, middle incomes'. That refers to a 500,000 job offer from the Australian Labor Party. Not one damn job has been created. In fact, the Government has done everything in its power to stop jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmania.

—It has tried to stop jobs in Tasmania on a dam. It has interfered with practically every program. What has happened to the Bicentennial Road Development Program? Not one shire in my electorate has received this year's allocation for its local road program. What is the Government doing about these programs? What is it doing about the Darwin-Alice Springs railway? It is mute on that issue but it was not mute before 5 March. It is walking away from one jolly promise after another. Where are those half a million new jobs? Where are the tax cuts? The Government gives us a sob story that it inherited the problem. It talked about a projected Budget deficit of $9.6 billion that came to hand in early February-March.

SPEECH.PARA: There are four good reasons why those figures could not be taken as a true guide to the final shape of any responsible Budget. Firstly, the Estimates at that time of the year are notoriously unreliable. Secondly, there is no way that a Liberal-National Party Government would have tolerated a $9.6 billion deficit. Thirdly, Labor's new-found concern-it is a new-found concern-for Budget deficits flew in the face of its electoral promises. The Government cannot have it both ways. It cannot be a humbug and a hypocrite and at the same time try to blame other people for policies that it has followed and pursued for as long as I can remember. This is a high expenditure Government. It is not afeard by Budget deficits. It has promoted and advocated them. Fourthly, Labor made its pre- election promises with reckless lack of concern for the current state of the economy. Since the polling day it has sought to retreat from promise after promise behind a smokescreen of blaming the former Government and the National Economic Summit Conference. That was the cleverest fraud and act of deception in my political career. If the Government is looking for something from which to gain credit, that is about the only thing it could be given credit for in its three months in office.

The Government has attempted constantly to blame the previous Government. It has learned that from Nifty Wran in New South Wales. He has been a classic, but all the chickens are coming home to roost on the top of his head. I hope they do a good job on him too. But the Prime Minister and his Ministers assured Australians that the National Economic Summit Conference would achieve the degree of responsibility that Australians are looking for on the wages front. But what has happened? Yesterday the Australian Council of Trade Unions resolved to demand a non-negotiable claim for full wage indexation from the March quarter this year and it will demand a catch-up. This decision has put an end to the promise of consensus, reconciliation and rehabilitation-the so-called new era of employer-employee relationships. We were told that the prices and incomes accord with the unions would ensure responsibility. What a lot of hogwash. How long does it think it can go around this country trying to convince the people that it is fair dinkum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether in the history of the Parliament there has been a more cynical matter of public importance raised by any Opposition. The wording of it is:

SPEECH.PARA: The erosion of public confidence because of the growing list of broken Government promises.

One would be forgiven for believing that those words had been directed against the previous Government. I was interested to see that the person chosen, conscripted, to raise the matter of public importance this morning was the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). He is a newcomer, a fledgling clean-skin, to the front bench of the Opposition. I wonder why one of the former Ministers on the front bench was not given the responsibility and the opportunity to raise such a matter of public importance. Was it because they are too closely identified with the deception, the fraud and the falsifications of the previous government? They would have made it a burlesque indeed had they raised this matter of public importance this morning. So it was left to one of the new recruits on the front bench, supported of course by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who is a former Minister. I believe that while he was a member of that Government he probably tried to distance himself as far as he possibly could from those frauds and falsifications.

Those are the very people who, during the time of the previous Government, were led by a man whose name we see blazoned across walls in the suburbs of the cities of Australia-'Fraser lies'. He is the person to whom the front page of the Illawarra Mercury referred. The whole of the front page was taken up with three words-'Lies, lies, lies'. Those are the people who, with cynical hypocricy , have the audacity here this morning to raise as a matter of public importance the question of the growing list of broken Government promises. Let it go on the record that to a very large extent those promises-if there have been any broken promises, and if there are to be any broken promises-were based on the assumption that the information which had been given by the previous Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is the present shadow Treasurer, could reasonably have been expected by the present Government to be statements of substance. The honourable member for Bennelong shakes his head. Who was the person in Australia with the responsibility and the authority to speak with some basic understanding and knowledge of the Budget deficit that might be projected for next year? If it was not the Treasurer in the previous Federal Government who could it have been?

The previous Treasurer indicated that the Budget deficit for next year would be in the vicinity of $6,000m. I have indicated that this is well documented, and on some future occasion we can debate it more adequately. The former Treasurer said that the Budget deficit would be in the vicinity of $6,000m at a time when he knew that it would be at least $8,000m. He had been informed as early as February this year by the Department of the Treasury that it would be approaching twice what the projected deficit was for this year at that time; that is, about $4 billion. The projected deficit for 1983-84 was at least $8, 000m when the former Treasurer used the figure $6,000m. It was reasonable to expect that the Opposition could have accepted the words of the former Treasurer and that it could have accepted the former Treasurer as a man of truth, a man of substance and a man of some credibility. The Opposition could have expected to base its undertakings to the Australian people on the assumption that that information, that projection made by the former Treasurer, was a projection of substance. It proved not to be. In the face of that let us not forget, and let no member of the Opposition bench ever forget, that as the rumour started to circulate and the evidence came forward that the $6,000m figure was not one on which we could place any credence at all, prior to the election on Saturday 5 March the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was sufficiently honest with the Australian people to make this statement, which I would like to put on the record:

If we get into Government and we have the National Economic Summit Conference and the people of Australia find out that Mr Fraser and Mr Howard haven't been telling the truth-that the Budget deficit is very much higher . . . and there is consensus at the Summit that there would have to be some modification of our programs, then obviously we would accede to that.
He went on to say:
I haven't got the capacity to say what modification there may have to be, because whether there would have to be depends on whether Mr Fraser has been telling the truth.

Now we know that the former Prime Minister was not telling the truth. After Saturday 5 March we found out that the projected Budget deficit for next year was to be in the vicinity of $9.6 billion not the $6 billion that had been referred to by the former Treasurer even at the time that he knew it would be a minimum of $8 billion. In the light of that, it was understandable that the Prime Minister would seek, and would receive, the endorsement of all of those sections and interests of the Australian people that were represented in this very chamber during the Summit Conference. Peak councils of industry, peak councils of trade unions and all major sections of the Australian community represented in this chamber endorsed that proposition that the Prime Minister put forward. So well might we ask these members on the Opposition benches: Who in heaven's name do they represent in the Australian community? Certainly they do not represent the people who were represented at the Summit Conference. Perhaps they represent themselves. Perhaps they speak for themselves. Certainly, they have given no evidence since they have found themselves in Opposition, that they speak with any degree of sincerity or credibility for any section of the Australian people.

The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), to his continuing embarrassment, was conscripted by the leaders of his party to raise this matter of public importance. There was no enthusiasm in the presentation of his case. How could the honourable member for Boothby, a man who has a creditable background, stand up in this Parliament and make the claims he did, knowing that he belonged to a political party now in Opposition, which over seven years had made a cumulatively increasing number of promises to the Australian people and had repudiated almost every one of them. The honourable member for Boothby did not raise that matter of public importance on his own behalf. He was conscripted by the Peacocks and the Howards, who wanted to distance themselves from such a proposition because had they raised it-bearing in mind that they were so closely identified with the previous Government and its deceptions and falsifications- the whole procedure would have been a greater burlesque than it has proved to be so far. This Parliament and the Australian people can dismiss the proposition put forward by the Opposition this morning as a miserable attempt to suggest that after a period of some 70 days all of the undertakings that have been given should have been put into effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Hon. Les Johnson)-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Not again!
—Yes, again. And the honourable member will go on hearing it because he does not like to. I will go on.
—Order! Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—During the course of his speech the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) made the totally dishonest, misleading and untrue statement--
—I think the honourable member should withdraw that.
—I will not withdraw it because what I am saying is true.
—Order! It is not in order for the honourable member to describe another honourable member as having been dishonest.

—It is apparently in order to describe in this House the former Prime Minister of this country as having been dishonest, but it is apparently not in order for somebody on this side to use the same language. With respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like more consistency in the attitude of the Chair on language of that kind. The honourable member for Hunter--
—Order! the honourable member cannot proceed along those lines .
—Well, the honourable member for Hunter used a misleading--
—Order! Is the honourable member seeking the attention of the Chair?
—I am, sir.
—Are you taking a point of order?
—No, sir. I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Is leave granted?
—Did he withdraw the word 'dishonest'?
—Order! Leave is not granted. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—In other words, the Government is denying me the opportunity of correcting a false statement.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—The honourable member knows the forms of the House. He can make a personal explanation, but we will not give him leave to make a statement. If he wants to take the procedures--
—Order! The honourable member is not now seeking to make a personal explanation. He has concluded that matter.
—I have not, sir, with respect. I would like to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable member may proceed with his personal explanation.

—Thank you, sir. In the course of his speech, my colleague the honourable member for Hunter made the totally incorrect statement that the promises of the Labor Party in the recent election campaign were based upon a statement that I had made to the effect that next year's Budget deficit was likely to be in the order of $6,000m. The truth is that all of the promises of the Labor Party is the last election campaign were made on 16 February which was a full five or six days before any qualified reference was made by any member of the former to a figure of $6,000m. The honourable member for Hunter, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) all know that that line of argument is totally dishonest and misleading.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented in the statement just made by the former Treasurer and wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—The premise upon which he based his personal explanation is without substance. I did not claim that the former Opposition had based its election promises on the figure of $6,000m.
—Oh, you are not claiming that now?
—I am not claiming that.
—The Treasurer did so at the Summit; your Treasurer!
—That was the maximum--
—Order! The honourable member--

—I know the matter is not to be debated. I am not debating it, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Bennelong is introducing the debate . I am simply trying to explain the way in which I have been misrepresented. The honourable member for Bennelong claimed that I had indicated that the promises of the present Government were based on a $6 billion deficit. I am quite aware of the fact that the election undertakings were given at a date prior to the former Treasurer using that figure. But the $6 billion figure referred to by the former Treasurer was the maximum that had been referred to until that time. It is still true that the present Government based its election promises on the assumption that the projected deficit for 1983-84 would almost certainly be less than $6 billion.
—Produce the evidence. You haven't got any.
—Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT (ELECTION BLACKOUT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 May, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, when the Broadcasting and Television Amendment (Election Blackout) Bill 1983 was debated, the Opposition put forward a proposal not to apply the blackout to advertising. That was a matter of some astonishment for the Government. Even having regard to the standards set by the Opposition it appeared almost certain that there would be a bipartisan approach on this issue. The Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, in a research paper commissioned by the Federation in March 1981 and distributed widely within the industry, supported strongly the blackout being abolished but with the retention of the ban on paid advertising. The proposal of the Federation was endorsed without qualification by the following: Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations; Mr McDonald, International Press Institute; Rupert Public Interest Movement Incorporated; Professor Henry Mayer, Professor of Political Theory, University of Sydney; Dr Patricia Edgar, Senior Lecturer, Centre for the Study of Educational Communication and Media; Latrobe University; and the Media Studies Department, Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology.

SPEECH.PARA: There were also other endorsements of the proposals put forward by the Federation but there were some qualifications about some of them. The people I listed earlier did in fact endorse the proposal that there should be a retention of the ban on paid advertising. The paper stated quite clearly that a licensee shall not at any time between the end of an election period and the close of the poll on the day on which the election is held broadcast or televise an election advertisement. The Opposition has again adopted a one-off position. Its motives must be questioned, having regard to the appallingly deceptive standards set by its advertisements in election campaigns. In particular I just want to refer to one advertisement-the infamous wealth tax advertisements which were run by the Opposition. It would have been delightful for the Opposition but not for anybody else if those advertisements had been able to continue without any period of blackout. A final indication of the extraordinary standards of the Opposition is revealed by the views of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), now the Leader of the Opposition. On 26 January 1982 he issued a Press release on the election blackout which stated:
The Federal Member for Kooyong, Mr Andrew Peacock, welcomed the move by the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters to lift the pre-election black out on politicial news and comment.
'The continuation of the black out is an insult to the intelligence of Australian voters'.

Commenting on the Federation's report 'a proposal to end the election black out ' Mr Peacock said that the Australian people should not be denied radio and television political comment in the two days preceding an election.
Mr Peacock welcomed the Federation's compromise proposal which would allow news and current affairs broadcasts but continue the ban against advertising through the electronic media.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peacock said that?
—That was the present Leader of the Opposition. He stated that on 26 January 1982. It is worth repeating the final comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Peacock welcomed the Federation's compromise proposal which would allow news and current affairs broadcasts but continue the ban against advertising through the electronic media.

Therefore, it is quite clear why it was somewhat of a surprise last night-even having regard to what we expect from honourable members opposite-to come into the chamber and find that the Opposition intends to move an amendment at the Committee stage to remove the blackout in respect of advertising. When speaking last night the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) indicated that if he suffered a disadvantage because of something that occurred during a campaign-I assume that he was referring to campaign material generally, news, comment or something that occurred on the radio or television-he would not be able to reply . He said that under this proposal he would be able to buy time to reply. Unfortunately, that seems to me to indicate that what is behind the proposal is to lift the ban on advertising.

It is all very well for those parties, such as the Liberal Party and the National Party, with coffers full, to talk about buying time to reply. It certainly does not apply to the Government, nor to the Australian Democrats, and it is an appalling situation. The Opposition stated that the money would be used on advertising to redress what was deemed to be a wrong during the campaign. Last night the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) indicated quite clearly that that is not so easy for people to do, other than members of the Liberal and National parties. Last night he went through in detail what advertisements were in fact booked during a campaign by the then Government, which is now somewhat depleted and in opposition. In fact the time slots were taken up to such a stage where if somebody wanted to reply by advertisement it would have been very difficult to find a time when anybody would have been listening to the radio or watching television to hear what was said.

It is disappointing that on this issue the honourable member for Murray conceded and was quite open about the fact that many in Opposition have doubts about lifting the ban-the Opposition can not adopt a bipartisan approach. We heard what it thought of the Bill. We have heard what the Leader of the Opposition thought about it as late as January last year. This morning I think we heard of one instance of what this Government has done or should have done. Since 1949 the Opposition has been in government in this country for 30 years and there has been considerable criticism from all kinds of people about this matter. In fact the criticism was so strong that we had reached the stage where there would have been an inquiry in relation to this matter. The infringement of civil liberties by this ban should not be tolerated in a democratic society. The fact of the matter is that prior to the last election the Human Rights Commission had already initiated an inquiry into section 116 of the Broadcasting and Television Act-the section which contains the blackout provisions-on the grounds that it violated internationally accepted political rights. After 30 years in government, since 1949, those opposite did nothing about this matter. This Government has acted quickly and it is indeed disappointing that we are going to have to argue the question of whether the blackout provision in relation to advertising should be removed. In addition to the amendment which will be moved in the Committee stage by the honourable member for Murray, there will also be an amendment moved by the Government, which is necessary to tidy up one aspect of the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, pages 1 to 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Broadcasting or televising of political matter or controversial matter
''3. Section 116 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by omitting sub-sections (4) and (4A); and
(b) by omitting sub-sections (6) and substituting the following sub-section:
'(6) In this section-
''election'' means an election of members, or of a member, of-
(a) the Senate or the House of Representatives; or
(b) a House of the Parliament of a State;
''election matter'', in relation to an election, means matter of any of the following kinds:
(a) matter commenting on, or soliciting votes for, a candidate at the election;
(b) matter commenting on, or advocating support of, a political party to which a candidate at the election belongs;

(c) matter commenting on, stating or indicating any of the matters being submitted to the electors at the election or any part of the policy of a candidate at the election or of the political party to which a candidate at the election belongs; or
(d) matter referring to a meeting held or to be held in connection with the election;

''election period'', in relation to an election, means the period that commences on the day on which the writ for the election is issued and ends at the close of the poll on the polling day for the election;
''licensee'' means the holder of a licence within the meaning of Part III B.'.' '.

This amendment, in effect, would remove all restrictions on the electronic media for the whole election period between the issuing of the writs and the close of the poll. The difference between our amendment and the Government's Bill is that the Government legislation lifts the ban on the electronic media only for news and commentary; it does not do so for advertisements. So it is still not possible for advertisements to be placed on the electronic media between midnight on the Wednesday and the close of the poll. This brings with it several other complications, including requirements for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal still to determine which radio or television stations can or cannot do certain things during those final two or three days of an election campaign. The Opposition amendment completely clears all of this doubt and removes all those sorts of inhibitions and complications from the Broadcasting and Television Act. The Opposition moves this amendment for the following reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it has $500m to spend.
—The honourable member should just listen and he might learn something for a change.
— Not from you.

—It was Labor policy, exactly, in 1980 to do this. So he should be careful before he starts putting his foot in his mouth, in the way that some Ministers have been doing. If we compare what is available to the print media and what is available to the electronic media, we find that the only fair course is to lift the ban on the electronic media completely so that they are as unrestricted as the print media. Any newspaper can take any advertisement, print any news or make any comment right through an election period. With the Government legislation the electronic media will still be disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: One hears in the debate comments about double standards and hypocrisy. But let us look a little at what the Australian Labor Party has been doing in this situation. I acknowledge quite freely that on both sides there have been differences of opinion as this debate has developed, particularly over the last few years. But looking at the Labor position in 1980, one finds that the Leader of the Labor Party, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden), stated quite clearly that he was opposed to the lifting of the ban. As recently as 1980 that was Labor Party policy. It was stated in 1980 by the Labor Party that once public funding for elections came in that party would be in favour of lifting the ban completely, which is exactly what we are recommending in this amendment. So, when we are talking about being bipartisan, let us look at that situation, and let us look at the position of the Australian Democrats, who are also in favour of completely lifting the ban on the electronic media.

The point about paying for advertisements has been made. I remind honourable members of one thing: That in the Broadcasting and Television Act there is no provision whereby a person who is maligned in news or comment on the electronic media in those last two days can be granted time to reply. The only requirement in the Act is that reasonable opportunity over the whole election period be given to those parties, politicians, or candidiates represented in the previous House. That means that it could be claimed by a station owner that someone has been given a run in an earlier stage of an election period and there is no specific requirement to provide equal time, or any time, for that candidate to reply.

The point has been made about the so-called coffers of the parties on this side . The point here is that if a person is not given that automatic right to reply surely in desperation he has one last opportunity, and that is to buy time. Anyone who has been so maligned in such a tight situation would, I am sure, make certain that he could buy time. The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) has made the point that booking schedules can be tight. I acknowledge that. Nevertheless, this amendment provides an opportunity for someone so maligned to have some comeback because there is no automatic comeback provided in this legislation.

To sum up, the reasons for our amendment are as follows: First, if one is fair dinkum about really lifting the ban on the electronic media and putting it on an equal footing with the print media there is only one thing to do, and that is to accept this amendment, which lifts it completely-which was Labor Party policy also at one stage. Secondly, because an automatic right of reply is not given in the legislation to somebody who is maligned or disadvantaged in some way through news and commentary issued in the last couple of days before an election, allowing advertising as well provides at least a potential fall back position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to the matter very briefly indeed. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), in his address to the House this morning, referred to a Press statement of mine last year and, as a consequence, sought to indicate that the Opposition was being two-faced and hypocritical on this matter. I want to point out that the statement that the Minister read to the Parliament which was issued by me, as I recall, early last year, was in fact correct. I did welcome the move by the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters as a compromise in a difficult circumstance in which very few people were prepared to go as far as we are going in moving this amendment today. But I did it as a first step.

SPEECH.PARA: My views on this issue go back into the mid-1960s, both in my own party's councils before election to this Parliament, in the coalition party room in 1966 and indeed, for further corroboration so far as this House is concerned, to a debate on the Broadcasting and Television Bill in this House on 1 May 1969 when I said, among other things:
I therefore put it to the Minister that the ban on the broadcasting of election matter during the 3 days prior to the close of the poll is outmoded.
I went on to talk about what one can read in newspapers, and said:
All--
Not just comment--
that pertains to the electoral battle that is going on.
I said:
Frankly, I believe that this legislation belongs to a bygone era. I think it is a negation of the principle that news should be unfettered.
Then I took the matter beyond news, and said:

. . . it is an absurd piece of legislation which debars television and radio stations from fulfilling their role of bringing current news and information on all major issues of the day to the public. I urge the Minister to consider whether the Act can be amended in this regard before the next Federal election.

I do not need to go further on this matter. My arguments last year, both in public and in the party room, were predicated on a twofold viewpoint-that I had long argued for unfettered utilisation of advertising, news, comment and the like in radio and television. But if this could not be achieved by agreement between the parties, I would accept the compromise that, for the first time, had been suggested by the Federation as acceptable to it, one that I understood at that stage was acceptable to the Australian Labor Party and, as a fall back position, to the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats' view had been until then similar to mine. So I have sought the thrust of this amendment before , both in the Parliament and in the party room.

We do support the Bill but go further and seek total freedom, not only for comment and news but also advertising. No accusation of double standard or hypocrisy can be directed at me. This has been a long time coming and I have been in a position to so influence my colleagues as to this particular point of view that we are moving this amendment today, As I say, my fight for the amendment goes back to the 1960s and I strongly support it. We support the Bill but also support the amendment because, if one is genuine in seeking to lift the ban and equate the print media with radio and television, it should be lifted in toto. Furthermore, it provides for greater freedom for the individuals concerned .

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I thank the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) for clarifying his Press statement but nevertheless acknowledging that that is what he said. He said that he welcomed the compromise proposal that would allow news and current affairs broadcasts but would continue the ban against advertising through the electronic media. If in fact it was the view of the honourable member at that time that advertising should not be subject to the ban, as far as I am concerned, his statement should have indicated that. It did not indicate that at all. It indicated precisely what I have said it indicated. I accept what the honourable member says about what his position was, but that is not clear from the Press release, which stated precisely what I have said it stated.
—Go back to the 1960s.

—The Leader of the Opposition referred to a debate in this Parliament in 1969 from which he read extracts. The implication in that speech in respect of advertising I thought was a little subtle but it may be that it is necessary to read the whole of the debate.
