I close on this point: That Press release indicated quite clearly what I thought was clear support for the Bill without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), in his second reading speech, referred to the blackout as an infringement of our civil liberties which should not be tolerated by a democratic society. He referred to it as an abrogation of free speech. He referred to Australia as a democratic society with a mature electorate and responsible broadcasters. Suddenly, however, he denied all that in the legislation as far as advertising is concerned. He said: 'Right, we cannot have this infringement, this abrogation of commentary. But, by God, we are going to have it as far as advertising is concerned'. I do not see the reality of the distinction. I am sure the Minister would agree that many commentaries are at least very similar to advertisements and are camouflaged advertisements. Surely he would agree that on many occasions some advertisements have been more informative than commentaries.

SPEECH.PARA: There must have been many occasions in the Australian Labor Party's history in elections when it took the view-it may well have been a correct view-that the advertisements which it placed were more informative and more accurate than the commentaries on its policies. Certainly, that has been the case on many occasions from the Liberal Party's point of view. So the distinction between commentary and advertisement is not one that can be maintained. Certainly, as the Minister said, there have been some appalling advertisements in the history of political advertising but surely he would agree that there have also been some appalling commentaries in the history of commentary. If the blackout restrictions are an intolerable abrogation of the rights of a mature electorate and responsible broadcasters then they are equally intolerable for advertisements as for commentaries.

To some extent the Minister relied on the support he was getting from a number of the media groups. He cited the Federation of Australian Commerical Television Stations, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia, the Australian Newspapers Council, the Australian Journalists Association and so on. Yet the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, in a footnote to its proposal, notes that the Public Broadcasting Association, the Australian Newspapers Council and the Australian Journalists Association reject this distinction. They go along with the proposal of FARB which the Minister has adopted, nevertheless, they reject the distinction which the Minister has incorporated in the Bill. I would be surprised if the other supporters of FARB, Professor Henry Mayer and Dr Patricia Edgar agree with it.

As I indicated in my speech last night there is something to be said for the status quo. But, if we are going to change then we should change consistently and equally for advertisers and commentators. Let us take seriously the Minister 's words about getting rid of an infringement of our civil liberties which should not be tolerated, getting rid of an abrogation of free speech and acknowledging a democratic society with a mature electorate and resposible broadcasters. Let us make the change consistently and equally for commentators and advertisers. There is no fundamental difference between the two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this Committee today I have heard a number of comments that, unfortunately, we have heard time and again in the House and outside in the industry. I would call them airy-fairy nonsense. While some of what the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), said sounded okay, in the practical world of the industry, it was just nonsense. I will elaborate on that as we go along. The Melbourne Age today carries the headline: 'Opposition switch on election blackout'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Liberal and National parties have done an about-face on their attitude to the election blackout, and are now urging its total elimination.

One must ask why. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has put his point of view but the question 'why?' can really be answered by looking at the money that is involved and how much money people have to throw into paid political advertising. For example, during the last election the previous Government got desperate and we saw two-minute advertisements with Malcolm Fraser being the sole participant. In the last week of available time the then Government ran two -minute advertisements in prime time. generally speaking, two minutes is the entire advertising time in one break. The cost of those advertisements throughout Australia would have amounted to tens of thousands of dollars. But, of course, the conservative parties are able to dig deep into their slush funds and bring out money for such emergencies. It did not help them on that occasion, but we have seen it time and again.

The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) referred to the wealth tax advertisements in the 1980 election campaign. Of course, in 1977 the Liberal- Country Party Government even ran an extra half-hour show on the Wednesday night . That would have cost the Government in excess of six figures, without any exaggeration, just to make sure that it retained office.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you don't believe in civil liberties?

—I will get to that in a minute. There is more to come. When talking of paid political advertising I must raise the question of whether we should in fact have paid political advertising at all because, as the Opposition knows, Australia is one of the few countries in the world that allows paid political advertising. The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) nods his head so obviously he agrees. Why should the Opposition parties, because they have more money than any other party, be able to fill the airwaves with a whole lot of drivel? The latest figures I have relate to the 1980 election campaign. On 15 October-three days before the election-the Melbourne Age ran an article, which was accompanied by a graph, headed 'Liberal commercials on Melbourne TV'. I repeat that they were on Melbourne television only. In an INSIGHT article it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: However, INSIGHT obtained a copy of the Liberal advertising booking schedule for Victoria between 28 September and 18 October.
The document, prepared by D'Arcy-MacManus and Masius, shows the extent of the Liberals' campaign.

The Liberals have also booked heavily in daily newspapers. They have taken nine full-page advertisements in 'The Age' at an estimated cost of $38,000. Similar full-page advertisements in the 'Sun' the 'Herald' and the 'Australian' will cost about $35,000 for each paper.
On the subject of the electronic media it refers to television and the graph accompanying the article. The article states:

On television, Melbourne's three commercial stations will have shown more than 190 'spots' of 60, 30 and 10-second duration before the blanket ban on political advertising comes into effect from midnight. The metropolitan television campaign will end up costing the Liberals nearly $200,000.

That was $200,000 in 1980. It would probably be $300,000 now. The honourable member for Murray tries to equate television advertising with advertising in the Press. Any dummy knows that television advertising is much more profitable for political propaganda. Why do sponsors, whether advertising politics, political parties or jams for that matter, want to put their advertising on television and not in the newspapers? It is because television is much more effective. That was the sort of money spent in 1980 and, as I have said, it would probably be more like $300,000 now. In fact 192 spot commericals were put forward by the Liberals in Melbourne alone. Twenty-eight per cent of those were of 10-second duration. What great monumental policy points were put forward in those 10-second commericals? The answer is absolutely none. What is the point of them-absolutley none. If one has the money one can just plaster people with a whole lot of emotive issues. Why does the Opposition not wish to have current affairs and news programs discussed at length and a debate of the real issues of the day?

As the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) said yesterday in his speech at the second reading stage, advertising will not correct deception. If we are to correct deceptions which occur at the last minute we must look at news or current affairs programs. For example, if there were a deception on a Wednesday the following process would occur: First of all, the commerical would have to be made; then it would have to be slotted in. In the practical world one does not front up to the Channel 9 network on a Friday morning, unless it is heavily on one's side-it might be possible but I would not think so-and say: ' Can you slot these half a dozen one-minute commericals into your transmission tonight?' That is nonsense. All the slots are booked out. According to the rules of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal the channels are allowed to show only so much advertising. Unless they elbow out some jam or vegemite commercials, which I do not think the sponsors would like, one does not get a run. As I started off by saying, there are certain practicalities that come into this whole argument in the practical world of television.

This Government is aware, unlike the Opposition, that television is the most effective means of advertising and putting across one's point. The Government, with the Minister, has proposed a Tribunal inquiry regarding a fairness code. That inquiry will be announced in the foreseeable future by the Minister. He has spoken about this before in this chamber. I am quite sure that with that fairness code and with allowing news and current affairs programs to run right up until the day of the election-I believe they should be allowed to run right up until election day-we will have a system unequalled anywhere else in the world. I do not believe we should be able to bombard people with paid political time, depending on the resources that one has, right up until the day. In fact, I have doubts about whether we should allow it at all. The honourable member for Wentworth spoke about appalling advertisements. They would be the fault of the party. If they are appalling or wrong the party or its agency which put them forward would be to blame.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the wealth tax.

—That is right. Just to reaffirm my point regarding paid political advertising, many countries in Europe, that is, the United Kingdom, Sweden, Netherlands, West Germany, France, Norway and Denmark-virtually all of the European countries-while admitting that they have various systems, do not allow paid political advertising. They all have effective rules and regulations in regard to news and commentaries and what they will allow the various parties to do and how long the slots will be. The system is geared in what would be termed a fairness code. The Minister has announced that an inquiry will take place before the Tribunal soon. I welcome that. I believe the legislation before the Committee is fair and will give everyone a fair go. It is time it was put into place. We reject the amendment put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken to my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). He knows that I cannot support the amendment, nor can I support the Broadcasting and Television Amendment (Election Blackout) Bill that is before the Committee. I will not be doing anything remarkable, such as crossing the floor or trying to get notoriety, because I accept that it is very much a matter of opinion. I have accepted and respected the opinions of both the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and the Government and also members of the Opposition. I see a danger in the matter of last minute deception. I see it as being much more dangerous with the electronic media than with the newspapers. I have a feeling that I cannot disabuse myself of the view that electronic media , particularly television, have attained an unfortunately and undesirably disproportionate influence on political and election matters. I think that this happens more through political public affairs segments and radio phone-ins than advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to take up the time of the Committee but I just want to put a simple point of view. I am sure that the blackout, as well as being regarded by the viewing and listening public as a merciful relief for a couple of days, is on balance more desirable for the purpose of quiet reflection. I would support the retention of the blackout. I privately see this as something of a safeguard. I am a director of a broadcasting company and probably my view is not in accord with the general views of broadcasters and televisers. However, this is my own private and honest view and I am bound to express it. Therefore I cannot support either the amendment or the Bill before the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I need to make a couple of points with respect to paid political advertising. The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) has already spoken to a degree about this. Perhaps I should simply elaborate a few points. I think that one of the emphases that we need to get across is that one of the main goals of advertising is to change people's judgments and perceptions. If we look at that in the context of an election campaign we have to ask the serious question: Why do those opposite wish to go on changing people's perceptions and judgments right up to the day of an election? Is it because they want to do something to change their performance or the image of their performance in the minds of the electorate? I think that is a very clear issue to which we have to address ourselves. We have no doubts on our side that there is nothing wrong with allowing the print media and the electronic media to have a free exercise of debate right up to the time of an election. Our concern is that the electronic media should not be used to change peoples' perceptions right up to election day. I really wonder why those opposite seem to be so concerned to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing to consider is that we ought to recognise, as the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Adermann) mentioned, that members of the public themselves perhaps have a right not to be bombarded right up to election day. I am sure, having spoken to many electors, that people breathed a sigh of relief when advertisements went off the air because it meant that at least they could get back to looking at regular television programs without a large amount of advertising being inflicted on them.

It is also interesting to reflect that during the recent Federal election campaign the then Government spent a substantial amount of money on election advertising. The Committee will recall that during that time we also had the tragic bushfires in Australia. We might reflect that if the then Government had not had that opportunity to spend money on advertising it might well have diverted some of its resources to relieving the distress of some of the people involved in the bushfires. I know that we in the electorate of Stirling made a decision to help those people rather than spend more money on advertising. I am sure some people in the electorate were rather pleased about that. I think we really have to ask the question: Is it not a continued misuse and misdirection of resources to allow paid political advertising right up to the day of an election? Bearing in mind my earlier comment that we have to recognise that first of all advertising is designed to change people's perceptions, should we allow that to occur right up to the day? Is there something wrong with the performance of a party if it needs to work at changing people's judgments right up to the election day? It might be better to allow the media freely to develop an analysis of the way in which a party is performing.

I think the second point that has to be established is that the electorate perhaps has some right to be able to say: 'We would like to be free from being bombarded, at least for the last few hours before an election'. I think that very often in this place we work on the assumption that members of the public out there like to hear everything we say and know everything we do. I think we realistically ought to recognise that sometimes they would be much freer and much happier if we were not bombarding them with election material. Therefore, to wrap up my comments, we on this side are quite happy to allow the normal public affairs radio and television activities to continue but we wonder why it is so important to allow people's judgments on political matters to be bent and turned right up to the last minute.
Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Lloyd's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the amendment to clause 3, circulated in my name, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, lines 5 and 6, omit the words 'in a substantial part', substitute 'in a part'.

This is a drafting matter. The amendment is needed to cover a possible loophole which could exist in regard to Senate elections and some large rural electorates where radio and television coverage extends over only a small part of the electorate. The amendment closes the loophole so that the Bill applies to Senate elections and those large rural electorates in the same way as other elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just as we do not oppose the Bill generally, we certainly do not oppose this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the debate will shortly be interrupted so I do not intend to speak at length now. I just point out at this time that the Bill we are to discuss, the Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Bill 1983, is one to which the Opposition has no objection. I often hear people commenting about the way in which the proceedings of this place are conducted and they all too often observe the confrontation and dispute that takes place. From time to time they ask us whether there is anything upon which we agree. I am pleased to observe that this is another of the many Bills which proceed through Parliament which has a measure of agreement from both sides. When I am able to resume my remarks I will explain why the Opposition agrees so readily to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to be directed to the Prime Minister. I am prepared to wait for a little time, Mr Speaker, until the Prime Minister fulfils his obligations and enters the House.

—I address my question to the Treasurer. Does the Government's economic strategy depend on restraining wages, said to have been agreed at the National Economic Summit Conference? Did the Prime Minister assert on 17 April that this meant limiting this year's wage rises to 3 to 4 per cent, which Mr Dolan now dismisses as a figment of the media's imagination? Does the demand by the Australian Council of Trade Unions for a 2.2 per cent rise for three months together with full indexation for the remainder of 1983 destroy the restraint involved in the Prime Minister's proposed 3 to 4 per cent rise? What would be the impact of what the ACTU is now demanding on the Government's economic and unemployment strategy?

—The Government has put its position very clearly on a number of occasions, and I think that the latest occasion was yesterday, when the Prime Minister was questioned at Question Time about where the Government stands on wages policy. We have said, firstly, that we would return to a centralised wage fixation system and at the case in June we will be putting views to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commisssion on that basis. We have said that any increase in the latter part of calendar year 1983 should be limited to a basis of between 3 and 4 per cent. That was the Prime Minister's position yesterday. It will remain his position and the Government's position today. I see nothing necessarily inconsistent between that objective and the statements by the ACTU yesterday.

—Not necessarily inconsistent-and also stressing that there must be acceptance of the Summit principle that any increases outside the national wage case be strictly confined. Concerning catch-up, I answered the Deputy Leader of the Opposition last week by saying that any--
—I was not talking about catch-up. You do not understand the question. I did not ask about catch-up.
—The honourable member asked me about the ACTU's 2.2 per cent. I have made it quite clear--
—That is not catch-up; that is current.
—That is current, exactly, and it is not necessarily--
—The Treasurer does not know what he is talking about.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.
—I thought that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition could understand precisely what I have just said.
—You are the person who does not understand the catch-up.

—I said that the 2.2 per cent is not necessarily inconsistent with a 3 to 4 per cent increase in calendar year 1983, as expressed by the Prime Minister yesterday. That is what I said about the current, and I repeat it. As to the catch-up-which the honourable member may not have asked me about but which I shall indicate anyway-let me just say this: I made it clear last week about the catch-up that any increase in real wages will depend on the economy's capacity to pay it. I indicated in that answer that when scenario A was put into the modelling, any catch-ups in that respect would be delayed until 1985.
—So you support catch-up?

—This is important. I wonder why I have to repeat it two or three times. Will the honourable member please listen? What I am saying is that any increase in real wages will be predicated only on the capacity of the economy to pay it. That is what I said to the honourable member last week; that is what I have just said again.
—What about catch-up?
—An increase in real wages is about the catch-up.
—Order! I invite the Treasurer not to take any notice of the supplementary questions.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition apparently does not know the difference between an increase in real wages and the maintenance of real wages. In terms of an increase in real wages, the catch-up will need to be delayed until there is a clear capacity in the economy to pay it. I simply indicate again that in terms of scenario A, in terms of that modelling exercise, when we looked at the catch-up there, it said quite clearly that it could not be contemplated until 1985.
—Is the Minister for Science and Technology aware of any attempts to quantify the employment creating potential of government assistance to high technology industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Sydney for his question. I have been preoccupied for many years about the impact of high technology on employment. Several points need to be made. First, most of the high technology industries are not in themselves large employers but, as in the mining industry, which is a perfect analogy, the major impact on employment is in second and third order effect, through expansion in directly related employment and indirectly through wealth creation, raising levels of discretionary income with its impact on service employment growth. The second order employment effects of high technology industries are generally estimated in Australia as being of the order of between 4 : 1 and 6 : 1. I was at the offices of Nucleus Ltd in Sydney recently. It has done a quite precise measurement and its calculation is that it is a 4 : 1 ratio; some other companies suggest a 6 : 1 ratio.

ANSWER.PARA: The third order effects are far more significant. High technology industries, which often have growth rates of between 40 per cent and 60 per cent per annum, even in the mature periods, make an enormous contribution to overall gross domestic product growth rates. Sweden and the Netherlands, for example, are high technology nations with very limited raw materials or natural resources compared with Australia. Nevertheless, Sweden has a GDP which is 54 per cent higher than Australia's and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Access to European markets.

—Yes, but there is competition in Europe. I mean, it has been known to have one or two-odd high technology products from Germany, France and Italy! We have to take that into account. The Netherlands GDP is 26 per cent per capita higher, with significantly lower unemployment. After seven years of economic ruin brought about by those people opposite our greatest problem is to convert our static economy to a dynamic economy. Many Australians felt very comfortable in the 1950s and they felt that we should keep Australia in the 1950s. That is exactly what the Opposition's policy is--
—That is not Liberal policy.

—Or in the case of Tasmania, in the 1930s. But we cannot secure our future by trying to stay 30 years behind our industrial contemporaries. High technology is a vital factor in restoring dynamism and economic health. If we fail to develop and export our own high technology industries we will become increasingly dependent on imports. This would have disastrous impacts on our trade balance, the value of our currency and employment generally.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. As a consequence of the Treasurer's answer to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, which clearly indicated a catch-up, I ask: Has the Prime Minister also seen Mr Dolan's call on behalf of the Australian Council of Trade Unions for a 2.2 per cent increase for the March quarter followed by similar full quarterly increases for the remainder of the year? Is the Prime Minister aware that this call has been criticised already by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures, the Victorian Chamber of Manfactures and the Victorian Employers Federation, and indeed was described by one industry spokesman as 'unadulterated stupidity and madness'? Put shortly, will the Government be supporting the claim by the ACTU or is its so-called accord with the unions now in ruins?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much indebted to the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I have seen the reports in the media of what are purported to be decisions of the ACTU. I have seen also the criticisms by people, including those to whom the honourable gentleman has referred. The third part of his question embraces the phrase 'unadulterated stupidity' concerning the position of the ACTU. Let me very briefly make it clear to the Leader of the Opposition-I had hoped that he would have understood from my answer of yesterday-that the position of the Government will be determined by the Government, not by anyone else. The position of the Government in respect of wages policy will be clearly in line with the fundamental premises which I outlined to this House yesterday. For the purpose of reminding the Opposition, and hopefully for its understanding , I repeat what they are: Firstly, an insistence upon a return to a system of centralised wage fixation; secondly, a position that will be put that any increase in 1983 will have to be a very small increase-I adhere to the position that I put that that should be of no more than the order of 3 per cent to 4 per cent, at the end of 1983; and thirdly, as I said yesterday, in respect of any increases outside national wage cases, the increases should be strictly confined and within the control of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission .

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to that, the Government's policy is clearly based upon the view that, largely because of its accession to power, there are increasing signs of confidence in the community, of a move to positive economic growth as against the negative growth which characterised the last 12 months of the previous Government, that it is important in that situation that any wage movement be minimal so that we will be in the best possible position as we go into 1984 to increase economic growth, to increase the capacity to create more jobs and to get a more equitable distribution of income in this country. In respect of that issue, which seems still to be totally beyond the comprehension of the Opposition, let me say that the question of any catch-up, which is referred to as being of the order of 9.1 per cent is, as far as this Government is concerned and as I understand it for as the ACTU is concerned, very much on the back- burner. There is no perceived room in the foreseeable future for that catch-up figure being implemented. That is the Government's position and, as I understand it, it is the position of the ACTU.

Finally, I make the point which I made in this House yesterday. As against the clear, coherent, equitable, workable wages policy of this Government we are still confronted with chaos on the other side of the House. I ask that the Leader of the Opposition take advantage of the opportunities that are being put to him to state whether the wages policy of the Opposition is that of the shadow Treasurer, which calls for a return to the free play of market forces and which resulted in the chaos and the wages explosion after the middle of 1981; or the alleged policy of the shadow Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the recent closure of the Kyneton abattoirs with serious effects upon employment opportunities in Kyneton and on the economy of Kyneton? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to newspaper reports which indicate that the management of the abattoirs considers that the closure resulted largely from a failure to gain a United States listing? Will the Minister please outline the reasons for this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I and the Government share the concern of the honourable member for Ballarat with respect to the closure of the Kyneton abattoirs. I know very well of the work he has been doing, mainly on behalf of the meat workers in his electorate who have been affected by this decision. It is a similar concern to that expressed by my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory in respect of the same set of circumstances which occurred at Tennant Creek last year. I spoke with the manager of these meat works before the elections. Also, to my knowledge he has had many, many discussions with officers of my Department since. He is well aware why approval was removed by the previous Government and why the Kyneton meat works have not been relisted as export works for the United States of America. I have personally reviewed that decision and I stick to it. It is not my intention to back down on any of these delistings in terms of the policy established by the previous Government. When a high official of the United States Department of Agriculture was in Australia recently, he confirmed to me that that is the wish of the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to the House that whereas 50 to 60 per cent of our meat exports go to the United States, Australian meat amounts to only 4 per cent of that country 's imports. It is pretty obvious that we are not indispensible to them. If we do not delist these firms as a result of the findings of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, it is quite clear that the United States will take action. The gentleman concerned, Mr Williams, has appealed to the High Court. The appeal was not upheld. The Government will relist those abattoirs only if Mr Williams complies with the procedures that are well understood by him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations: Is it not a fact that the wages pause froze the March quarter consumer price index figure so that it could not be part of the catch-up referred to by the Prime Minister? Is it not a fact, therefore, that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is highly unlikely to accede to the application from the Australian Council of Trade Unions for the passing on of the 2.2 per cent? In those circumstances what will the Government do to support the Arbitration Commission against what Mr Dolan describes as a free-for-all to put the Arbitration Commission out of business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claim by the Australian Council of Trade Unions for a 2.2 per cent increase is unlikely to be heard by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission until after 30 June because the Commission has already declared a six months wages pause. In those circumstances we must expect that that application will be heard and considered some time in July or August. If it were granted, it would not be paid in full until August. The Government has made it clear and absolutely beyond doubt that its policy is that wages will increase by no more than 3 to 4 per cent in the course of this year. It is quite clear that the March quarter increase of 2.2 per cent can be part of the basis for that 3 to 4 per cent rise. To that extent we have no problem. But we will have a problem if there is any suggestion of increases beyond 3 to 4 per cent. We are not aware that that is the case and, on that basis, we believe that the application by the ACTU for the 2.2 per cent rise is in accordance with the Government's policy.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no suggestion by the ACTU of pursuing a catch-up in any way this year. Indeed, I note that in its decision yesterday it states that the application for a 9.1 per cent rise is to be pursued over a period, consistent with the progress of economic recovery. As everyone in this House is aware, at present there is no economic recovery. We inherited an economy in a state of virtual free fall. In the next few months we expect to have arrested that free fall. We will then begin a gradual recovery and certainly, in the context of that gradual recovery, we will not be able to afford an increase in real wages for some time. That is the position we have articulated quite clearly on previous days and we do so again today. It remains our position and the House should accept now that there is a clear wages policy on this side, which is in no way upset by yesterday's decision of the ACTU. It contrasts markedly with the chaos of the wages policy on the other side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Last week's closing communique of the meeting in Paris of the Finance Ministers of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has been widely interpreted as signalling a move away from the 'fight inflation first' priority that has marked such gatherings in recent years and towards an emphasis on economic stimulus and job creation. Does the Prime Minister regard this outcome as vindicating the economic priorities of the present Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The OECD document to which the honourable member referred is indeed a profoundly important document. As distinct from the situation that obtained with the previous Government, this is not a doctored document. It in fact supports the policies of this Government. The communique certainly signals a move away from what has tended to be the policy in the past of 'fight inflation first' and in that respect it endorses the approach of this Government. But it does not do it in any simplistic way. I will put it this way: In the first place the communique indicates that the first priority must be to increase employment; it gives second place to a reduction in inflation; it gives third place to the necessity to eliminate structural rigidities in the economies of the OECD; and, in the fourth place, it gives importance to the need for additional aid and assistance to developing countries. In particular, the communique has some very sensible things to say about a steady medium term policy framework, about the balanced use of macro-economic and structural policies, about the need for labour market policies, the lack of which was a very distinguishing characteristic of the seven years of the previous Government, and of the need for social consensus.

ANSWER.PARA: One very important point that the communique does make is that in those countries of the OECD which are seeing a move back to the inflation levels of the 1960s there is very much greater scope for an emphasis on policies which will expand production. Unfortunately, as a result of the inherited policies of the previous Government, this country finds itself in a position where the inflation level is about double that of the average rate of the OECD. Therefore, the capacity of this Government to initiate such stimulatory policies with the degree of confidence that others may do is restricted. Nevertheless, I conclude my answer by saying that with a due sense of our responsibilities towards, firstly, the need to increase employment and, secondly, to reduce inflation, this Government will be taking those policies which are very much in line with this very sensible outline of policy priorities contained in this undoctored OECD document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Prime Minister by making it quite clear that it is not alleged that he was personally aware of these matters at the time that they occurred. Has the Prime Minister now been provided with information that the expelled Soviet KGB agent Ivanov had provided, or had attempted to provide, substantial financial assistance to certain organisations in Australia? Will the Prime Minister, pursuant to paragraph (d) of the letters patent, refer these matters to the royal commissioner, the Honourable Mr Justice Hope?

—In the light of the announcement that I made yesterday about the reference of all the circumstances surrounding Mr Combe and the expulsion of Mr Ivanov I believe it is not appropriate that I should, in respect of that matter or any matters dealing with the royal commission, deal with the question raised by the honourable member. But let me say this: I am sure that the honourable member will appreciate and, I hope, accept the answer that I put. If the honourable member has any concern-I do not understand the details of his question-about the issues to which he referred he should raise them with the royal commission. I give him this undertaking: If he should find in respect of the matters which apparently concern him that the royal commissioner indicates that he is incapacitated by any weakness or absence of specific terms of reference that would enable a consideration of such matters, I ask him to approach me and if any action is necessary to enlarge the terms of reference I will consider it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. In view of the fact that in less than 200 years the European occupants of Australia have succeeded in destroying about two-thirds of our natural forests, including most of the natural habitats of koala bears, which are important to our tourist industry, will the Minister undertake to review the guidelines for the taxation deduction presently allowed for the clearing of natural forests which I believe provides an undesirable incentive for the continued destruction of our forests?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. He will be aware that the last Labor Government did act to deal with the taxation treatment of land clearing. There is an important question of not wanting to discourage the further development of agricultural land in this country, but at the same time not providing a taxation incentive for the indiscriminate and wanton destruction of important parts of the Australian bushland. I think they are important questions that have to be addressed. The honourable member quite rightly drew attention to the fact that the taxation system through the allowances for these kinds of expenditures does have an effect on the rate and extent of clearing on particular properties. As I indicated before, the last Labor Government did act to ensure that a balance was returned to the taxation impact of these sorts of actions. In the light of the honourable member's question, I would be happy to have a further look at the matter he raised to see whether further action is required to prevent the sorts of circumstances about which he is talking.

—My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, follows through the line of answers given earlier. When the Prime Minister spoke of 3 to 4 per cent, was he not contemplating the passing on of the June and September quarter consumer price index towards the end of the year? If the March quarter 2 .2 per cent were to be included, surely the 3 to 4 per cent would become 6 per cent?

—Well, one always has optimism in this life, so I will try again. I repeat to this House that it will be the view of the Government, put in the forum where it should be put in detail, and that is before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, that there should be in calendar 1983- that is distinct from financial 1983-84, so that there is no difficulty in understanding-a minimal wage increase which we say should be no more than of the order of 3 to 4 per cent. How that will be done will be a matter for decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There is no doubt what the position of this Government will be. It will put that position clearly and without equivocation. Whatever may be put by anyone else, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which submission by the ACTU or someone else may have the result of some increase in late 1983 or beyond that, is a matter for them. But I say again unequivocally, that the position of this Government to that Commission fully put will be that we will not be wanting an increase and we will be arguing against any increase which involves an increase in wages in 1983 beyond the order of 3 to 4 per cent. I have said this several times. I think everyone in the House, with the possible exception of the Leader of the Opposition, has understood it and, hopefully, he now will.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What is the Government' s attitude to the signing of the Lebanese-Israeli agreement and the rejection of it by Syria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As distinct from the obvious differences we have in the area of wages, I preface my answer to this question by again saying, as I did on 11 May when I answered a question in respect of the Lebanon, that I believe that what I say in respect of this question will receive general endorsement in this House. As I indicated on 11 May, the Government welcomes the conclusion of the agreement between Israel and Lebanon. I would on this occasion, as I did then, pay very considerable tribute to the United States Secretary of State, George Shultz, for the work he has done to achieve that agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that it is an encouraging sign that President Gemayel has been able to achieve a very considerable degree, apparently, of unity in the quite disparate forces which operate in his country to enable the achievement of the signing of that agreement between Israel and the Lebanon. Although we all recognise that the agreement falls far short of a representation of a full normalisation of relations between Lebanon and Israel, I think all members of the House would recognise that it represents a significant advance which we all welcome.

With respect to that part of the honourable member's question which referred to Syria, I think everyone-whatever may be his emphasis of view in regard to the tragic position in the Middle East-would recognise that Syria has legitimate interests in this area. On behalf of the Government I express regret that at this stage the Government of Syria seems set, according at least to its public statements, to undermine the agreement that has been reached between the Lebanon and Israel. The Australian Government hopes that the Government of Syria will think again about this issue and see virtue for itself and for all countries in the area in trying to move towards a position in which there could be a removal of all forces from the Lebanon; that is, Israeli forces, Syrian forces and armed Palestine Liberation Organisation forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in absolute agreement.

—I am very glad to see the signs of agreement from my friends in the Opposition that this view represents a bipartisan position. It is a sine qua non for the achieving of what we all want to see very particularly; that is, the establishment of conditions in the Lebanon that will enable the tragic people there to resume a normal and peaceful life.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. Is the Australian National Line threatening union bans against three non-conference lines operating on the Australia-Asia route unless those three lines reduce their cargo share and limit their discounting of conference rates? Does this action by the Australian National Line represent Government policy?

—The matter to which the honourable member referred concerns, I think, discussions which have taken place between non-conference line operators and some of the conference line members and other discussions which have taken place with representatives of the sea-going unions and non-conference line operators. The discussions between the non-conference line operators, the lines the honourable member mentioned, and the conference members are normal commercial negotiations; they are not matters for involvement of or participation by this Government. They are not new discussions. From time to time conference line operators and non-conference line operators meet to discuss terms of trade and trade matters. The Government has no direct part in the discussions. In fact, I advised the Chairman of the Australian National Line prior to a meeting a couple of weeks ago that we expected that it would be conducting normal commercial negotiations on these matters in accord with normal commercial principles.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I draw his attention to articles in the Canberra Times on 13 May and the Melbourne Sun on 16 May 1983 which relate to the need for emergency accommodation for homeless young people. Is the Government aware of the crisis facing homeless youth in this country where, of the 12,300 requests for emergency shelter in the past 12 months, no more than 5,000 requests were able to be met? When funding for the Youth Accommodation Services Scheme expires in 43 days time on 30 June, what does the Government intend to do about it?

—I thank the honourable member for Diamond Valley for drawing the attention of the House to one of the tragic by-products of the 750,000 unemployed we were bequeathed by the previous Government. Difficult economic and social questions face the Government in relation to these matters because we have, at the same time, to provide resources both for creating jobs and for welfare support for the army of unemployed. Many of those 750,000 unemployed were in full time employment but suddenly, often after a lifetime in work, found themselves out of employment. Many of the unemployed, of course, are young people coming straight from school. The cost of unemployment to this country is not only the cost of the vast unemployment benefit bill but also the cost of crime, vandalism, drugs and broken families. All that is part of the cost this Government faces in this matter. This applies particularly to many young people who have come into the community with a sense of hopelessness because it cannot provide what they might have expected. As I have said, we have a difficult task. We have to provide resources for job creation and balance that against welfare provision to meet the needs of the unemployed. The national evaluation report on the Youth Services Scheme was presented to the Government in April. The report evaluated the Youth Services Scheme, which is the prime scheme for providing emergency accommodation and other crisis assistance for homeless youth. The national evaluation report was received by the Government in April. We immediately forwarded it to all States for comment. It will be tabled in this Parliament tomorrow. We will be taking immediate action, in the light of that evaluation, to provide the most effective resources for supporting the people to whom the honourable member for Diamond Valley has drawn our attention.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Support. In the administration of his Department, has the Minister implemented the Government's decision of 2 May in relation to ministerial dealings with lobbyist Mr David Combe? When was the Minister informed of the real reasons for that decision and, in particular, the involvement of, and the Government's reliance on, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation? Does the Minister support the Government's reliance on ASIO in making that decision? Does he support the Government's decision?
—I missed the first part of the honourable member's question.
—Will the honourable member for North Sydney repeat the first part of his question?

—I will keep going, Mr Speaker, until the Minister tells me that I have reached the part of the question that he heard. In the administration of his Department, has the Minister implemented the Government's decision of 2 May in relation to ministerial dealings with lobbyist Mr David Combe? Does the Minister want me to keep going or has he got the rest of the question?

—In answer to the honourable member's question, it is my understanding that that decision has been implemented. I will certainly check with my Department to ensure that there are no inconsistencies. But my understanding is that the decision has been implemented.
—Will you advise us?
—I will.
—What about the rest of the question? Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister appears to have heard only the first part of the question.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister can answer a question to the degree he wishes. He has done so and has resumed his seat.
—Can the Minister for Aviation advise what progress has been made on proposed arrangements for the introduction of regular air services by Royal Brunei Airlines between Brunei and Darwin?

—The honourable member has raised this question with me on a couple of occasions, as have indeed the Northern Territory authorities. I am pleased to be able to advise that the Australian Government has approved the establishment of a Royal Brunei Airlines scheduled service between Brunei and Darwin. The service will operate under arrangements agreed with the United Kingdom Government, which has responsibility for air services to Brunei as that country has not yet reached full independence. I am advised that these arrangements are well advanced and that they will be formally agreed to in the very near future. I understand that Royal Brunei Airlines is proposing to begin operations about mid -year using a Boeing 737 aircraft. Royal Brunei Airlines will, of course, need to satisfy the normal operational requirements and standards for scheduled international air services to Australia. I hope that the necessary technical details of that can be finalised quickly. Royal Brunei Airlines will join Qantas Airways Ltd and Garuda Indonesian Airways in operating international services to Darwin and will assist the development of international travel and tourism to and from the Northern Territory.

—Does the Treasurer agree with his colleague, the Deputy Prime Minister, that so far as the ownership of our mineral resources is concerned Australia is being taken to the cleaners by the Japanese? If so, as the Minister responsible for foreign investment policy, what does he propose to do about this state of affairs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For many years in this country there has been concern about the general level of foreign investment and ownership of Australian resources. Indeed, the whole impetus for the development of a foreign investment policy gives permanent recognition to that fact. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to the fact that in some industries, particularly the coal industry, there is a significant level of foreign ownership. That is true. When the last figures were published I think it was about 62 per cent, given the fact that foreign investment participation figures were not published regularly by the former Government.
—Japanese?

—In some mines, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects, Japanese investment is quite high but across the industry generally it is quite modest. In terms of foreign investment what has to be viewed is the overall benefit to Australia, whether it would have developed without foreign investment at the pace at which it has developed and whether the economic benefits are sufficient to compensate for the loss of control of Australian resources. On balance it is the view of the Government that foreign investment has accelerated our development as a nation, including development in the mineral industry, and that there is no reason why properly and appropriately structured foreign investment proposals cannot be accepted by Australia for the future ongoing development of industry.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true, of course, that the resources industry is going through a very difficult time with the downturn in world markets. That is reflected in prices and returns and the industry is languishing. But I think, overall, the contribution by foreign investment is significant. It is also true to say that there has been a degree of bipartisanship between the former Government and this Government in foreign investment policy which has been conducive to the best interests of Australia, especially through the mineral industry.

That does not detract from the point my colleague made about the very high level of foreign investment. Australia embarked upon doing something about that high level of foreign investment many years ago, in contrast to, say, Canada, which overnight decided to do something about the alarming level of foreign investment and dislocated its investment policies and foreign investment in that country. That has not happened here. There are benefits to be gained from foreign investment. Appropriate structuring between local and foreign investment is, I believe, still appropriate. Those remarks are entirely consistent with the views put by the Deputy Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Science and Technology whether he is aware that a technological directorate is in the process of being established by the new State Government in Western Australia. Does he believe that such State- based projects should be integrated as part of a national technological directorate to ensure that Australia's technological development occurs in a consistent way? Finally, is the Minister considering the introduction of tax incentives for investment in high technology industries along the lines employed by the film industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could just answer yes, yes, yes, but I think the House would feel cheated. I am aware of what is being done about the Western Australian technological directorate and it is, to coin a phrase, an example of co- operative federalism to get the States in the act. If we are to develop high technology awareness in Australia, we cannot do it by centralising it. We must do it on a co-operative basis. I am glad to say that State governments of Australia-and not just Labor ones-are doing a good job in this area. The Western Australian Government should be commended, and particularly the Deputy Premier, the Honourable Mal Bryce, who has taken a very keen interest in it. I shall be discussing the matter in Perth on 9 and 10 June, when we have a meeting of all the Commonwealth and State industry Ministers and technology Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: As to tax incentives, the final determination of that will be for the Government. A variety of procedures is being examined. I hope to be able to make a comprehensive recommendation to the Government about the Espie report-' Developing High Technology Enterprises in Australia'-the Australian Scientific Industry Association report, the Australian Science and Technology Council report and a number of other options. I hope that we shall be able to say something very early on in the spring session. Last night Sir Frank Espie and his Committee met members of the Cabinet. The Minister for Finance, the Minister for Industry and Commerce and I spent a very productive evening discussing the Espie report.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the 1981-82 annual report of the Legal Aid Commission of the Australian Capital Territory.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs 1981-82 annual report. The report also covers those matters on which a report is required pursuant to section 12 of the Immigration (Education) Act 1971.

—For the information of honourable members, I present Volume 4 of the Studies of Tertiary Student Finances- Evaluation of Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme: An Investigation and Review of Policy on Student Financial Assistance in Australia.

—For the information of honourable members, I present the Recombinant DNA Monitoring Committee report for the year ended October 1982. This has nothing whatever to do with the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.
—I am well aware of what DNA is.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMERCIAL TELEVISION TRANSLATOR STATIONS, FOSTER, VICTORIA

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present a report by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on its inquiry into commercial television translator stations at Foster, Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Deputy Prime Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—The Deputy Prime Minister may proceed.

—As is well known, in the Press and media in recent days a view has been expressed that I had suddenly announced a change of Government policy in respect of our initiatives in Kampuchea. I want to place on record statements that have been made in this House, and I thank the Opposition Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) for giving me leave to tender a number of statements that have been made. They are very short, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member is tabling them, is he?
—Yes.
—Make sure that Bill Hayden sees them.
—He is not here at present.
—Tomorrow.

—Yes. Anyway-if I may continue without the honourable member's help-I am anxious to say that, as is known, I explained yesterday that I had met Son Sann of the Khmer People's Liberation Front, and following that meeting I made a statement in Bathurst that he agreed that some initiative could well be taken by Australia; and Mr Hayden is going to Hanoi in the near future. I explained that this was not a new concept, and that I had discused it over a period, and in fact I had discused it not only with Japan but also with the Association of South East Asian Nations, Vietnam and others. Perhaps I may explain that I would be about the only Minister or ex-Minister in this House who has ever visited Hanoi.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I may also correct another point. In 1980 I was party spokesman for foreign affairs in this House and I visited the refugee camps in Thailand and Kampuchea. I also spoke to all the ASEAN foreign ministers and to the Vietnamese Foreign Minister. There was never any opposition to the suggestion that there be withdrawal of all armed forces from Kampuchea and that there would need to be some United Nations peacekeeping or supervisory force to allow free elections. Mr Thach, the Foreign Minister of Vietnam, confirmed that he would be prepared to withdraw from Kampuchea provided that Pol Pot was disarmed. The following is a Hansard extract of one of a number of statements I made in the House of Representatives that year. Mr Speaker, I seek leave to incoporate the statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
28 August 1980

I refer honourable gentlemen to the statement made by Khieu Samphan, who was the President of the Pol Pot regime. As recently as March this year, he expressed his warmest thanks to the Government and the people of Australia for helping to mobilise opinion in respect of Kampuchea. I have been inside the refugee camps of Kampuchea. The people there certainly do not like the Vietnamese. But their No. 1 enemy is Pol Pot. Where is the guarantee that, if the Vietnamese forces leave Kampuchea, somebody else will save the remnants of the Kampuchean people from Pol Pot? Is it not a fact that in the absence of any preventative force Pol Pot will again swarm over the remnants of his people?

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1981, still as the party spokesman for foreign affairs, I visited Japan. On 9 July that year I spoke to the Japanese Foreign Minister, Mr Sonoda, and suggested that there could be an Australian initiative along the lines that I have mentioned. He encouraged such an initiative. He, of course, was then about to attend the International Conference on Kampuchea which was to be held in New York in the following week. It is a matter of record that during 1981 the Japanese Foreign Minister, Mr Sonoda, had canvassed the possibility of an international peacekeeping exercise in Cambodia. This can be confirmed from the Japanese Foreign Affairs Department. Shortly before my meeting with the Japanese Foreign Minister, I had held a meeting with the Austrian Foreign Minister, Mr Pahr, in the course of which he was fully supportive of an Australian initiative along the lines that I have mentioned. Shortly after that meeting, Mr Pahr left for New York to chair the International Conference on Kampuchea, to which I have referred. It is a matter of record that the outcome of that Conference was a declaration by the international community which called for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Kampuchea under the supervision and verification of the United Nations Peacekeeping (Observer) Group. The following is the relevant section of that report. I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
REPORT OF THE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON KAMPUCHEA
New York 1981

(a) An agreement on cease-fire by all parties to the conflict in Kampuchea and withdrawal of all foreign forces from Kampuchea in the shortest time possible under the supervision and verification of a United Nations peace-keeping force/ observer group.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is also a matter of record that the declaration was supported by all the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations and by Japan.
