PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the House of the Government's decisions concerning Australia's immigration policy and the size and composition of the 1983-84 immigration program.

SPEECH.PARA: Preamble
The Government has reaffirmed the nine principles underlying migration policy. In summary these are:
1. The Australian Government alone decides who can enter Australia.
2. Migrants must provide some benefit to Australia, although this will not always be a major consideration in the case of refugees and family members.
3. The migrant intake should not jeopardise social cohesiveness and harmony in the Australian community.
4. Immigration policy and selection is non-discriminatory.
5. Applicants are considered as individuals or individual family units, not as community groups.
6. Suitability standards for migrants reflect Australian law and social customs .
7. Migrants must intend to settle permanently.
8. Settlement in closed enclaves is not encouraged.
9. Migrants should integrate into Australia's multicultural society but are given the opportunity to preserve and disseminate their ethnic heritage.
Overview

The question of immigration intake is always potentially controversial, especially during times of economic recession. It has been argued that immigration can be stimulatory at any time as new arrivals create extra demand for goods and services, particularly in the construction industry, Conversely, it can be argued that to take large numbers during severe economic recession, when there are few jobs available, simply adds to unemployment and creates extra strain on budgetary outlays. The Labor Government's policy will be to steer a middle course, rejecting demands for a massive reduction in intake and at the same time preventing major increases until the Government's economic policies stimulate recovery.

For 1982-83, the original estimate of between 115,000 and 120,000 has already been revised downwards to between 90,000 and 95,000. The migration program for 1983-84 will be held to a ceiling of between 80,000 and 90,000 visaed migrants, with no growth proposed for the triennium unless economic conditions improve sufficiently. Within this ceiling our strong commitment is to the reunion of close family members of Australian citizens and permanent residents, and to refugees.
Family Migration

In 1983-84 I expect the approval of between 51,000 and 57,000 migrants in the family migration category. Family migration categories A and B; that is mainly spouses, minor children, parents and fiances, are expected to be between 26,000 and 29,000 and sub-category C, which we will retain; that is, brothers and sisters and non-dependent children, between 25,000 and 28,000. The former Government had introduced a points assessment system under which brothers, sisters and non-dependent children of intending sponsors are assessed before allowing sponsorship and which is used when making final assessment at overseas posts.

The Government intends to restructure the points system to eliminate its more discriminatory features. Points for English language and occupational demand have been dropped for family selection purposes, but points will still be allocated for arranged employment. The separate Occupations in Demand category will be retained. I will return to this later. Other minor adjustments to the points system will remove to some extent an inbuilt bias in favour of highly skilled English speaking and financially well off migrants. One of the more telling points made by the ethnic communities has been that under the former Government some people were more entitled to family reunion than others.

I will ensure that the category C intake does not exceed 28,000 for 1983-84 by controlling visa issue. I am sure that the new points system will be more acceptable to the ethnic communities of Australia than allowing the former Government's unfair bias to continue without moderation. The Government will keep the points system under review.
Refugees

The Government has reaffirmed its commitment to a refugee policy based on humanitarian objectives. In 1982-83, from an assisted intake of 16,000, 12,200 are expected from Indo-China, 3,500 from Eastern Europe, only 100 from Central and South America and 200 from other regions. The special humanitarian intake will number 1,050 for this financial year.

The Government proposes a refugee and special humanitarian program ceiling of 20,000 for 1983-84 to be administered within an agreed budgetary limit. Further, there will be a greater diversification of refugee sources. It is unacceptable for instance that only 100 out of 17,000 in 1982-83 should be from Central and South America, when there are already 300,000 refugees in Central America alone. Persons from totalitarian regimes in that part of the world are not receiving adequate representation in Australia's humanitarian programs. To achieve this diversification the Government will maintain flexibility. Within an overall ceiling of 20,000 refugees we are planning for 16,000 assisted passage places with a refugee and special humanitarian component of approximately 15,000 and 1, 000 respectively. Of the 15,000 assisted refugee passages, and whilst retaining flexibility, we are considering the very approximate intake of 10,000 Indo- Chinese, recognising the continuing reduction in the number of boat refugees; 2, 500 East Europeans, recognising the continuing reduction in the number of Poles seeking resettlement outside Europe; and 2,500 from other areas, including Central and South America and the Middle East.

We are planning to have 2,000 unfunded refugee places in contingency reserve and 2,000-including the program of 1,000 assisted passages-for the special humanitarian program. This latter category is a special category with relaxed intake criteria for people in human rights difficulties, who may have family links with Australia but are outside the scope of assisted refugee entry. Unlike the refugee program the special humanitarian program-this is important-can in extenuating circumstances be applied to people in their own country. It was originally established by the former Government partly to help those with human rights difficulties in the Middle East, and greater emphasis will also be given to its use in Central and South America and other areas from now on. I stress that these figures should be regarded as ceilings but remain most definitely flexible. The Government made an election commitment to place greater emphasis on seeking political solutions to refugee situations. This aim will be vigorously pursued.
Labour Shortage and Business Migration

The Government believes that less reliance should be placed on the migration program as a source of skilled workers. Much more emphasis is needed on training and retraining of Australians to fill skilled vacancies. Skilled migration will continue to be needed to fill gaps for some time but the Government will develop a manpower planning approach to ensure that economic recovery is not held back by skilled labour shortages, and conversely, that immigration does not become an alternative to Australian training and retraining programs, particularly for adults.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and I will look for alternatives to the recruitment of skilled workers overseas, based on manpower planning. This approach will emphasise the training and retraining of Australians. In the meantime, the Government will continue to accept some skilled migrants in the occupations in demand sub-category. The employer nomination scheme will also be continued while the new mechanism is being developed. Under this scheme, employers who have a satisfactory training record and who have carefully tested the Australian labour market may nominate overseas workers to fill specific vacancies. One year ago it was estimated that in 1982- 83 about 25,000 people would migrate in the occupations in demand sub-category. The figure will now be closer to 16,000 to 19,000, and for next year it will be about 3,000 to 6,000 people including dependants. There will probably be only about 2,000 to 2,500 workers. In other words, only about 2,500 workers will migrate in this category next year. This will be a maximum.

The business migration program will be continued. I believe that this program has considerable potential to create employment and boost economic growth which far exceeds the small size of the program. Some 2,000 business migrants and their families are expected in 1983-84. However, previous policy made it easy for people with nothing more than money to be accepted in this category. I have removed a concession that allowed to migrate wealthy people who did not intend to set up a business. I have placed a lower limit of $250,000 capital on the business migration category and have given priority to businesses with employment or technology improving potential.
Other Measures

These policies complement measures that I have already taken which have been designed to lessen the impact of immigration on unemployment while still maintaining a commitment to family reunion and assisting refugees. I have already removed a concession granted by the previous Government to wealthy people between the ages of 55 and 65 which allowed them to migrate provided they had significant amounts of income or capital. These persons were a potential addition to the labour market and it could be inferred that it was possible to ' buy' permanent residence in Australia. I have already prevented working holiday makers in Australia remaining permanently on the grounds of their qualifications and/or employment prospects alone.

I have closed a loophole under which large numbers of temporary residents could remain, on the ground that they were irreplaceable to their employers. Only those applicants who can establish beyond doubt that they are irreplaceable will be allowed to change status from temporary resident to permanent resident in this category. That is the way it ought to be. I have already supported the intensified efforts of my Department to locate and remove from Australia prohibited immigrants and others found working without authority. It is estimated that there are 50,000 to 60,000 illegal immigrants in Australia and that 10,000 to 15,000 per annum become illegal immigrants. That is very serious in a situation of high unemployment, when they have no right to stay here.
Independent and Special Eligibility Migration
The Government will make no change to the independent and special eligibility categories. Numbers in these categories will be small-under 1,000 in each category.
Trans-Tasman Migration

The Government has reviewed the entry of New Zealand citizens under the trans- Tasman travel arrangements, which allow for the free flow of people between the two countries. This review was prompted by concern about unemployment. In coming to a decision the Government considered both the costs and benefits of the present arrangement. Suspension of the arrangements would have serious implications for trade, foreign policy and other national interests and would be inconsistent with the recently signed Closer Economic Relations Agreement. Accordingly, the Government will allow for the continued visa-free entry of New Zealanders under the trans-Tasman travel arrangement, which recognises the special relationship which exists between the two countries. The requirement for New Zealand citizens to produce a passport before entering Australia will also remain. However, entry under this arrangement will be closely monitored to ensure that it remains in Australia's interests.
General

In determining the size and composition of the immigration program for 1983-84 and the immigration policy needed to achieve this objective, the Government has addressed the twin dilemmas of short term economic difficulties versus long term benefits of migration and benefits of family migration versus possible unemployment and settlement difficulties. The decisions the Government has taken are balanced decisions. The Government recognises that there are costs, both financial and social, but there are also benefits. It is these benefits which the Government has sought to maximise at an acceptable cost. In determining the size and composition of the migration program the Government is backing Australia's future. We have tried to balance the various competing and conflicting interests. We recognise that the economy is in recession but we also recognise that we have humanitarian obligations to people who are far worse off than we are. Concentration on short term problems should not obscure the longer term, when we and our children will reap the benefits of a larger, more culturally diversified Australia.

I believe that the changes I have outlined, which will take effect from tomorrow, will make Australia's immigration policy fairer, and more consistent with Australia's future needs. I trust it will be well received by the migrant communities. I will be sending to honourable members an information paper setting out in more detail the changes I have outlined. I present the following paper:
Australia's Immigration Policy and Program-Ministerial Statement, 18 May 1983.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am honoured to speak in the Parliament for the first time in my capacity as shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. As I informed the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) when I rang him to congratulate him on his appointment to the Ministry and to advise him that I was to be his shadow, the Opposition will endeavour to maintain a bipartisan approach to the question of Australia's migration policy. I indicated to my friend the Minister that from time to time we would find ourselves in disagreement and that on those occasions I would, to quote the words of Sir James Killen, 'endeavour to engage in robust debate on the subject but without personal acrimony or bitterness'. It is in that spirit that I respond on behalf of the Opposition to the statement of the Minister. As will be clear from my remarks, there are matters within the statement with which the Opposition concurs; there are matters with which we strongly disagree. Speaking generally, I believe it can be fairly said, on the basis of the statement just given to the House by the Minister, that Australia now has a more authoritarian, a more rigid , a more discriminatory and certainly an anti-English-speaking migration policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement contains a major shift which the Opposition views with grave concern. There are two particular matters to which I wish to advert before referring to it in detail. Firstly, notwithstanding the Government's assertion that it has sought a middle course, it is putting migration into reverse gear. Secondly, the Government has already indicated, through the statements of the Minister, that it will take away one of the essential elements of a proper migration policy for this country; that is, the exercise of ministerial discretion in appropriate cases. Indeed, it is fair to say that on statements made to date, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has effectively abolished the exercising of his personal ministerial discretion.

I now turn to the preamble and indicate that the Opposition applauds paragraphs 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9-that is not a bad go at consensus. But we do express reservations about paragraph 2 in which the Australian Labor Party, through the Minister, now proclaims that migrants must-I emphasise the word 'must'-provide some benefit to Australia, although this will not always be a major consideration in the case of refugees and family members. With the greatest of respect, we contend that the use of the word 'must' instead of the word 'may' confirms the proposition which I have just put, that is, we are now moving into a very authoritarian and rigid migration regime. I will continue to argue in this Parliament-I do have a personal regard for the Minister-that the Minister has acted very wrongly in the initial stages of his ministry in cancelling out the question of ministerial discretion. I will say more on that later.

The Government in its statement says that it will steer a middle course as to the size of the intake. The Minister was kind enough to point out to me that, in fact, there is a reduction; that the intake is down some 5,000. This goes directly against one of the most significant submissions put to the National Economic Summit Conference by the Housing Industry Association of Australia whose spokesman, Mr Kirkby-Jones, in a most impressive address to the Economic Summit, said that there were very strong arguments for increasing the migrant intake on the basis that it would provide a major stimulus to the economy and, he went on to say, to the building industry in particular. Mr Deputy Speaker, as a former Minister for Housing, you will know, as Mr Kirkby-Jones pointed out to the Economic Summit, that migrants have a higher per capita rate of home ownership in this country than Australian born citizens. In other words, members of the migrant community, on a per capita basis, have been able to get into housing and have been more committed to getting their own homes. Mr Kirkby-Jones in his submission, which was one of the best submissions put to the Economic Summit, made this point. I have to say that whilst the Minister indicated later in his statement that he will be co-ordinating with other Ministers-of that I certainly approve-this policy seems to cut across some announcements that may come out tomorrow in relation to our housing industry. If what I read in the newspaper is correct, migrant home owners will be the hardest hit. I am puzzled as to why, before the statement which is to come out tomorrow night, we have found effectively that the submission of the Housing Industry Association has been rejected.

The Opposition does not quarrel with the statement of the Minister on family migration except on a humanitarian basis. I ask the Minister to take into account that in some families cousins can be closer than brothers and sisters. It is precisely that case where I believe there should be ministerial discretion . But in relation to the categories, and I accept this as a continuum, the Minister is effectively saying that brothers and sisters, non-dependent children -I am referring to sub-category 'C'-and no more will be accepted. I can assure the Minister there would be many cases in which, if he were only prepared to exercise his ministerial discretion, he would recognise that some cousins-I do not say all cousins-may be in a closer relationship, one to the other, than siblings.

The Opposition objects strongly to the decision by the Government to drop points for English language in relation to family selection purposes. I have to ask the Minister: What is he on about? Why is he writing into his policy in the first several weeks of his term of office a deliberate anti-English speaking bias against prospective migrants? That is what he is doing. Let there be no misunderstanding about it. I am not surprised that the Minister has taken this approach but I am surprised that it has been done in such a blatant manner. What does he have against the proposition that one of the bases of the establishment of a multicultural society and the assimilation into our community of Australian citizens is enhanced if those citizens have a capacity to converse in the English language? I could understand the Minister saying that he has altered the weight, but he has dropped it. It will be accepted in the migrant communities that in so doing this Government is saying that it regards that in the past there has been a bias in favour of English speaking migrants and the Government now intends to turn that around. It has said as much as that because on page 3 of its statement it alleges an inbuilt bias in favour of highly skilled English speaking migrants. The Government now intends to go against English speaking migrants and those who are highly skilled.

The Minister went on to say-I believe it was a most unfortunate and inaccurate statement-that one of the more telling points made by ethnic communities has been that under the former Government some people were more entitled to family reunion than others. I reject that. If honourable members opposite check the files of their predecessors they will find that no member of the Parliament made more representations to Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs than did the honourable member for Denison. It is a matter of record. Our Government can be proud of the fact that it had fine Ministers in the portfolio of immigration and ethnic affairs during its term in office. I deeply regret that the new Minister cannot start his ministerial career without making a totally baseless and inaccurate allegation which is totally rejected by the Opposition. Again, the Minister used unfortunate and inflammatory words when he referred to the former Government's unfair bias. I suggest that the former Government had one of the best and most accepted immigration policies. Its policy was recognised on a bipartisan base as a proper policy. The present Government now intends to go out into the market place to defame it unfairly.

Australia has a reputation unparalleled in receipt of refugees from all parts of the world. As a former Minister reminded me today, unfortunately Australia cannot take them all. He said-I hope the present Minister will accept this-that one of the most important criteria is that we take as many as we can but we recognise the manner in which they are taken must be conditioned on the basis of Australia's interests, our humanitarian concern and the individuals concerned. I have to say-the Minister has made it very clear to this Parliament-that in the Minister's period of office fewer refugees will be accepted from Asia and more from Central and South America.

Let me talk about Central and South America for a moment. The Opposition and I are extremely concerned that there are some 300,000 refugees in Central and South America. We are all considerably concerned about the continuing war and the guerrilla tactics. The problems in that continent are enormous. Effectively, the Minister has said that he will see to it that instead of only 100 people coming from Central and South America in 1982-83 the figure will be considerably increased. Depending on how many are accepted from the Middle East that figure could go from 100 to 2,000. It may involve people who are genuine refugees; it may also involve people who are not. The Opposition and I are extremely conscious of the situation in South America. I ask the Minister to exercise the greatest care in allowing people into this country from that continent. The Minister is dealing with something which has the potential to prove extremely serious, if not explosive, within our Australian community.

The Opposition supports the move by the Minister contained in page 4 of the statement in relation to the special category concerning the relaxed intake criteria for people in human rights difficulties who may have family links with Australia but who are outside the scope of assisted refugee entry. I think the Minister will know that the former Government was moving somewhere along the line towards achieving that result. I congratulate the Minister in this respect because I, as he will find out from his files, have been involved in such cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is right.
—I repeat: Where the decision is good it will be approved. But I caution the Minister in relation to South America. I do not need to say much more in relation to that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition strongly opposes what the Government will be doing in relation to the cut-back in the number of people who will be permitted to migrate under the occupations in demand sub-category. The Government will be cutting back the number of migrants in this very special category by over 70 per cent. If that is not putting migration into reverse gear, I do not know what is. We do not agree with the decision of the Minister in respect of the business migration category. The Minister blandly and unfairly talks about wealthy people who migrate. He is to place a lower limit of $250,000 on the capital of people in the business migration category and is to give priority to business with employment or technology improving potential. The Minister has already taken away, abandoned and destroyed forever his capacity to approve ministerially a change of status in relation to those people who are in Australia as working holidaymakers. Let me quote what he has now done. He prevents working holidaymakers in Australia remaining permanently on the grounds of their qualifications and/or employment prospects. In other words, an employer might have been looking, in some cases for years, to employ a young man or woman with certain qualifications. I have one case before the Minister at the moment involving a Rhodes Scholar from the United States of America. Under this Minister people on working holidays will have to return to their home countries and formally lodge an application for permanent resident status. Last year 1,000 out of 15,000 applications were approved.

This Minister has started off on the basis that he will not exercise his ministerial discretion. As we have seen from Press reports today, when he does exercise his ministerial discretion he is subject to improper pressure from others who force him to reverse his decision. The plain fact of the matter is that the Minister is the Minister. He is being paid to administer his Department . There are cases in which he can exercise a discretion. There are cases in which he can bring a bit of justice and humanity into what would otherwise be a rigid and authoritarian regime. The Minister has the right to issue visas, nobody else. Never again let it be seen that the Minister is rolled by his Cabinet colleagues after having issued visas because that is not a proper exercise of ministerial discretion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that we are discussing Australia's migrant intake and the matters raised by the honourable member are not relevant to the subject before the Chair.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The Minister knows what I am talking about. Not only will he not exercise his discretion in many areas but also he is prepared to have his ministerial discretion interfered with by improper pressures. We are disappointed that we have a Minister who has started on that basis.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on the Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Bill 1983 was interrupted because of Question Time I had made some short observations. I said that the Opposition had no objection to the passage of the Bill. I made some positive comments about our willingness to agree to legislation of this sort without confrontation and dispute. The Bill's purpose is to wind up the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission and to terminate the Christmas Island Agreement with New Zealand. The Bill contains a schedule which sets out an agreement between Australia and New Zealand dated 22 November 1982. I guess that because the purpose of this Bill is to put that agreement into effect, honourable members would appreciate why one so readily agrees to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement was negotiated between representatives of the previous Government and the New Zealand Government to implement a program announced earlier by one of the Ministers of the previous Government. Honourable members no doubt will be aware that on 8 March 1981 the former Minister for Administrative Services, my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman), announced decisions on the recommendation of the Commission of Inquiry into the Viability of the Christmas Island Phosphate Industry. The main developments that he outlined on that occasion were the disbandment of the British Phosphate Commissioners and the establishment of a wholly Commonwealth Government-owned mining company as managing agents for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. The company that was set up to undertake that task on behalf of the Commonwealth of Australia was the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd. He also announced at that time that the disbandment of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission would proceed ultimately and also the relinquishment by New Zealand of its right to extract phosphate and its related rights under the Christmas Island Agreement operating at that time. The Minister then stated that New Zealand would retain its right to purchase up to half of the total Island phosphate output at the same price as it is sold to Australia. He went on to say that Australian manufacturers would assume responsibility for purchasing phosphate rock and for shipping it to Australia. The agreement also provided that stockpiles of phosphate rock at Australian and New Zealand manufacturers' plant on 30 June 1981 would become the property of the respective governments.

The legislation before the House will give effect to the objectives announced at that time. It will bring to an end the role of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission, as was then foreshadowed, and the Commission's assets on the Island will pass to the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd. The Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd will then be able to mine in its own right rather than as a managing agent as has been the case. As has been previously announced, it is to do so on a non-profit basis but it is expected to operate commercially.

The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) stated in his second reading speech that agreement in relation to the future operations of the island, phosphate marketing and related questions, is close to being reached. I assume that the agreement about which the Minister spoke will deal with the distribution of the assets of the Commission and arrangements for future purchases of phosphate. Unlike previous agreements which have required legislative intervention to give them force and effect, this will not, as I see it, be the case now with the anticipated exchange of notes that the Minister indicated would be the way in which the agreement presently being negotiated would be put into effect.

The Minister has stated that the agreement will begin to operate when this legislation is proclaimed. In effect, the proclamation of this legislation seems to be dependent upon such an agreement being negotiated and concluded. Whilst the Bill is said to be dependent upon a concluded agreement without any statement of intention, I would certainly ask the Minister, who is not here at this time, to give an assurance to the House that the agreement will be reported to the Parliament because I think honourable members should be aware of the agreement as this Bill is conditional upon it.

I join the Minister in extending thanks to the previous Commissioners. He mentioned, in particular, Mr Morris Timbs, A.O., a man known to many of us, Mr W . D. M. Bremner, C.M.G. and Mr W. G. Marston, O.B.E. On behalf of the previous Government and Opposition I extend thanks to them for their work in relation to the Commission. When the previous Christmas Island Amendment Bill was before the House in 1981, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) raised a number of questions. Honourable members would be aware that the honourable member is now the Minister for Primary Industry. When he spoke on that occasion, he raised a number of questions relating to phosphate stockpiles, their size and value, and the cost of phosphate to manufacturers and thus to farmers and graziers. He noted at that time that some increase in price under the new arrangements was inevitable. He also made some observations about the effects of the bounty on the continued use of phosphate. I would like to quote for the benefit of honourable members the speech the Minister for Primary Industry made at that time, because it may be interesting to him in his present capacity. In Hansard, of 10 June 1981, at page 3451, he is quoted as saying:

The Government has gone along with the recommendation to pay a bounty but it has not kept up its value. It could easily keep up the value if it wanted to, if it was fair dinkum, by paying a percentage or by indexing the bounty to take inflation into account.

I am sure that the honourable member for Werriwa, the Minister for Primary Industry, will well recall that quote. Implicit in it is a commitment to an increase in bounty and a suggested way in which that might be taken into account . It will be interesting to see what approach the honourable member takes on this issue now that he is in Government. The honourable member for Werriwa also noted Australian Labor Party concern about the Christmas Island work force. He did not do other than draw attention to the problem and at that time he did not suggest any solutions. I simply note that neither has the new Minister for Territories and Local Government mentioned this matter in his speech, but it is one on which I would like the Minister to keep the Parliament informed. I would also like him to take a continuing interest in it and to ensure that the question of the future of the labour force is addressed. I note that it has been a matter of considerable concern to the Australian Labor Party from time to time and I think its record in government needs to be noted as much as its expressions of concern when it was not in government.

Finally, the honourable member for Werriwa at that time mentioned a number of environmental matters, including the Abbott's booby bird. It has been a matter of some notoriety from time to time that whenever Christmas Island is referred to, questions of this sort are raised. Whilst the Minister for Territories and Local Government is not in the House, I would certainly like to note what I know of his personal concern about environmental matters. From time to time I have admired his very considerable interest in matters of heritage at home. The Minister has been known to express a view about Parramatta Park which is of interest to people in the western suburbs of Sydney. I was somewhat surprised, therefore, knowing his interest in environmental and heritage matters and the like, that his personal concern did not run into his address on this occasion and that he made no observations. I simply note that the Minister in his second reading speech has not referred to those issues, although they were covered in considerable detail in the 1981-82 report of September, of the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd. Honourable members who might be interested in questions relating to the environment and what was being done, if they would like some further information on it, should refer to that report.

The former Minister for Administrative Services, in a statement made on 1 November, said that provision was being made to protect the Abbott's booby bird and other Christmas Island fauna and flora. In the Senate Estimates Committee concerned with the Department of Territories and Local Government, questions were also addressed on this matter. Some indication was given as to the nature of the program of monitoring the booby bird and its habitat and the work that was about to be undertaken by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service . In view of the interest that has been expressed in these matters from time to time, I would like the Minister, when addressing questions relating to Christmas Island in future, to give attention also to these very important matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Bill, it is my understanding-I was not a member of parliament at the time, having only been elected on 5 March-that this is unfinished business from the previous Government. As the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has rightly pointed out, the legislation is not controversial. I am glad that he used the word consensus; it is a word that is gathering momentum with every day. It is also my further understanding that the Bill is basically just a machinery motion to facilitate the transition of the management of the Christmas Island phosphate deposits from one management structure to another.

SPEECH.PARA: In my short speech I will consider a few points-the purpose of the Bill, some of its effects, or more correctly, non-effects-and I will finally stress the importance of its passage. The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the winding up of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission and the termination of the 1958 Christmas Island Agreement with New Zealand. The Bill enables the agreement to come into operation on a date to be specified by proclamation. Following much consultation between the governments of Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom, the previous Government, on 5 March 1981, announced a series of wide ranging decisions concerning the future of the phosphate industry . The changes will occur in two stages. Firstly, the Christmas Island Agreement 1958 and the enabling legislation were amended in June 1981 to enable the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission to employ managing agents other than the British Phosphate Commissioners. In July 1981 the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd, a company wholly owned and controlled by the Australian Government, took over the mining operations as the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission's managing agent. Secondly, with the enactment of this Bill, the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission can be wound up and the Phospate Mining Co . of Christmas Island can continue to mine in its own right. These changes should occur around 30 June this year.

Consistent with this intent, I believe, a memorandum of understanding has been reached with New Zealand. The three points basically covered in that agreement concern the distribution of assets between Australia and New Zealand; the agreement by New Zealand to share unforeseen liabilities with Australia; and the agreement by both countries to accept a guaranteed tonnage in the 1983-84 financial year to assist the transition. This agreement has been reached notwithstanding the fact that both countries have significant stockpiles of phosphate. I turn now to some of the effects or possible non-effects of the Bill . There is no change in the price of the product. No unemployment will be created by the transition. The previous administration was handled by three part time commissioners. There will be no effect on the workings of the Island. There are about 10 to 15 years left in which to mine A grade phosphate. That period can be lengthened if the A grade deposits are mixed with B and C grade deposits. There will be no additional cost but, conversely, several million dollars in revenue will be raised as a result of this Bill. In closing my remarks, I stress the importance of not delaying the Bill. For that reason I will not fully take up the time allotted to me. If this legislation is not passed by 30 June there is a possibility that auditing and company structure problems may ensue. My colleague, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), will outline a few points about the company structure and the industrial relations aspects of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) referred to the nature of the work force at Christmas Island. The Government, in a spirit of bipartisanship, has to look at the work force when it is considering the management of the Island. Obviously, there have been considerable tensions in the past. What one might call almost a feudal mentality prevailed on the Island because management tended to have a large say in what went on and the work force was consulted very little. I emphasise that at this point in the transition phase we as a government will be concerned to ensure that there are appropriate consultative processes. Under the current arrangements on Christmas Island the three Christmas Island Phosphate Commission members are joined by a representative of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and a representative of the farmers. This is to ensure that there is effective participation at the management level on Christmas Island.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise to the House that the Union of Christmas Island Workers needs to have a far greater involvement in the operation of Christmas Island than has been characteristic in the past. We must recognise also that to ensure the effective management of Christmas Island we must have consultative processes. It is pleasing to note that during the last visit by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) to Christmas Island he encouraged the establishment of weekly meetings between management and the work force on the Island. It is to be hoped that that pattern will continue so that an effective relationship can be established between workers and management. One of the concerns we had, particularly in Western Australia because we are geographically closer to the region, was that tensions had developed in the past. The Union of Christmas Island Workers had a number of grievances that it wished to raise. It is to be hoped that the future arrangements will be more effective.

I take up a point raised by the honourable member for Dundas. I think it is important that this Parliament should be involved and should know what is going on in relation to Christmas Island. I do not think it is sufficient for us to say simply that we should go ahead with this transition arrangement. We should also make sure that we follow up this legislation so that we as a parliament, and therefore the people of Australia, know what is going on at Christmas Island . I am particularly concerned to ensure that we have an opportunity to be briefed on the industrial relations aspects.

The honourable member for Dundas raised an important point about the conservation aspect. Perhaps we should consider referring that matter to a committee of the Parliament. It might be appropriate to do so at some future date. During this transition period we as a government-the Government recognises that it is carrying forward some measures of the previous Government-should facilitate these things. In winding up, I want to emphasis two points: First, we ought to ensure that under the current arrangements industrial relations activities are improved and, that a more enlightened climate is established for industrial relations. Second, we should reflect on the fact that the conservation aspects which have been pointed to are also important.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1983 which is before the House. I will indicate towards the end of my speech one reservation that the Opposition has. I point out that had the Opposition still been in government I would have proposed legislation of this nature in this session. The Industrial Relations Bureau is the first matter I wish to raise in relation to the Bill. Essentially, the Bill restores the pre-Industrial Relations Bureau position and does not diminish the rights of individuals under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, including those which were inserted by the Bill which set up the Industrial Relations Bureau. In that regard, it is noteworthy that at paragraph 4.9 in the first annual report, of 1977-78, the Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau said:

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from changes to procedures to meet internal administrative arrangements, the policies of the Bureau in relation to securing the observance of the Act, regulations and awards closely followed those of the former Arbitration Inspectorate.

Presumably the transition will be equally smooth in reverse. No doubt the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will assure the House of that. It is worth dwelling for a moment on what are the rights of individuals under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I do so by reference to the last annual report of the Industrial Relations Bureau which, at pages 19 to 21, lists those rights under the present legislation. It is worth reminding the House of what the Director of the IRB said in the report. When referring to those who have most frequently been drawn to the attention of the IRB, he said:

S.5 prohibits employers from dismissing or disadvantaging employees because of particular activities associated with their organisation membership, their award rights or their refusal to participate in industrial action.
S.132A prohibits discriminatory action by an organisation against an independent contractor who does no belong to the organisation.
S.140 specifies the requirements to be met by the rules of organisations including the requirement that they shall not impose on members conditions that are oppresssive, unreasonable or unjust.
S. 141 provides procedures whereby members can act to secure the performance and observance of the rules of their organizations.
S. 144 prescribes the entitlement of employers, or persons desiring to become employees, to be admitted and remain as members of employee organizations.

S. 144A provides procedures whereby an individual with a conscientious belief against membership of any organization may obtain a certificate from the Industrial Registrar and be protected from victimisation.

There are two or three more sections of particular relevance. Section 145 prescribes procedures for members of organisations to resign their membership. Section 159 entitles members of organisations to apply for an inquiry by the Federal Court into alleged election irregularities. Section 188 prohibits victimisation by organisations of employees who refuse to participate in industrial action. Those sections, which are summarised very compendiously and accurately in the Director's last annual report, indicate the range of matters handled by the Industrial Relations Bureau. These will, of course, continue to be handled by the Arbitration Inspectorate. I hope that the Minister will give the House an assurance that the people on whom rights are conferred by those sections will be able to resort to the Inspectorate just as they were to the Bureau.

I will come back to one matter but wish to refer the Minister especially to page 21 of the same annual report, where reference is made to some of the cases which come before the Bureau in relation to those sections. I refer in particular to the case of an owner-driver who alleged:

. . . that an organization threatened that industrial action would be taken against a newspaper company, with which he had a contract, because he would not join it. His contract with the newspaper was subsequently terminated.

I will be suggesting that the protection afforded by the Act is itself inadequate. It is another area to which I would have given attention by proposing a Bill to this session of the Parliament. I will come back to that, but I ask the Minister to assure the House that people will be as free as hitherto to exercise their rights under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, although in practice they will now approach the Inspectorate instead of the Bureau, that the Inspectorate will try to assist these individuals, as did the Bureau. I am sure it will but I ask the Minister to assure us of that. I also seek his assurance that the phrase in the second reading speech, that this Bill '. . . will not give the Inspectorate the intrusive role that the Bureau had in respect of the internal affairs of registered organizations' does not mean that an individual's entitlement to redress under the Act as it now stands will be reduced in any way. I am sure that is the case, but I believe a lot of people who have placed great reliance upon the provisions of the Act would draw comfort from the Minister's assurance.

I also ask the Minister to seek to resolve with the National Labour Consultative Council the weaknesses in the law which were identified by the Bureau in its annual reports. There are several but I refer in particular to the plight of independent contractors. Shortly before losing office I had discussions with the Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau regarding the inadequacies of section 132A. The Bureau drew attention to that in its last report, presented to the Parliament in October 1982. At page 25 thereof it observed:

One hundred and fifty-four complaints and enquiries were dealt with by the Bureau in 1981-82 from persons who either claimed that they were not employees but were being coerced into joining an employee organization or who wished to know the protection afforded to them by the Act. Section 132A purports to provide a measure of protection, against discriminatory action by employee organizations, for independent contractors who meet the definition of, and, who do not belong to an employee organization. The difficulties and limitations associated with its application were commented on in some detail in the Bureau's 1979-80 Annual Report.

Although the Bureau continued to be able to secure relief for some complainants , especially sub-contractors who could demonstrate that they were themselves employers of labour, the Bureau's experience in 1981-82 was of continuing difficulty in obtaining a resolution of problems brought to it that satisfied complainants and enquirers.
The Director of the Bureau made a similar observation in the previous year at page 17 of his annual report:

From information tendered and enquiries made it is apparent to the Bureau that the incidence of dissatisfaction amongst 'independent contractors' or 'self employed' persons concerning unions enrolment overtures is very much higher than is reflected in the number of individuals who have approached the Bureau directly.

I have spent some time on this because, as the Minister knows very well from his own experience, certain sections of the Australian community are particularly anti-trade union. If one traces the reason for that, one finds that they have had adverse experience in what they regard as the abuse of union power. One substantial section is made up of those who believe that they are self-employed and ought not to be induced to belong to a trade union. There are also others, such as the victims of the recent shearers' strike. Each of those cases represent the ugly face of trade unionism and it makes it hard for the Minister, and for me as well as a supporter of trade unions, to explain the situation away and, above all, to explain why there is inadequate protection. I draw it to the Minister's attention, not to embarrass him but to point to a genuine grievance which the law, as it now stands, does not adequately meet-one which I was determined to try to correct. I therefore ask him to look at that matter with a view to trying to correct the situation during the Budget session.

By way of giving the Minister further information I refer him to the 1979-80 annual report, in which the Bureau reported at length on the technical aspects of administering Section 132A. I refer him to pages seven to 10 of that report and ask him to raise the matter with the NLCC as soon as possible and to come back to the Parliament in the Budget session with legislative changes designed to overcome the weaknesses exposed by the Bureau. It might be useful if I were to cite to the House a case described at page 8. It serves to provide an example of the problem. The relevant passage states:

X operated his own business which involved the buying of bricks on a demolition site, cleaning them and either re-selling them on site or removing them for subsequent sale. He employed several persons on a casual basis to assist in the cleaning work. X was not himself engaged in the demolition of the building (that was performed by another firm-Y).

X was approached by an organizer of a building industry union and told that unless he, X, joined the union, the site would be closed down. X refused and the employees of Y walked off. X then paid the union subscription by cheque but subsequently stopped payment of it. The site was again 'closed' until X paid for himself and one of his employees in cash. X sought the Bureau's advice.

Investigations by the Bureau raised considerable doubts as to X's status in relation to the definition of 'eligible person'. Even if X had been an employee, it was not apparent that, having regard to the particular nature of his activities, X would have been eligible to join any organization including that represented by the organizer who had approached him. Other difficulties of an evidentiary nature were also revealed.
Before these technical questions could be resolved, X indicated that he did not wish to pursue the matter and declined to assist the Bureau any further in its inquiries.

The fact that someone in X's position did decline to pursue the matter further indicates the degree of frustration which people, who are entitled to use sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which are designed for their protection, will feel when they in future will have to approach the Industrial Arbitration Inspectorate. I believe that there is in the law a major deficiency which needs to be corrected. I do not criticise the Minister for not correcting it in this Bill, but I believe that he ought to do so in the next parliamentary session.
I also draw the Minister's attention to a most important observation at page 14 of the 1978-79 annual report of the Bureau:

The essential problem, however, is the reluctance of the trade union movement to accept the principle involved, i.e. that independent contractors or self employed persons should not be forced to join employee organisations. It is the Bureau's view that the resolution of the problem in the long term can only be achieved by dialogue with the union movement and employers.
Initiatives to establish such dialogue have been taken and are meeting with some success.

It would seem from the 1981-82 report, a report of three years later, that those negotiations and dialogues did not meet with enough success. Were I the Minister still, I would have raised this matter with both the National Labour Consultative Council and the departmental review of industrial relations which I had instigated. Now that the new Minister has handed that review to an NLCC committee, I ask him to request that committee to give high priority to this matter and to recommend legislation prior to the completion of the examination of the whole Act. I do not believe that the public interest should be imperilled in this regard by waiting for the completion of a review which might well take another 18 months or two years. The problem is urgent.

All independent contractors, owner-drivers and other self-employed persons are entitled to have their position clarified and protected from the coercion to which they are so often exposed by union organisers to join unions even when they are not strictly eligible to do so. I must say again that one of the deficiencies in the law-as I recall, it is section 141-is that it really just does not give protection to a member of the public who is complaining about coercion to join a union, even where the union rules are such that a person such as him would not be eligble to be involved. I think that that section confers a right only on someone who is already a member of the union, not on a member of the public who is under coercion but who is not a member of the union. That is clearly a deficiency which ought to be tidied up at the same time.

As it stands, section 132 (1) (a) is quite unsatisfactory. It is pleasing to see, from paragraph 3.25 of the 1981-82 report, that the Bureau successfully pursued the Transport Workers Union to the Federal Court. However, not all individuals are as courageous as the one involved in that case, and few are prepared to stay the complicated legal obstacle course which is now facing them. Owner-drivers suffer serious intimidation, discrimination and disadvantage. For example, I have had people come to me, as have other honourable members, including the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), complaining that because they are owner-drivers, they go along to a warehouse to pick up some goods which they are to deliver under a contract of service, and the storeman and packers give priority to the loading of vehicles which are driven by Transport Workers Union members. Even if there were a more expeditious and effective remedy than is now provided under the law, there would still be that lack of co-operation and discrimination against them by another union, which has talked from time to time of amalgamation with the Transport Workers Union. I think that the Minister, in supervising the other aspect of this Bill, the amalgamation provisions, really ought to look at the rights of people who are not, strictly speaking, employees or employers and recognise that ancilliary protection has to be there for them against intimidation and bludgeoning of that character. It simply means that small business people cannot operate their businesses successfully if they are discriminated against, even for 24 hours, in terms of the loading and unloading of goods in that kind of case.

So, as a matter of public interest, the Act ought to be amended in order to ensure that first, independent contractors are given protection from action taken against them by anyone on the basis that they are not members of a registered organisation. In theory, this should apply to both unions and employer organisations but I doubt that employer organisations pursue them in this fashion, and so in practice it is likely to apply only to unions. Secondly, independent contractors who are not employees should be precluded from membership of employee organisations but be able to join employer organisations where the rules so provide; and, thirdly, independent contractors who are actually deemed eligible to join an employee organisation by virtue of section 132 (4) should have the same rights as other employees regarding conscientious objection to union membership under section 144A.

Again, this is one of the anomalies, like the other section to which I referred , which I think is section 141. Clearly, it is an oversight by the government of the day and the drafters but it is a matter that the Minister could pick up. Section 144A as it now stands, especially in conjunction with with section 132 ( 4), is deficient in its protection of conscientious objectors even if the rules cover their situation. Moreover, I believe that consideration should be given by the Minister and the NLCC to legislating for a special category of registered organisation for the independent contractors who are neither employers nor employees in a technical sense. Perhaps I should say in passing that as some of the self-employed people actually incorporate themselves as private companies, they can be said to be technically employees of their own companies. I recognise that that is one of the difficulties that government and legislative draftsmen have in remedying this situation; but there will need to be another of those tripartite conferences, which seem to be the order of the day for Ministers with this portfolio, to try to come to the best solution possible.

The Minister would be aware of the unsatisfactory nature of section 132, section 132A, section 144 and section 144A. The problem really begins with section 132. As section 132 (1) (a) of the Act presently stands, an organisation of employers is capable of making provision within its membership for persons who are independent contractors engaged under a contract for services. This class of person is not an employer and not an employee, and as section 132 (1) ( b) and (c) of the Act presently stands, an organisation of employees is capable of admitting to membership persons who describe themselves as independent contractors but who are, in fact, engaged under a contract of service. A person of this class is an employee.

Section 132 (4) of the Act enables employee organisations with branches in any or all of the States of New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia, whose rules make appropriate provision, to recruit to their membership persons deemed employees for the purposes of those respective State industrial codes. The entitlements can differ from State to State and, in some instances, would include persons entitled to join an employer organisation under section 132 (1) (a) or section 132 (2) of the Act. I make that point for the record for the Minister's guidance because I believe that he, as Chairman of the Federal-State Ministers for Labor Conference, is very well placed with four Labor governments and an extremely constructive Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in Queensland, to rectify that situation. It cannot be beyond the wit of those Ministers, who traditionally are non-party-political in the way in which they handle things, to resolve that situation. It is not a major issue in industrial relations, but it is a major irritant to the people affected by it.

The limited and restricted entitlement to membership of an employee organisation provided for by section 132 (4) is the cause of both confusion and pressure for further legislative change. It creates inconsistencies between the membership of the separate branches of organisations; it causes inconsistencies within branches of organisations; and in certain branches of an organisation it gives an entitlement to membership to a person who has an entitlement to be a member of an employer organisation under section 132 (1) (a) or 132 (2) of the Act. It also may be varied by widening or narrowing by amendment of State legislation which may or may not accord with the wishes of the Federal organisations concerned and may have effect without the consent of the registrar having being obtained and without interested organisations even having an opportunity to object. This is a highly technical area. I apologise to the House in one sense, for boring honourable members with that kind of detail. But we get rare enough debates here, and it seems to me that if we are looking at the abolition of a bureau designed to protect people, we should also look at ways in which the law is deficient and ways in which the new Arbitration Inspectorate can be given more authority to act to resolve these matters.

The independent contractor problem looms largely in the building and construction industries and in the transport industries with those who work on the tools or are owner-drivers. Essentially, the problem is one about industrial coverage. As the Act currently stands, independent contractors may, where the rules so provide, join an employer organisation. They cannot join an employee organisation except where there is a potential entitlement arising under section 132 (4) of the Act by virtue of any relevant State legislation and where there is an entitlement under the rules of the organisation. Irrespective of restrictive legislative prescriptions, most employee organisations will tend to ignore those prescriptions in respect of persons who work on the tools or who are owner-drivers, regardless of whether the contract is one for service. Some even ignore the fact that a person working on the tools or the owner-driver is an employer. I recall the Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau informing me that many employer organisations and employers openly aid and abet the employee organisations in this kind of behaviour. That again is a very unfortunate outcome if members of these registered organisations find a collective interest in excluding rights that one would have thought, as a matter of natural justice, ought to lie to a very small segment who are genuinely self- employed and neither employer or employee in the sense that the registered organisations' coverage normally admits.

Part of the problem is due to the nature of the industries and the growth in the number of independent contractors both of and for service. Another aspect of the problem is the difficulty of distinguishing between contracts of and for service and, like so many other matters in this complex area-it is complex in areas of both law and human behaviour-this problem is now firmly on the table of the Minister, not myself. I am sorry for his sake that it is so but, if he thinks that I can be of assistance to him, I would be very pleased to help. Let me assure him again that the matter is urgent and of great economic significance to the multitude of independent contractors throughout Australia. I say multitude because they are growing but they are still not of such significance that the registered organisations will suffer by not being able to get coverage of them.

I should mention one other matter in respect of individual rights. Amongst the sections of the Act to which I have referred is section 188, which in fact provides protection for people who have decided to work in accordance with the award and not abide by a union direction not to work. I would suggest strongly that in strikes such as the recent shearers strike the Minister satisfy himself that the Arbitration Inspectorate has the authority to give protection to those people.

In the last few minutes available to me I turn to the second portion of this Bill which concerns the amalgamation of unions. I wish to propose, and then briefly talk to, an amendment to the motion for the second reading. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government should adopt the unanimous view of the all-party Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation which recommended in October 1982 that in elections where the membership is consulted on mergers, at least 25 per cent of the membership of each union should be required to record a vote, and of those voting, at least two thirds should be required to vote in favour of the proposition or that an alternative could be for at least 25 per cent of the total membership of each union to vote in favour of amalgamation, provided that those voting in favour constitute a majority of the votes cast'.

The Opposition does not oppose the concept of facilitating legislation to make amalgamations between registered organisations easier but it brings this amendment before the House because it wishes to see the maximum feasible involvement of rank and file members of the organisations, whether they are employee or employer organisations. One of the criticisms that has been made for many years, and rightly so, is that under the current law it is extremely difficult to get 50 per cent of the enrolled membership actually voting. There are also deficiencies in respect of rolls and I commend the Minister for correcting those in this Bill.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions, in its evidence before the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation, drew attention to the fact that the report of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration and the report of the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry pointed up the multiplicity of unions and the need for reductions in the number of unions and the need for trying to find some community of interest in the amalgamations. The ACTU, at page 41 of its submission, also pointed out the difficulties that the present legislation placed in the way of people with a community of interest actually coming together. Therefore, the Opposition supports very strongly the easing of the current restrictions.

I must say, speaking personally, that it is legislation which is long overdue and I welcome it. I recall calling for legislation of this kind not only long before entering this Parliament but also in my maiden speech. I quote from page 41 of the submission of the ACTU. It states:

Other amalgamations, where a way around the s. 158N requirement was not available, simply have been prevented from taking place. The most recent example of an amalgamation being stymied by the present provisions of the Act is the proposed amalgamation between the Australian Textile Workers' Union and the Australian Boot Trade Employees Federation. Despite the fact that there is a clear 'community of interest' between the two unions and that over ninety per cent of those members who voted in the ballots conducted in each union supported the amalgamation, the amalgamation cannot proceed because the s. 158N requirement (that at least 50 per cent of the members must vote in the amalgamation ballots) was not met. The return rate of ballots from the members of the Textile Workers' Union was 34.7 per cent and the return rate in the Boot Trade Employees' Federation was 44.5 per cent.

This provision is important because of the mergers which are now in contemplation and I understand that the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia and the Australasian Society of Engineers face a similar situation. What was proposed ultimately by the Senate Select Committee in its report of October last year would not be an obstacle to the two major mergers that are currently prohibited by the existing legislation but which would be facilitated by this legislation. It would have the benefit of enabling more people to participate in the decision making.

I refer the Minister to clause xii of the summary of observations, conclusions and recommendations, paragraph 9, of the Senate Select Committee report. It is quite clear that the Committee believed that there should be greater rank and file participation. The Committee put forward two options to the Government and in this amendment the Opposition puts those two options forward for debate in this House. I should say that in most organisations, whether they are companies or registered organisations under this Act, there is usually a requirement for more than the simple majority for the dissolution of those organisations. I think, if my memory serves me correctly, that even the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union has a requirement that it can only be dissolved with a majority vote of two-thirds of its members. On that basis I would have thought that the spirit of the Senate committee report, an all party committee comprising an independent member and members of the Australian Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party, was appropriate and I commend this amendment to the House whilst still supporting the second reading of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill. The overall intent of the legislation is to improve industrial relations in this country after years of industrial mismanagement by the now Opposition. The legislation is to be commended for two aspects: Firstly, for abolishing the Industrial Relations Bureau, a mechanism introduced to attack the trade union movement and working people; and, secondly, for easing the restrictions on union amalgamations. This Government was elected on the promise that it would repair the serious industrial damage inflicted on the trade unions by the previous Government. The IRB legislation was one of the many pieces of vicious legislation introduced by the Fraser Government to restrict the rights of trade unions and trade unionists and to limit the opportunity for working people to better their lot in the bitter class strugle of industrial relations. The IRB reflected the general attitude of the government of the day. Indeed, had the previous Government been a football umpire, I would suggest that the score of the employers would have been 100 and that of the workers nil. According to that Government, the bosses were correct in every industrial dispute over the past seven and a half years.

SPEECH.PARA: That Government launched an attack on the unions and their membership through legislation, through the activities of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission at wage hearings, by its redirection of the Australian economy from the public to the private sector, by its substantial pay-as-you-earn tax increases, by its substantial decreases in taxation of the wealthy and the private privileged class and the use of public funds to bolster the private sector. It reinforced the attack on wage earners by introducing an arsenal of legislation aimed at decapitating the trade union movement. It backed this up by creating an atmosphere of fear and distrust, and by painting the trade union movement as the bogy of not only our industrial life but also of Australian society.

This lie finally lost its effectiveness in March this year. The Australian people saw through the layers of fabrication and recognised the rottenness and corruption of the perpetrators, that is, the spokespeople for business and that government that used the term 'militant trade unionism' to justify their attack on living standards. Incredibly, every social ill from unemployment to the economic crisis, to the Government's disastrous record of failure, was labelled the fault of the militant trade unions. The spokespeople for business and government attempted to make the word 'business' synonymous with everything good and decent in society and the word 'unions' with all that is bad.

The Liberal Government deliberately attempted to divide society, to turn worker against worker, to tell the most disadvantaged of the work force, of the unemployed and of welfare recipients that their problems were caused by their fellow workers in the unions. This divide and conquer tactic worked for just so long. It came from a government that talked of national unity while it plotted to undermine that unity for the interests of national and international capital. The tactics had two purposes: Firstly, to perpetuate government for the incompetents who administered the shambles; and, secondly, to divert attention from the real issues and from the real cause of the economic woes and personal misery, the capitalist system which the Opposition espouses as the salvation of society. We know that has proved to be wrong. Yet, as part of its tactic to create that myth, the Government introduced the arsenal of legislation, from the IRB to the use of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act to the draconian fines and penalties for normal industrial action. It is interesting to note that one of its activities, an attempt to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation, cost the taxpayers of this country nearly $2m. I am reminded that that was unsuccessful. People on the opposition side of this chamber wasted that $2m. I point out to the House that their spokesman was not interested enough in this legislation to be here when the debate commenced.

As we all know, the bosses have given the workers nothing over the years. It is senseless to suggest that workers will improve their lot without industrial struggle. Despite the Press barons' and conservative spokespeople's attempts to decry talks of class struggle as old-fashioned and Marxist, the facts remain that the class struggle exists. In Australia in a period when the bosses were backed by their party's Government and when that Government worked to create division and to slander hard-working militant union officials and union membership, those militant union officials and union members remained the strongest allies of the working class under attack. The IRB was part of that attack. Yet it is significant that none of the draconian, horrific legislation worked. That is the extraordinary part. The Government introduced the major plank of Fraser's platform and ideas and it did not even work. It gave the Government the opportunity to launch its dishonest attacks on worker organisations but did nothing to prevent workers continuing their struggles. Further, it did nothing to solve one industrial dispute.

The Labor Party and the labour movement attacked the IRB bitterly when it was introduced. I commend this Government for maintaining that opposition now that it is in government and for undertaking the removal of the IRB as the first major step in improving industrial relations in this country.

This legislation returns to the tried and proven system of an arbitration inspectorate. The inspectors will be responsible only to the Minister. State and Federal inspectors will have reciprocal powers as they ought to have to facilitate their role for the good of all. Under this legislation inspectors will have the power to obtain documents and information from the cause of most industrial disputes, the bosses. It will be within their power to intervene in the running of a company, to see that workers are being paid adequately and that conditions are proper and in accordance with the law.

The second aspect of the Bill repeals legislation designed to limit the power of the unions. In many cases desirable amalgamations which would increase the industrial power and muscle of working people have been retarded by legislation deliberately designed to ensure the amalgamations were frustrated. This again was a product of Fraserism. This legislation will not mean that every union or group of unions wishing to amalgamate will automatically do so. They will have to prove a community of interest under one of five headings. But if they can prove that community of interest then the procedures for amalgamation will be facilitated to the benefit of all members of all the unions involved in the amalgamation.

The legislation also attempts to overcome anomalies in the rolls of those eligible to vote overcoming aspects of the present system which allows non- members of the affected unions to vote. I draw the attention of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to the need to monitor the voting system very closely and to conduct ballots in a manner ensuring improper practices cannot occur. Recent experiences in some unions have disclosed unscrupulous disruption, lies, rorting and cheating by the previous Government's neo-fascist supporter, the National Civic Council. If honourable members want proof of that I suggest they will find that proof in the New South Wales courts. There is plenty of proof of involvement by this group-the National Civic Council -which propped up the previous Government. It interfered in trade union ballots. The sooner society wakes up to the role of that organisation the better we will all be.

As I said, I urge the Minister to ensure that these threatening, unscrupulous tactics are not able to be employed in amalgamation ballots.
