Another sensible aspect of the Bill is its simplification of the procedures when more than two organisations are involved in the ballot and one organisation opposes amalgamation while the others support it. Under the present legislation, the whole question is thrown back to a ballot. But in future, the organisations supporting amalgamation will be allowed to amalgamate on the result of the first ballot. I point out again that the spokesman for the Opposition was late for the commencement of this debate. A quorum had to be called to wake him up and get him into the House. I commend the Minister for introducing this legislation. It is a Labor Government initiative. It is encouraging, after years of legislation by our predecessors which attacked working people, to see the process being reversed by a government with genuine industrial relations at heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has introduced amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. There is no doubt that the Australian Labor Party has given plenty of notice of its intention in regard to these matters. I refer the House to statements made in the 1982 platform of the Australian Labor Party which clearly indicates the current Government's intention to move in the way that it has. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis ) in speaking to the National Economic Summit Conference also gave clear indications that the Government intended to move in certain areas to make amendments of the style that we see in the House today. In his speech to the Summit, the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The prices and incomes accord places considerable importance on supportive policies as well as those related directly to prices and incomes. The Government is well aware of their importance to the accord and in the limited time it has been in government has taken action to implement a number of them.

Thus in regard to industrial relations policies, we have already announced our intention to legislate in May to abolish the Industrial Relations Bureau and to greatly facilitate the amalgamation of trade unions. I am pleased to say that both these actions have been unequivocally endorsed by the employers represented on the National Labour Consultative Council as well as by the ACTU.

This is one promise that has been kept; this is not another retread exercise. In fact, the Government has kept these two promises because the Australian Labor Party is so close to the union movement-in fact, at senior levels it is controlled by the union movement-that it has no choice but to fulfil the commitments laid down in the platform. The Minister, in his speech to the Summit , was seeking support for the policies announced by the accord and the policies set out for the Summit.

In fact, one could say that by abolishing the Industrial Relations Bureau and making easier the amalgamation of unions, the Australian Labor Party is fulfilling part of an obligation it made to the union movement in order to gain its support for moderation in union activity and consensus in matters of wage claims so that the Government's policy that wage claims should not rise by more than 3 to 4 per cent for the rest of this year could be endorsed. Of course, that has been proved fallacious. The endorsement of that policy by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labor Party has been falsely based. In the Minister's speech to the Summit he said:
However, I ask them-
That is, the employers-
to bear in mind that the unions too are entitled to be irritated by a policy that imparts restraint on wage claims-yet they have agreed to do so.
They have not agreed to do so and that has been proved in the past day or two. The Minister then said:
The Government regards the maintenance of real wages as a key objective but recognises that in a period of economic crisis as now applies that this will be an objective over time.

Of course, that objective is now current. That objective is being pushed on with by the ACTU and constituent groups within the Australian union movement. From the beginning of the IRB in 1977, the Australian Labor Party has consistently opposed its provisions. Almost from its beginning, I would say, the employers have also opposed some aspects of the Industrial Relations Bureau. Of course, now in office, the Government has moved to legislate to take away the IRB and to improve the prospects of amalgamations of unions. In 1977 the then Government introduced the Industrial Relations Bureau to be the third arm of industrial relations, of conciliation, to assist aggrieved persons and to create an awareness of obligations under the law-of both employers and employees. To a large extent the IRB has been successful in those approaches.

The Industrial Relations Bureau was also to have powers to refer matters directly to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Those powers were never provided for it. It would have been beneficial to the Industrial Relations Bureau if it had had the strength that was originally proposed for it. But employees and employee organisations have seen the Industrial Relations Bureau as an opportunity for the law to be enforced in areas where they prefer the law not to be enforced. The spokesman for the Opposition, Mr Macphee, in fact enunciated some of those areas, particularly in the subcontracting area where the union movement, particularly the militant unions, did not want to see the enforcement of law as it stands in those areas to assist subcontractors. In fact employers saw the Industrial Relations Bureau as purely an inspectorate which was more tough, more solid, more exacting and more demanding than had been the inspectorate under the registrar of the former arrangements for conciliation and arbitration. They have consistently said that the Industrial Relations Bureau has not filled the purpose for which it was formed. They too have rejected the Industrial Relations Bureau as a proper avenue for effective industrial relations.

The Minister has moved to resolve these outstanding matters-this dissension and these difficulties-by abolishing the Industrial Relations Bureau. When the Minister returns to the chamber I would appreciate his being informed of my concern regarding outstanding matters for the Bureau. I understand that these are four current award matters outstanding, one to be filed and eight more which will be filed before the end of the financial year. I note that the Minister in his speech said that he will have discretion as to whether they will be concluded. I take it from that that he will select those which should be concluded.

Of particular concern in this process of winding up the Industrial Relations Bureau are the matters outstanding in regard to the legislative aspects of its work. There is one matter which involves an offence under section 5 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act concerning which action has been commenced against an employer. There is another matter under consideration concerning the Australian Public Service Association Fourth Division officers in Queensland on which the IRB, in order to move to assist aggrieved persons, has taken up the cause of the victimisation of a group of individuals who would not participate in industrial action. In both of these matters I hope that the Government will move forward and have them resolved before the IRB eventually disappears from the industrial relations scene. On the matter concerning the Australian Public Service Association, the coercion that can be placed on individuals-threats, intimidation and other work place practices-is something that all Australians deplore. It would be most satisfactory indeed if the Industrial Relations Bureau could bring this matter to a conclusion which is in favour of those that have been victimised and those whom it is seeking to assist in their aggrieved state.

The spokesman for the Opposition, Mr Macphee, has spent some time dealing with the problems that the abolition of the Industrial Relations Bureau will create. He mentioned in particular sections 140 and 141 and the problems of sections 132A, 132 (4) and 188. There is no doubt in my mind that the matters concerning private contractors and subcontractors, people who have their feet on the first rung of the business world as self-employed, need to be specially dealt with and protected. It seems that the prospect of large employers and large unions being able to trample over these people, sometimes by coercion, is disastrous for the well-being of many Australians.

The protection that is needed for individuals is clearly enunciated in the report of the Commissioner, Mr Justice Winneke, that he provided for both the Commonwealth and the Victorian governments entitled 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to inquire into activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation'. I wish to read some extracts from that report because they clearly indicate the activities of organisations such as the BLF and the way in which they can put pressure on and coerce individuals- small individuals, perhaps one or two men, part of a team, subcontractors, working in a way that they have chosen, seeking and wishing not to be interfered with by people such as Mr Norman Gallagher. At page 26 of the report, the Commissioner states:

Following his conviction in the Supreme Court of Victoria for refusing to answer questions, Gallagher was again required to attend before the Inquiry and give evidence. On this occasion, he challenged the validity of the requirement but at the same time asserted that even if he was compelled to attend he would refuse to co-operate. This attitude displays an arrogant contempt for the processes of the law, an attitude which the evidence given before the Inquiry reveals as being carried into the administration of the affairs of the Federation.
On page 28 the Commissioner also states:
. . . they exhaust the legal processes-
He is speaking of the BLF-

(and no doubt the people who participate in them) in pursuit of what they assert to be 'their rights'. When, at the end of the day, the processes have been of no assistance, they help themselves by direct action and in defiance of the very processes which they have been so keen to employ.

It is important to indicate the nature of the work place of sub-contractors, the pressures to which they are subjected and the sorts of difficulties that they have in being real individuals in a place of contest and conflict. At page 35 of the report the Commissioner said:

firstly the lengths to which employers within the building industry have been prepared to go for the purposes of accommodating Gallagher's personal interests and, secondly, the clear determination by Gallagher not to 'put his hand into his own pocket' in respect of any expenditure incurred, or to be incurred, in the construction of those houses.

To me that is a man who has ratted on his mates. He has no principles whatsoever in regard to the union movement, his colleagues or his associates. Those are the sorts of people that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Melbourne ( Mr Hand), supported. He left no doubt at all that in regard to the Industrial Relations Bureau and the assisting of aggrieved persons he had no time whatsoever for anyone but people such as Mr Norman Gallagher who, I repeat, did not 'put his hand into his own pocket in respect of any expenditure incurred, or to be incurred, in the construction of those houses'. They were his own homes.

That is the sort of climate in which many sub-contractors in the building industry have had to work. In 1980 I followed with interest the processes of an inquiry into the building industry in New South Wales. That inquiry was conducted by an eminent person, one well versed in the whole field of industrial relations-Mr Justice Burns. It was instigated by the Minister of the day under pressure from the Builders Labourers Federation, to examine the sub-contracting industry in that State. The eminent figure came to the conclusion that sub- contractors should not and could not belong to unions. It was a very firm finding and one that, despite the pressure that was being placed on it, the New South Wales Government had to observe. I quote from a statement made within the last few days regarding Mr Justice Alley's criticism of the pressures that are brought to bear on people within the building industry. The statement reads:
Mr Justice Alley strongly criticised the B.L.F.'s industrial record-
This is a case, considered within the last few days, which was concerned with the turmoil, strife, standover tactics and intimidation that had been created-
and the overall damage it had inflicted on the building industry.
The statement noted:
the Commission had been given information that more than 100 sites had been affected by 516 bans, including 285 on 34 Victorian sites in the seven months to March.

Mr Justice Alley went on to accuse the BLF of grossly abusing the right to strike, breaking award undertakings, ignoring the Commission's decisions and operating in conflict with the policy of economic recovery expressed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Federal Government. That is a clear indication of the sorts of people who can get involved in the industrial relations scene and who can, in fact, make it impossible for the sub-contractor to continue his business. One has only to consider the position of bricklayers, wall and floor tilers, landscapers-any sub-contractor, even earth moving sub- contractors with equipment worth perhaps $200,000-who are coerced and stood over until they join the union. It was only these processes that the IRB sought, by way of some aspect of its activity, to alleviate. I appeal to the Government and to the Minister to make sure that individuals who are aggrieved and who do suffer these difficulties have a proper outlet to vent their grievance and are allowed to enter the industrial relations field in their own right.

Another area of which I know the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) is well aware is that of the trucking industry. I refer to the techniques that are used by large freight forwarders, in combination with the Transport Workers Union of Australia, to coerce owner-drivers, forcing them to do indescribable things. Let me elucidate. A time limit is set for drivers travelling to and from Brisbane. Unless they comply with the time limit they get no more loads from the freight forwarder. It is, in fact, a licence encouraging people to kill themselves. The coercion about which I am talking is entered into by the Transport Workers Union and large freight forwarders. The fact that the strike at Razorback was pursued so strongly by sub-contractors and owner-drivers was on the basis that they did not wish to be coerced into belonging to the Transport Workers Union.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should follow the suggestion of the Opposition shadow spokesman in regard to this matter. I feel that there is need to look at section 88E of the Industrial Arbitration Act of New South Wales with a view to ensuring that States' rights are not carried to a stupid extreme, whereby they can override the wishes of the Federal Government. That, together with the Moore and Doyle decision, is the basis of much of the strife in the transport industry of Australia. It all commenced in New South Wales.

The effective encouragement of people to go into the work place, to make a commitment of their own resources by way of finance, their own time and the time of their families, to the extent that they provide services that are desired by all sections of the community, clearly indicates that they need support. They need to be properly accommodated. They need to be able to carry out their business without fear of intimidation, without fear of organisations-whether of employers or employees-ganging up in such a way that they cannot act as normal, free people.

I conclude by indicating that the Government should immediately respond to the recommendations put forward by the Opposition in relation to sub-contractors and self-employed individuals who are neither employees nor employers, as our industrial law sees them at this point. They need assistance; they need protection. Otherwise I believe that we will have a nation, not of people who seek to improve their way of life and that of their families, but rather of employees. If that is the objective of the Australian Labor Party it should say so clearly. If it is not it should move to amend the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Government in introducing this legislation and to oppose the amendment moved by the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee). The honourable member, in opening-I jotted down a couple of his remarks-said that he too would have introduced this Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill. It seems strange to hear such a statement from one who is now the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, when the Fraser Government had seven years in office and the opportunity to do something in that regard. It would take two hours to go through the finer details of the numerous occasions on which the Fraser Government deliberately created a situation of conflict in industrial relations rather than settle down to introduce legislation such as that which is before us today. It is odd to hear a statement such as that which was made at the beginning of the debate in the House today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill seeks, firstly, to abolish the Industrial Relations Bureau and re- establish the Arbitration Inspectorate and, secondly, to introduce a number of provisions to facilitate amalgamations between registered employer and employee organisations. The legislation has been the subject of plenty of discussion both within the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement. The previous Government had the opportunity to become involved in such discussions, but clearly took the line that there was no political gain in adjusting the industrial relations situation in Australia. The economy of the country would have been very much aided by a system of industrial relations based on community consultation and trust rather than the type of approach which the Fraser Government adopted.

I have before me the statement of accord between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I propose to read from it in order to give the Parliament some idea of the sort of negotiations that took place prior to the election, and the sort of negotiations that eventually led to the people of Australia deciding that they had had enough of confrontation and looked forward to having a government that would adopt a more conciliatory approach to running this country. In the industrial relations section of the accord, under the heading 'Specific measures', the following statement is made:

The Government will endeavour to create a better industrial relations climate by itself adopting and encouraging other employers to adopt a rational and less confrontationist approach to industrial relations. The Government will encourage the settlement of disputes between employers and unions by conciliation and without recourse to legislative or common law penal sanctions.

The Government will establish, in consultation with the ACTU and employers, an Inquiry into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and Regulations to conduct a total review of federal industrial relations legislation to improve that legislation. Within the review, priority considerations should be given to reform the laws relating to the internal affairs of unions to ensure the continued effect of efficient and democratic operation of unions.

The Government will support the establishment of rights of employees, through their unions, to be notified and consulted by employers about the proposed introduction of technological change. The Government will also support the establishment of fair redundancy protection for workers including a requirement on employers to consult with unions in redundancy situations.
The restrictive laws inhibiting the amalgamation of unions should be reformed. The Industrial Relations Bureau should be abolished and an independent Arbitration Inspectorate re-established.

The Government will, in co-operation with the unions representing its own employees, take steps to bring about a better industrial relations environment in the public sector. As a first step, an ALP Government will confer with the Union Movement on a program for action guided by ALP and ACTU policies on Australian Government employment matters.
The Government will consult fully with employers and the trade union movement through the ACTU, before the introduction of new industrial legislation.

It is with great pleasure that I have the opportunity of seeing the Government very early in its term of office introduce legislation to restrict the laws inhibiting the amalgamation of unions, abolish the Industrial Relations Bureau and set up an independent Arbitration Inspectorate.

The Bill proposes to repeal Part VIA of the Act which establishes the IRB and the position of Director of the IRB. It is proposed through clauses 5, 6, 10, 11 , 25 and 27 to remove references to the IRB throughout the Act. The Bill will restore the pre-IRB position by doing away with the power of the IRB to take a wide range of actions in respect of the conduct and affairs of registered organisations. The Act did not previously make such provisions in respect of the Arbitration Inspectorate. There are, however, two areas in which the role of the IRB is to be continued by the Industrial Registrar. Firstly, the Registrar is to take the place of the IRB in being able to apply to the Federal Court under section 132B for a declaration as to the eligibility of a person convicted of a prescribed offence to seek or hold office in an organisation. The organisation or a member will continue to be able to apply. Secondly, the Registrar is to be responsible under Part VIIIAA of the Act for investigating deficiencies in the financial accounts of organisations. The Registrar will also now have sole responsibility under section 160 for investigating alleged irregularities in elections of officers under the Act. Previously this was shared with the IRB. The proposed Arbitration Inspectorate will resume its responsibility for safety inspections under section 54. This was transferred to the IRB when it was established.

In the time that I have available to me, I would like to move to the section in respect of which the Government has moved its amendment, namely, that dealing with amalgamations, and speak about how the Bill will facilitate amalgamations. The Bill proposes, in accordance with National Labour Consultative Council recommendations, three basic changes to the Act to facilitate amalgamations. The first is to introduce new provisions to lower the voting requirements of the Act where an amalgamation would be in the public interest and in the industrial interest of the organisations concerned-that is, 'community of interest' amalgamations. Secondly, in proposed amalgamations of more than two organisations, where the overall amalgamation does not succeed, amalgamation of some of the organisations will be able to proceed if their members vote in favour without the amalgamation process having to be recommenced as at present. Thirdly, rolls of voters in amalgamation ballots will be considerably more up to date by comprising persons eligible under the rules of the organisations concerned to vote in an amalgamation ballot or, if the rules do not provide for such eligibility, those persons eligible to vote under the rules in rank and file ballots for elections to office. The amendments proposed in this section will apply to all amalgamations, whether under the existing provisions or the proposed 'community of interest' amalgamation provisions.

One could ask why it is necessary to facilitate amalgamations. This is something that the previous Government would not face up to. It is widely recognised that there are too many unions in Australia. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures in December 1981 there were 324 trade unions in Australia at that time. Presently there are 150 federally registered trade unions. The problems associated with the large number of trade unions and the need for some nationalisation have been commented on in a number of inquiries initiated by the Commonwealth Government. Those inquiries have included the report of the Committee to Advise on Policies for Development of Manufacturing Industry in 1975, the report of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1977 and the report of the Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia in 1980. Some of the problems that have been identified include demarcation disputes between unions with overlapping eligibility for membership rules; inefficient use of the finite resources available to trade unions from what are often small and fragmented memberhips; and problems in negotiations between employers and trade unions as to the terms and conditions of employment arising from the multiplicity of trade unions within not only an industry but also often a particular enterprise.

I now refer to the sort of approach that the previous Government took in this regard. We remember not so long ago when a former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, who no longer holds his seat in this House, introduced legislation based on what the then Government called company-based unions. Rather than taking a common-sense approach and reducing the number of unions in this country, for some strange reason in the seven years we had to put up with it, the previous Government sought to increase the number of unions. I quote from an editorial which appeared in the Melbourne Age on Thursday 18 February 1982. The editorial, which was headed 'Viner shoots at wrong target', stated:

The new legislation he has foreshadowed envisages company-based unions and industry-based unions springing up in Australia to compete with the traditional craft unions for the workers' allegiance. Workers in a factory would be free to choose whichever one they-or, at least, the majority of them-preferred, or even none at all. The problems of how such a radical departure could be introduced peacefully in Australia are brushed aside by Mr Viner as of no consequence.
That is typical of the approach that the then Government took at that time. The editorial continued:
The question of whether such a jumble of unions would work better than the craft-based system he answers with platitudes about freedom of choice.
Simple idealism is a delightful thing in many people-but not in Ministers for Industrial Relations.

It is indeed a change to see that the Liberal Party which is now in opposition seems to be taking a more conciliatory stance through its spokesman at the table , the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee). The honourable member was always known for his more conciliatory approach. However, he did not appear to have much say in the previous Government. I conclude my remarks by raising with the honourable member the apparent position of the Opposition at present. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review which was mentioned yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during Question Time. Quoting that article he said:
At a joint meeting of the Liberal and National parties in Canberra yesterday the issue-A centralised or decentralised approach to wage fixation-
Another industrialised matter-

was sent to an all-party committee after no senior front bencher could lay claim to there being an Opposition wages policy. The scene is now set for months of manoeuvring between the decentralists, led by Shadow Treasurer Mr Howard, and the centralists, headed by the Employment and Industrial Relations spokesman, Mr Ian Macphee.

I look forward to the coming months to see whether the Opposition will learn a little bit. It may be able to develop a coherent policy. It had the opportunity to introduce such a policy when in government. I am happy to stand here today and support the government for its policy. I look forward to voting for the Bill if a vote is taken later today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) stated in his second reading speech on the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill that his Government's policy is to improve industrial relations. Presumably, the preference-no, let me say the deference- paid to Mr Dolan as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions at the recent National Economic Summit Conference was in pursuance of such a policy. The Australian people were assured that the ACTU was participating with the Government in achieving a new, never before experienced, consensus. From this consensus would flow wage restraint as well as an agreement upon a central wage fixing system.

SPEECH.PARA: Well, recent events have put paid to that concept of consensus, a concept around which the Government has woven both its economic and industrial relations policies. I refer to comments made by Mr Dolan this morning on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM. A question was put to Mr Dolan after a discussion had taken place regarding the ACTU's 2.2 per cent wage increase claim . The transcript of that interview states:
Q. If the Commission then knocks back such a claim, will you accept it?
A. Well, they will put themselves out of business as far as I see it. There will be just no role for the Arbitration Commission because unions will seek to achieve that increase.
A further question was asked of Mr Dolan as follows:
Q. Is this the industrial free for all you are talking about?
A. That is right.

It is clear that this Government's industrial policy has broken down completely. It has no substance and, more importantly, it has no future. To use a colloquialism, Mr Dolan's public statements have thrown out the window the industrial policy which the Minister, in his second reading speech, said was directed towards achieving consensus and better industrial relations in the interests of all Australians. What threatening language and bully-boy tactics Mr Dolan employs! Yet he expects the Australian people to accept his stance. Does this Government expect us to accept that there is consensus in industrial relations? As of today, the Government does not have an industrial relations policy. Moreover, the central wage fixing authority, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, has been deemed irrelevant by the ACTU. Just what authority does the Commission have now that Mr Dolan has said that he will ignore the Commission if it does not grant the requested increase? He has displayed a cynical contempt for the Commission.

He is not the only union official to display a cynical contempt for the rule of law. It has also been displayed by the recent actions of the Australian Workers Union during the shearers' strike. What action did the Government take to enforce the Commission's decision with regard to the use of wide combs? It took no action. As a result, the AWU made a mockery of the rule of law. In the meantime, a great number of people suffered. What action will the Government take in respect of this latest attack upon the authority of the Commission, and therefore upon the rule of the law? I very much suspect that no action will be taken, given this Government's record in office to date. The Government will take no action because its commitment in the field of industrial relations is not to the people of Australia but to a handful of anti-democratic extremist union officials. This Government's only concern is to pay off the extremists within the trade union leadership and those of the socialist left which is the dominant faction within the Australian Labor Party. As such, the Government's so -called policies serve only a narrow sectional interest within the trade union movement.

I do not play the card game known as poker but I understand that an element of bluff is an important skill in it. I am most tempted to learn the rules of that game as I believe this Government is the most easily bluffed collection of gentlemen one could hope to encounter around a card table. I would particularly like to play the game of bluff with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. At the National Economic Summit Conference the Government was completely and utterly bluffed. It was bluffed into thinking that the ACTU would accept wage restraint. Moreover, it was bluffed into assuming that the ACTU would respect the authority of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The bluff is now at an end. The so-called consensus with the ACTU is also at an end.

There is nothing remarkable about this or about the fact that the so-called consensus collapsed so quickly. What is remarkable is that the Government actually believed it could succeed. What naivety! What an amateurish approach! I want to know how the Government could possibly have expected an industrial policy arising out of a week of back slapping and self-serving statements at the Economic Summit to last. How could such a policy have possibly had any substance or relevance to the great majority of Australians? I also want to know when this Government will acknowledge that its duty is to all Australians and not just to narrow sectional interests. Finally, I want to know where the Government goes from here. What does it do now that the ACTU has made a complete fool of not only the Minister but also the Cabinet at large? Will it take steps to contain the extravagant wage claims of the ACTU or to protect the authority of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Alternatively, are we to see a return to the chaos presided over by the then Honourable Clyde Cameron when the term ' rule of law' became an irrelevancy and a term of mockery during the previous Labor Government when 4.3 million strike days every year were lost to the economy? The previous Government managed to lower that to approximately 2.5 million working days lost a year. Yet this Government-as with the previous Labor Government-pretends to have a special relationship with the unions. I again say that that special relationship is one-sided; it is a matter of bluff. This Government is repeating the same mistakes of the previous Labor Government in accepting at face value every statement put out by the extremist union officials .

Notwithstanding the ineptitude of the Government to date, all is not lost, as the Bill before the House this afternoon contains, in essence, the policy of the previous Government. The previous Government gave the Industrial Relations Bureau three basic tasks. The first was that of day to day award inspection. The second was the provision of information to both individuals and organisations on their rights and obligations under industrial legislation. Its third duty was to secure the observance of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and Regulations. Whilst this Bill abolished the Bureau and replaces it with an Arbitration Inspectorate, I am pleased to note that the same basic tasks will be carried out . The Minister ought to state plainly and honestly that, by and large, this Government is adopting the previous Government's policy in this area of industrial relations. Instead, the Minister said in his second reading speech:
The Fraser Government believed that industrial relations could be controlled by legislative prescriptions, without proper consideration of the reality of industrial relations in Australia.

Such a statement has an extremely hollow and ridiculous ring to it, given the events of the past 36 hours. It has a hollow ring, first, because the ACTU has broken the so-called consensus; and secondly, because the new Arbitration Inspectorate will simply continue the work of the Industrial Relations Bureau. Likewise, the provisions of the Bill in respect of amalgamation of unions also reflect the previous Government's policy.

The previous Government set up the National Labour Consultative Council in 1977 as a forum for consultation between the Government, employers and unions on industrial issues. The Council through its committee system assisted the previous Government in consulting with employer and union groups to produce tangible results for the benefit of each other and the community. The fact that this Bill introduces NLCC recommendations is further evidence of the previous Government's enlightened, yet responsible and representative policies. An important lesson for this Government to learn is that the previous Government, the coalition Government, did not represent narrow, sectional interests. It represented all Australians. It consulted representatives of all Australians not just union officials. It represented employer groups. It represented individuals , whether they be urban or rural based. In conclusion, I wish to support the call of the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) for greater protection for people from being coerced into unions. The honourable member for Balaclava stated that it was his intention when he was Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a good Minister too.

—The honourable member for Balaclava was an outstanding Minister. He continues to be outstanding in his position as shadow Minister on employment and industrial relations matters. When the honourable member for Balaclava was the Minister he planned to introduce legislation to protect the freedom of people and prevent their being coerced into unions. It is now incumbent upon the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the present Government to ensure that the Arbitration Inspectorate operates vigorously to protect individuals from being coerced into unions. Self-employed people and sub -contractors, in particular, need protection from such coercion. If individuals choose not to join a union then that basic democratic right must be guaranteed. The Government must at all times direct the Arbitration Inspectorate towards this end.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask you whether the fact that the Government has got only a quarter of the number of members of the Opposition in the House means that it is not interested in this important piece of legislation.
—There is no point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am very pleased that the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) led for the Opposition in this debate. I think that has done a great deal to establish a consensus. I wish to reflect upon some of the remarks that have just been made by the honourable member for Gippsland ( Mr McGauran). With due respect to the honourable member for Gippsland, I point out that he has to understand that the main thrust of industrial relations in Australia today is to try to establish a wide consensus between the Government and the Opposition in the good conduct of industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the honourable member for Gippsland that essentially the field of industrial relations, when it is well practised, is the business of getting good behaviour from employers and unions. That is the role of government. I say that with due respect because we must as a government-this applied to the honourable member for Balaclava when he was the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations-try to establish whenever we can good behaviour by employers and unions. Unfortunately, if we go around and treat the entire industrial relations environment as if it is peopled by thugs then those concerned indeed will behave that way. It would be wrong for me to pretend that every union is run by people who have high principles or that every employer has high principles. It is also realistic to recognise that the majority of employers are well intentioned. I think the honourable member for Gippsland should understand that the National Economic Summit Conference was designed to get good people together to say how we ought to arrange the affairs of Australia, in terms of both the economy and industrial relations. Again, I think it is important to recognise that in the kind of world in which we live there will be conflict from time to time. It would be naive to imagine otherwise. Just how we deal with that conflict is a crucial issue.

I think the major point about this legislation-I suggest to the honourable member for Gippsland that this was an important point in the contribution of the honourable member for Balaclava-is that when conflicts arise we do not then proceed to beat the people around the head and say: 'You will behave the way I tell you or else'. I think that is the major point that marks off this move. I suggest to the previous Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) that we have now got a new game in industrial relations. We are not in the business of trying to promote conflict. There is enough conflict already. There are enough problems already in that area. The proper role of industrial relations is to try to achieve a better industrial climate.

I point out to the honourable members opposite who are trying to interject that , by their interjections, they are indicating that some people create difficulties in the industrial environment. It is interesting to note that if we were to focus all our energies upon who created problems then all we would simply be doing is lowering the entire tone of industrial relations. It is wrong to say that the Government was naive in holding the National Economic Summit Conference because it follows that one would then have to say that the managements of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, CSR Ltd and Ford Motor Company of Australia Ltd and so on are naive. I think we have the extraordinary situation in which the honourable member for Gippsland is somewhat out of step with the rest of the army. Honourable members may well want to draw that conclusion. I do not want to suggest that, but they might want to suggest that.

I think an important point is that the Government wants to achieve a good industrial relations climate. That ought to be our serious intention. At the same time, we are not in the business of sweeping under the carpet things with which we do not agree. There is nothing wrong with that either. The crucial thing we have to do in this place because a lot of people pay attention to what we do, is to say to people: 'Yes, we recognise your role and we recognise that there will be conflict but our job is to reduce that conflict'. Unfortunately, the Industrial Relations Bureau was seen by both employers and unions as heightening conflict. That is the reality of the world and we cannot escape from that.

The other point that has to be recognised is that it was desirable to set up the National Labour Consultative Council. It was brought in because that was the only way that the Australian Council of Trade Unions was willing to co-operate with the legislation to set up the Industrial Relations Bureau. It was a bargaining relationship. If one examines industrial relations one realises that it is a series of bargaining relationships. It is important to recognise in that context that when one side makes a claim with which one does not agree, one does not throw mud at it but says: 'Why is it that you have that view?'. We have to recognise the right of employers in the same way that we have to recognise the right of unions.

I would like to dwell for a moment upon the fact that we do have conflict and we do have problems. One of the things I am very pleased to see in the context of this move by the Government and by the Minister is that we will now have an enlarged Arbitration Inspectorate which will be able to get on with the business of dealing with some of the problem areas in industrial relations. I am pleased to note that one of the areas to which attention will be given is industrial safety. We recognise-I think honourable members opposite may share this view- that when a greater number of injuries occur in the industrial arena than on the roads then we have got a very serious problem.

It is not good enough for us to stand here and say: 'It is the fault of all those employers and all those unions'. We have the responsibility to redress that problem. We must say seriously and sincerely that we must try to do something about reducing the problems of industrial safety. If we examine the figures, for example, in terms of the time lost because of accidents we will realise that we have a very serious problem on our hands in Australia. I will not go into detail but I simply say that in a broad sense we have a very serious problem. I am pleased that this change will mean that the Inspectorate will be able to put more emphasis on industrial safety.

I remind the honourable member for Gippsland that there is a particular problem with which we need to deal. The employers themselves are carrying very large workers compensation costs. Why is that? In Australia we pay too little attention to one area of conflict. I think it is necessary to recognise that where industrial safety problems are high then the conflict problems are high. We see that in factories right across Australia. We have a responsibility as a government, as do honourable members opposite as an Opposition, because it is our electors who get injured in factories. We should all do something about industrial safety. I hope that honourable members opposite support this legislation from the point of view that it will make some major changes in the area of industrial safety. That is very important.

In summing up, I point out-I began by making this comment-that I am pleased that the honourable member for Balaclava led in this debate because he injected a bipartisan approach to this Bill. It is important that this legislation be brought through. The reason for it, very simply, is that it changes the tone of industrial relations. The tone we have had in recent years has been very much one of laying blame, of fault, of vindictiveness and of nastiness. It is wrong to imagine that all the ills of Australia are the result of the union movement; that is not the case. We have a collective responsibility in this place to resolve problems for the entire community. I suggest that this legislation goes a long way towards redressing that imbalance and towards saying to both parties: 'Yes, we do recognise your problems; yes, we are sincere and we will try to reduce conflict'.

I am very pleased to see that the legislation has been brought on. I think it will do much to follow through on the prices and incomes accord in showing that we are sincere about working towards a better climate in industrial relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) , give support to the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill in its broad concept, but there are some measures within the Bill what I will refer to later in my contribution to which I suggest improvements can be made. The Bill covers two quite distinct and separate aspects: Firstly, the elimination of the Industrial Relations Bureau and its replacement with the Industrial Inspectorate ; and secondly, the introduction of measures to facilitate the amalgamation of unions. I will touch on both of those aspects. The elimination of the Industrial Relations Bureau is, I think, supported by all those practitioners in the industrial relations field who believe that it was not an appropriate body, that it did not serve the purposes for which it was established and that it would best be replaced by the Arbitration Inspectorate. I believe the employers, the union movement and other practitioners in the industrial relations field would agree. However, I think that we in the House, the unions, the employers and practitioners in the industrial relations field must recognise that there must be and needs to be a body that can ensure that the provisions of industrial law and the provisions of awards are properly complied with by both employers and unions. It worries me greatly that we are proposing a mechanism through the Arbitration Inspectorate that on paper and in legislation gives all of the appearances of being a body that will ensure and enforce the provisions of industrial law; but it will enforce those provisions only if governments have the courage to ensure that the body, when it is set up, does exactly what the Parliament intends it to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Relations Bureau was a body with the same intent as the Arbitration Inspectorate. It did not work properly because there was not the conviction on the part of governments to make it work. We all agree that employers have a responsibility to ensure that they comply with the provisions of industrial awards and legislation and that if employers breach those provisions there needs to be a body to identify those breaches and to ensure that some sort of corrective action is taken. We all agree on that. But, equally , that same body must be charged with the responsibility of ensuring that the other side of industrial relations also complies with those provisions. I am talking particularly of the union movement. We cannot have a situation in which one side of industrial relations totally complies with the provisions of industrial awards, with a policing mechanism to ensure that it does, while the other side can flout the law in the way that it has in the past.

The unfortunate situation is that since the O'Shea case in 1968 no government has had the courage to take action against a union for non-compliance with awards. The result of that is that we now have a union movement that is in effect a law unto itself. That situation in any ordered society cannot continue to exist. There are unions which are responsible and which maintain that their major roles are for the betterment of the working conditions of their members and that they play a responsible part in the Australian community; and true, they do. But equally we have to recognise that there are some unions, just as there are some employers, which do not play the game, which flout the law and which treat themselves as being above the law. That situation in any ordered society cannot continue to exist. If we are setting up an Arbitration Inspectorate that body must be charged with ensuring that unions comply with the law in the same way that employers are required to. I am sure that my colleagues on the other side of the House, while they are silent on this point, would have to agree that we cannot have industrial anarchy as we have had in the past. It is tearing this country to pieces. We must have unions which are prepared to accept and comply with the law.

My colleague, the honourable member for Balaclava, has pointed out some of the actions that have been taken against individuals on particular occasions. He particularly cited the protection that needs to be given to self-employed people . I support him in the propositions that he made. There are a few illustrations we can cite of individuals, whether they be self-employed or employees, without doubt not only being discriminated against but also blackmailed. That cannot continue. For example, I cite the case of Mr Noel Latham in Broken Hill. When Mr Latham chose not to join a union-surely that is his democratic right, which is a decision according to his conscience-he was totally discriminated against by the whole union movement of Australia. The result is that Mr Latham has not worked since. He was so aggrieved that he was able to obtain a very substantial judgment in the courts, I think in the order of $110,000, for the damages that he had suffered. Despite the fact that he could prove damages before the courts, he still has not got a job because the unions discriminate against him. I notice that the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) is nodding his head in support. Civil liberties are out the door. We do not care about that one individual because he dares to stand up to the power of the unions! So what the honourable member for Melbourne would have is not government in this country by parliament or government by law-oh, no, we are going to have government by unions! The unions say: Join the union or we will break your leg'. We call this industrial democracy! I call it blackmail. I quote another case, that of Mr Laidely, an oil distributor. Honourable members may remember his case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another one.

—Another one, says the honourable member for Melbourne. Mr Laidely dared to raise the question of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. What happened to Mr Laidely? He was totally discriminated against, not just by the Transport Workers Union but by the whole of the union movement. Eventually we did finally get a resolution on this matter, thanks to the efforts of the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr Street). In his role as Minister for Industrial Relations he was able to resolve that dispute. But no credit at all goes to the union movement for what it attempted to do to Mr Laidely.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making is that within our industrial relations area we must have a mechanism that protects the individual. Anything else is a blatant and flagrant violation of the law as we know and understand it in Australia. We must protect the individual against monopolising, power hungry unions. I fully support the Minister in saying that we will have an Arbitration Inspectorate to ensure that unions comply with the law, and hope that it will do that. One of the things that concerns me in saying that is the statement made by the Minister in his second reading speech that:
as previously the powers and duties of Inspectors will be as laid down by the Minister.

I suggest to the Minister that if that is what is intended, it represents a grievious shortcoming of the legislation. What we are doing is setting up a body that is designed to ensure compliance with industrial law, but saying that the Minister will be the only person who will determine what powers and functions that body will have. That is a grievious shortcoming of the legislation.

We have been told often of the accord that the Australian Labor Party has with the union movement. What is to ensure that the role and functions of that particular body, when it is established, will not be to ensure compliance by the union movement but merely to engage in some form of secondary blackmailing role against the employers, simply to back up what the unions are doing, to act against the employers without any form of compliance by the union movement taking place? I hope that the Minister does not have that in mind; knowing him as I do, I am sure that he does not. I think that it is just an oversight in the drafting of this legislation.

However, I suggest that we in this Parliament need to ensure that the public at large has confidence that this body will play its role in ensuring compliance with industrial law. To ensure that, I suggest that the powers and functions of the Arbitration Inspectorate be laid down by regulation, not by direction from the Minister. If the powers and functions are laid down by regulation, it gives the Parliament the opportunity to peruse them and to voice any objection that it might see to them. At least in that way we as a parliament and the public at large would have the opportunity to identify and correct any shortfalls in the way in which the Arbitration Inspectorate will operate. Having said that and having made that suggestion, I give my support to that aspect of the legislation .

The other aspect of the legislation involves the amalgamation of unions. I think that all of us, in this place and across Australia, would agree in general principle that there are too many unions in Australia. There are 300-odd unions some large and some small, which cause quite extensive disruption at various work place levels, particularly in demarcation disputes that the public neither understands nor supports. If this mechanism can help in some way to reduce the incidence of demarcation disputes, it has my full support. One of the objectives of this aspect of the legislation is to reduce demarcation disputes. If it can play a role in doing that, it should be supported by the Parliament and people of Australia.

The problem of the large number of unions that we have goes well beyond this legislation. The problem is compounded by having unions which are registered at both Federal and State level and, in many cases, dividing themselves as between State and Federal bodies. Some unions spread their tentacles all over the place. They are not subject to any control and disputes can take place between State unions and Federal unions. We need not just a mechanism which will allow for the easier amalgamation of unions but also one that will reduce the methods of registration, as between the Commonwealth and the States, so as to achieve a more ordered, functional role for industrial relations. I shall not dwell too much on that point.

The reduction of the number of unions has the support of the National Labour Consultative Council. In that regard, I believe that we as a parliament have a duty to enact legislation to give effect to the recommendations of the NLCC. The matter goes much further back than just the history of the NLCC. Back in 1975 the Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry, the Jackson Committee, recommended that there be more effective methods for the amalgamation of unions so as to reduce their number. That proposal was backed up by the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, which looked into the Public Service and made the comment that there were too many Public Service unions and that some should be amalgamated.

In calling for amalgamation, or enacting legislation for union amalgamations, we need to be careful to ensure that any proposed amalgamation will genuinely comply with the wishes of the majority of the members of the unions concerned. I do not believe that, under the provisions of the present Act, that is properly done. The Bill requires the vote of a minimum of 25 per cent of the membership of a union and a simple majority in favour. I put it to the Minister that, in effect, 12 1/2 per cent of the members of a union could agree to an amalgamation and the procedure would comply with the provisions of this legislation. I do not believe that a vote by 12 1/2 per cent of the membership gives a sufficient indication of what the total membership of a union wants.

For this reason, I fully support the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Balaclava, which effectively would ensure that the support of 25 per cent, or one-quarter, of the membership of the union would be needed before an amalgamation would be considered approved: Twenty-five per cent of the membership is still a very small proportion, but at least it can give a clearer guide to the wishes of the total membership of the union than what is being proposed in this legislation. In a spirit of bipartisanship, I say that I hope the Minister will look very seriously at the proposition that we are putting. If he does so, in the same spirit of bipartisanship, I think that he would have to agree that the proposition put forward by the honourable member for Balaclava would produce a far more democratic process and give a much better indication of the wishes of the total membership of unions that might be proposing amalgamation.

Having made those suggestions to the Minister, I say that the Bill, in its broad concept, has my support, but in regard to the role and function of the Arbitration Inspectorate I hope that the Minister will ensure that the Inspectorate has not only the necessary powers but also the necessary support of the Government, to ensure that all sides of industrial relations, both employers and unions, will comply with the industrial law. Without such compliance we will have anarchy. It will not just be restricted to industrial anarchy; it must spread to other sections and activities within the community. I urge the Minister to look seriously at my suggestions so that the powers and methods of operation of the Inspectorate will be determined by regulation rather than by ministerial decree. I believe that would ensure that it would have the support of the Parliament and of the public at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Firstly, I thank all honourable members for their contribution to this debate. I am very pleased that the Opposition has seen fit not to oppose the Bill. That is a wise decision, because we should remember that this is a piece of legislation which has the full agreement of all parties represented on the National Labour Consultative Council. The trade union movement is fully in support of it, but so, too, are the employers represented on that body. It is, therefore, quite clearly a piece of legislation which is very much in the interests of improved industrial relations in this country. That, I believe, is a very good reason for the Opposition not to seek to oppose or amend it in any way. Of course, the Opposition has proposed a second reading amendment, with which I will deal in a moment. Before coming to that amendment, I will make a few comments on some of the suggestions made in speeches by Opposition members. The shadow Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), was concerned, for much of his speech, to discuss the situation regarding independent contractors and, as he sees it, the deficiencies of the principal Act in that regard. I will study his remarks. I believe that they were sincerely made and I will give them due consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to him also that this matter has already been the subject of representation to me, which I am sure is not a surprise to him. Therefore it was already in my mind as something to which I have to give consideration in the future. This matter will be the subject of further consideration at the NLCC and in due course I will doubtless be able to make some further comments about that NLCC consideration. I would say to him, however, as he would presumably already be well aware, that the Bill does not repeal or affect any provisions relating to independent contractors, so the position of independent contractors is not adversely affected by the legislation. His comments really pointed to the deficiencies of the Act as it stood and he said that more needs to be done. Of course, those deficiencies are not necessarily the fault of the present Government. We have been in office for only a couple of months. Those deficiencies were present under the previous Government and I accept his comments that he would have acted upon those alleged deficiencies had he remained in office long enough. If there are deficiencies, they are not of our making.

The rights of individuals was the subject of comment by a few speakers on the other side. I draw their attention to the fact that the rights of individuals as presently contained in the Act are, of course, not in any way affected and also individuals can continue to seek assistance, with the abolition of the Industrial Relations Bureau, from either my Department or, more likely, from the office of the Industrial Registrar, to overcome their problems. I believe that we are not neglecting the interests of individuals in removing the IRB and moving to reinstate the Arbitration Inspectorate which existed before the introduction of the IRB.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you pursue the matters at the IRB?

—I will come to the honourable member's points now. Firstly, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) was concerned about the outstanding IRB proceedings before the court. Under the Bill the inspectors will be able to take over proceedings in regard to award matters, so there is clearly no problem there. I am informed by the Director of the Bureau that only two active prosecutions, other than award breaches, are current at present. The first of these is the matter mentioned, I think, by the honourable member for Mitchell; that is Linehan v. the Australian Public Service Association, which involved prosecution of the union for offences under section 188 of the Act for the imposition of penalties upon members for failing to join in industrial action. I understand that submissions by the parties in this matter have been completed and that the Federal Court of Australia has reserved its decision. The second prosecution is Linehan v. the Australian Railways Union which involves similar action against the ARU for imposition of a fine on a member. I have been advised that the union concerned has agreed to revoke the fine and the Bureau has instituted action to withdraw the prosecution. I believe that both of these matters, which are not award matters, will be resolved and there will be no problem in the way that was raised by the honourable member.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the matter of union amalgamations, I will make just a few comments , particularly as this is the subject of the second reading amendment. The suggestion by the Opposition is that instead of having a requirement for at least a 25 per cent return of members eligible to vote with the majority of those in favour of the amalgamation, there be a minimum return of ballot papers of 25 per cent and a two-thirds majority vote in favour, or, alternatively, that 25 per cent of the total membership vote in favour, provided that those so voting constitute a majority of the votes cast.

The first of those proposals was considered by the NLCC as far back as February 1980. The Council then unanimously rejected that proposal and recommended the proposal contained in the present Bill, that is, that there be a minimum return of 25 per cent and a majority vote in favour. The proposal, as reflected in this Bill, has been re-endorsed by the NLCC. It said that that was what it wanted in February 1980 and very recently it has re-endorsed that proposition. It is not something which has been poorly considered or ill considered. It has been in the minds of the top level members of the trade union movement and the employers of this country and on those two occasions they have endorsed the proposal in the Bill at present.

I point out also that the NLCC recommendations were accepted by the previous Government and, indeed, they formed part of that Government's election policy commitment in 1980. Of course that commitment was not honoured. The then Minister, in May 1980, said that the NLCC proposals were to be further considered and they were ultimately dropped by the then Government in favour of the 1982 industry union proposals which were rejected in the Senate. As I said, the NLCC has, having gone through all that process, re-endorsed the original proposal which it endorsed in February 1980. We have every confidence that what we have now put before the Parliament has the confidence of both sides of industry. The measures should be accepted by the Opposition as being appropriate in regard to union amalgamations. Anything else that the Opposition proposes is not favoured by either the unions or the employers. It will clearly make union amalgamations more difficult to achieve and that, I believe, is a major mark against it. If we simply up the requirement we make it more difficult to get union amalgamations and, therefore, we have to ask whether amalgamations are desirable. It is the clear view of the union movement, the national employers and the Australian Government that it is very much in our interests to improve industrial relations in this country, to reduce the mammoth number of unions that we have. If we are to reduce them in any substantial way, we have to ease considerably the present quite prohibitive provisions in relation to union amalgamations. That is what this Bill is designed to do. I believe that it should have the full support of the Opposition. I am disappointed that the Opposition has seen fit to criticise the proposal and to suggest an alternative.

I make one other point in regard to this matter. The shadow Minister mentioned that an argument for the proposal which he put forward in the second reading amendment was that it would give greater opportunity for involvement of members. Of course, it gives no greater opportunity for involvement of members at all. Every member who is eligible will get a ballot paper. He has the same opportunity to vote. The opportunity to participate is just the same, but by upping the requirement for the proportion of members who must vote in favour of amalgamation, we are simply making it more difficult to get union amalgamations because, as honourable members opposite have acknowledged in their speeches, it is very difficult to get anything like a large vote of members of a union for union amalgamation or for most other things. I believe that it is not a matter of giving union members greater opportunities to participate or to be involved. That opportunity is there. We are simply making it more likely that union amalgamations, which are in the interest of better industrial relations and therefore, I believe, in the national interest, can be proceeded with. We are very determined to stick to the proposal in the legislation and I hope that the Opposition will not pursue in the Senate the proposal which is contained in the second reading amendment.

Another point I should like to make relates to some comments by the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) regarding the powers and duties of the Inspectorate which he was concerned were being left to be determined by me under the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or any future Minister.

—Or any future Minister. I accept that. I say to him firstly that we are putting back into the legislation pretty much what was there from the time the Inspectorate was introduced, I think in the early 1940s, until the IRB was introduced in 1976. Throughout that period those powers and duties have been determined by the Minister. But in addition to what applied in all that time, we will be publishing them in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. That was not a provision which applied before. So there will be clear public knowledge as to what those powers and duties are as determined by me. They will not be something hidden from public scrutiny as was the case in the past. With those comments I again commend honourable members for their contributions to the debate. I hope that the House will pass the second reading of this Bill unanimously.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Macphee's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

These amendments are quite technical amendments which rectify some deficiencies in the original Bill which I can explain in the following way: The first two amendments to clause 7 which I have moved have arisen following an examination of the wording of clause 7 in the Bill by Parliamentary Counsel. In this respect , on reflecting on the wording of the clause the conclusion has been reached that proposed sub-sections 4 and 5 tend to be circular. In other words, proposed sub-section 5, insofar as it refers to powers and duties conferred or imposed by proposed sub-section 4 refers to a sub-section which really does not confer or impose powers and duties but merely indicates how powers and duties are to be conferred. The amendments proposed to clause 7 will remedy this defect.

The reference in paragraph (b) to sub-paragraph (i) of paragraph (a) should have been to paragraph (a). The amendments moved to proposed new section 158AH in clause 11 are again technical drafting changes which are necessary as a consequence of the amendment proposed in sub-clause 11 (c) which deletes proposed new sub-section 158AH (30A). The amendments moved in relation to clause 27 are further technical drafting changes to the amendments consequential upon repeal of Part VIA contained in the Schedule to the Bill.
