DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (COMPANIES, CORPORATE UNIT TRUSTS AND SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Act 1982 which declares and imposes the rates of tax payable for the 1982-83 financial year by companies, trustees of corporate unit trusts and trustees of superannuation funds. As I explained in my accompanying second reading speech on the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment Bill 1983, the amendment proposed by this Bill will extend the operation of the Income Tax ( Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Act 1982 so that it also declares and imposes the rate of tax payable-that is 46 per cent-by a trustee of a trust estate who is to be taxed on behalf of a non-resident company beneficiary. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (PAYMENTS FOR WORK) (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is complementary to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 which I introduced earlier. Honourable members will recall that in introducing that Bill I outlined for the House features of the proposed system of deductions of tax at source from payments for work and services. The purpose of this Bill is to ensure that a debt payable to the Commissioner of Taxation in respect of such unremitted tax deductions will, in a bankruptcy or liquidation, have the same priority as do unremitted pay-as-you-earn tax deductions. A technical explanation of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum that is to be made available to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I have your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, to suggest that the House has a general debate covering the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1983-84, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1983-84 and the Supply ( Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1983-84 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
-Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are the normal Supply Bills and the Opposition will be supporting them. They cover the granting of Supply from 1 July this year. It is therefore appropriate, because debate on these Supply Bills is taking place on the eve of the long awaited economic statement from the Government, that something should be said about the perspective and circumstances in which the economic statement of the Government will be brought down tomorrow night. Whatever may be contained in the economic statement we can be certain of at least one thing-that is that the decisions to be announced in that economic statement will have a very significant bearing upon the fiscal and budgetary policies of the Hawke Labor Government not only in 1983-84 but also in subsequent years. On the eve of the presentation of that economic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) it is important that the statement be put in context and be put in perspective, particularly so far as it relates to economic debate which is occurring in Australia at the present time, which has occurred in Australia over the past 18 months and will no doubt continue to occur in its wake.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of foremost importance that the House recall the economic policy on which the Hawke Labor Government was elected. It is important to do that because if one goes back to first principles one realises that government is about implementing the election platforms of political parties. As we have been reminded so often by honourable members on both sides of the House, election platforms are not things to be totally repudiated and totally torn up.

TALK.START.PARA: —That didn't worry you when you were in.

—I am glad that the honourable member for Bowman, who interjected, and the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who is trying to interject, share my enthusiasm when I say that parties should stick to the platforms on which they are elected. It is important to remind ourselves that during the campaign before the last election the Labor Party called, above everthing else, for a complete change in economic policy. Surely no honourable member on the other side of the House dissents from the proposition that the Australian Labor Party campaigned before 5 March on one simple matter-that is that Australia needed a totally different economic policy. People like the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) would be candid enough and honest enough to agree that the Australian Labor Party campaigned on that policy. He is honest enough and he is doctrinely pure enough to admit that the Labor Party campaigned before 5 March on the proposition that the monetary and fiscal policies of the former Government were far too contractionary. If one goes back to the statements that were made before that election, one goes back to the joint economic statement that was released, just after the election campaign commenced, by the now Treasurer and the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the launching of the Australian Labor Party economic platform. I quote in part from that, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the Treasurer--
That is referring to the then Treasurer-

intends that the next Budget should continue the contractionary policies of the past. the deficit increase during 1982-83 was overwhelmingly the result of the depression causing increases in unemployment benefit payments and reducing taxation receipts. However, this deficit is still contractionary . . .

That is, the amount of $4,000m was still contractionary in the minds of the then shadow Treasurer and the then Leader of the Opposition, for if there were full employment there would be a huge surplus. In making that statement, the then shadow Treasurer and the then Leader of the Opposition were very much echoing the sentiments and the beliefs of the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) who, as shadow Treasurer in the former Labor Opposition, on 14 December, criticised the economic policies of the former Government as:
. . . containing extremely tight monetary policies which had caused a rapid increase in interest rates and a severely contractionary fiscal stance.

It is of significance that that criticism and that categorisation of the former Government's economic policy made on 14 December by the Minister, as the then economic spokesman for the Opposition, was made on the very day that the former Government released an update of the economic forecasts and projected Budget deficit for 1982-83 which it had provided to the Premiers Conference convened to discuss the then Government's wage pause initiative. What, in effect, the then economic spokesman was saying was that a projected Budget deficit for this year of about $4,000m represented an extremely tight fiscal policy. I repeat those words 'severely contractionary fiscal stance'. So we had a situation that as we approached the last election we had not only the then economic spokesman for the Opposition, the now Treasurer, but also the then Leader of the Opposition and the now Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations saying that a fiscal policy which implied a deficit outcome this year of about $4,000m was severely contractionary. They are not my words, they were the words of the Government's then economic spokesman. He said that amount was severely contractionary.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know about your $4,000m. That was before you announced-

—I know the honourable member for Burke does not like this because it is utterly inconsistent with the line his leader is now taking, but he will hear this because it happens to represent one of the greatest policy and economic somersaults that any political party has engaged in in recent years. But of course there was nothing strange about those words from the then economic spokesman and the then Leader of the Opposition because the present Prime Minister said after the last Budget that as far as he was concerned a deficit of about the average of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries would be quite in order. He knew then, as he knows now, that that implied about 4 per cent to 5 per cent of gross domestic product, which would imply not an outcome this year on the basis of the former Government's Budget deficit of about $4,500m, as last advised to me, but an outcome indeed of $6, 500m. So what the now Prime Minister was advocating, as the Opposition spokesman , at the end of last year, was a deficit outcome this year of about $6,500m, and the Lord alone knows what that would have implied so far as 1983-84 is concerned . Yet he has the audacity to come into this Parliament, to go before the Australian people, to wring his hands and say: 'Shock, horror, isn't it dreadful ? We face a very severe and difficult budgetary situation'. Yet he alone ran around this countryside during the election campaign without a care in the world about the size of the Budget deficit. He ran around this countryside and said: ' Comrades, throw away your conservative calculators. Let us all gather around and throw away our conservative calculators. Let us forget about these wicked conservative Budget deficits because under a Hawke Labor Government all will be well'. The fact is that before 5 March the Prime Minister could not have cared less about the size of the Budget deficit. He know, that, and every person who sits behind him knows that, because he told us to throw away our calculators. Yet now he comes into this House and goes before the Australian people, wrings his hands and sheds crocodile tears about the size of the Budget deficit because he knows darned well that the policies he advocated in Opposition would have implied a starting point for next year's Budget exercise on his own calculations released on 18 March of several thousands of millions of dollars in excess of the figure that he deceitfully and misleadingly flings around concerning the former Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing we have to get into perspective and fixed in our minds is that tomorrow night's statement will be made against the background of a government that was elected by the Australian people on one simple economic proposition. It was, very simply, that we needed a change of economic policy and that the abandonment of the tight monetary and fiscal policies of the former Government was the real answer to all the economic problems of Australia. It was said that what was really needed was not less spending and more taxation, but more spending and less taxation. The then Leader of the Opposition went before the Australian people and said: 'We have to abandon all this contractionary economic policy, all this monetarism and all this tight budgetary discipline adopted by the Fraser Government. What we really have to do is spend more and tax less'. Throughout the whole of the election campaign, with reckless indifference to the effect of the promises made during that campaign on the size of the Budget deficit in 1983-84, or indeed any subsequent year, the then Labor Opposition campaigned on the basis of an expansionary economic policy, saying to the Australian people: 'What we want to do is adopt an expansionary economic policy. We want to throw out the contractionary budgetary deficit of $4,000m in 1982-83. It is too contractionary.' That is the result of the contractionary fiscal stance. We want to throw all of that out and come to the Australian people and offer a spending of some $4,000m to $5,000m more. When the then Government said to the Opposition during the election campaign that the Australian economy could not afford further tax cuts, what did the Prime Minister and his colleagues say? They said: 'There are the conservatives, once again dragging out their calculators and talking about Budget deficits and scaring the daylights out of us on the basis of some outmoded economic policy'. They poured scorn on the warnings that the Australian economy could not afford the economic program that was promised during the election campaign. We warned the then Labor Opposition that the Australian economy could not afford the thousands of millions of dollars of additional spending and the taxation cuts. We said that the taxation cuts that were given in the last Budget were as much as the Australian economy could afford during 1982-83. But what did the Labor Opposition do in the face of those warnings? It brushed them aside and said: 'Do not worry. The Australian economy can afford it. It needs a total change of economic policy. It needs an expansionary policy, more spending and less taxation. If you elect us, we will implement that sort of policy'.

The most important thing that this Parliament and the Australian people must understand about the economic statement to be delivered by the Treasurer of the Hawke Labor Government tomorrow night is that it will be delivered by the Treasurer in a government that won office on the basis of promising an expansionary budgetary policy. It won office on the basis of promising to spend more and to tax less.

The Opposition will not tire over the coming months of reminding the Australian people of that particular commitment that was made by the then Leader of the Opposition, by the Treasurer, by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and, in their name, on behalf of the members of the entire Government. So the Australian people will constantly be reminded that that was the policy that the present Prime Minister, during the election campaign and in the months before it, advocated-an increase in this year's deficit of about 50 per cent. He advocated that we should have a deficit in 1982-83, this year, of about 4 per cent to 5 per cent of gross domestic product. Imagine a deficit this year of $6, 500m! He knows as well as I do what that would imply for 1983-84. Yet his Treasurer had the hide to mislead the National Economic Summit Conference by saying: 'We did not know. We were not warned. We would not have promised it had we really known'.

The truth is that the Government won power on the basis of promising a total reversal of economic policy. It won power on promising an expansionary economic approach. It was warned that the economy could not afford it. Now that it is in power it will seek, through tomorrow night's statement and many other statements , to excuse itself, to excuse the deceit and to excuse the misleading policy that its members presented to the Australian people during the election campaign .

Beyond reminding the Parliament and the Australian people of the perspective against which the economic statement of tomorrow night has to be presented, I suggest to the Treasurer and the Government that the economic policy statement tomorrow night is not just an opportunity to announce a series of ad hoc revenue and expenditure decisions; it is also an opportunity for the Treasurer to provide to the Australian people, on behalf of the Government, a clear indication of where his party and his Government stand in a number of major economic areas. Firstly, I hope that the Treasurer, in tomorrow night's statement, will give a very clear indication of precisely where the Government stands in regard to its wages policy. I think it is common ground between both sides in this Parliament that the greatest domestic enemy of employment at present is the excessive wage rises of the last 18 months. That is not just propaganda of the Liberal Party or statements made by Ministers in the former Liberal Government. One has to go no further than to look at the economic statement by the Treasurer to the Summit Conference. That was a very good statement because for a short period, impressed by the need for objectivity, impressed by the desire to achieve consensus at the Summit, there were many sections of that speech by the Treasurer at the Summit that came very close to the reality of Australia's economic circumstances.

On behalf of the Opposition, I say that one of the great benefits of the Summit was the extent to which the Treasurer, on behalf of the Government, was prepared to supply to the Summit, and through the Summit to the Australian people, some very valuable information and objective commentary on the state of the economy. As a consequence of that, economic debate in Australia has been greatly improved . I said that at the time, and I repeat it today. I believe that that was one of the beneficial outcomes of the National Economic Summit conference. I congratulate the Government on its initiative in calling that Conference.

Having said that, we cannot avoid the consequences of the information that was made available by the Treasurer and his colleagues to the Summit, and he cannot avoid the consequences of what he says. He cannot avoid the fact that he told the Summit that the major reason for Australia's present economic dilemma was the international recession. What a remarkable discovery by the Treasurer of the Hawke Labor Government! At long last, after 2 1/2 years, Labor members have discovered the international recession, having for 2 1/2 years said: 'The international rcession does not really have anything to do with it'. My colleague from Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) is so embarrassed about that revelation that he cannot contain himself. The truth of the matter is that for 2 1/2 years, while we were in government, they ran around saying: 'The international recession has nothing to do with it'. But, having been elected to government, and before the jury of the trade union movement and the business community, faced with the need to be totally objective and totally honest, the Treasurer said: 'Really, the central economic problem at present is the international economic recession'.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was reminding the House of the sorts of economic policies on which the Australian Labor Party had campaigned in the recent election. I reminded it that the Labor Party was elected on the basis that the solution to all our economic problems was to adopt an expansionary Budget and fiscal policy, a relaxed monetary policy , and generally overturn the economic policies of the former Government; that that was one of the reference points against which the economic statement to be delivered to- morrow night by the Treasurer should be measured. All of us will look forward with very great interest to seeing how consistent will be that statement with the alleged offerings of the Australian Labor Party during the election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of my remarks, I heard a few interjections. In one of those interjections I thought I heard a reference to a figure of $9.6 billion. I am pleased that honourable members opposite have raised that figure because, in the remaining moments available to me, I should like to say something about it. I remind the House that as everyone knows, that was a starting point figure provided to me by the Government's advisers in terms of $9,000m, without any documentation and without any detail, several days before the election. The figure of $9.6 billion was provided to me on the evening before the elections and it was unveiled in all its glory, in much greater detail, to the new Government a day or two after the elections.

I have said on many occasions, and I will say again tonight, that I do not accept that figure as being other than a speculative starting point for working towards the true size of next year's Budget deficit. I have repeatedly said that on every occasion in past years, when a figure has been presented at that time of the year, it has been demonstrated to be virtually irrelevant by the time the Budget is actually put together. The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), was kind enough yesterday to remind the House that in successive years when we were in power, starting point figures of that kind were significantly altered, not just because of a decision in the expenditure and revenue area made by the former Government but more importantly, or just as importantly, because of changed economic parameters. I would like to say something about that tonight.

I do not think many honourable members here tonight realise that that particular figure of $9.6 billion was calculated on an assumed rise in gross domestic product in 1983-84 of only 0.5 per cent. But over the last few days, and as recently as this morning, we have had both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer coming into this House and saying that recovery is on the way. They cannot have it both ways. They cannot on the one hand try to clobber the former Government and say: 'Look at this terrible figure', accepting that it is based on a growth forecast of 0.5 per cent and, in the next breath, come into this House and say, as does the Treasurer: 'Look, growth is on the way and by early 1984 the Australian economy will be growing strongly'. I hope that the Treasurer 's statement proves to be correct. If it is, to the extent that credit is due to the Treasurer, I will give credit to him. But he cannot, on the one hand, say that by early 1984 the Australian economy will be growing strongly and yet fall back on a GDP forecast in 1983 of only 0.5 per cent, which is fundamental to that projection of $9.6 billion.

But even more precisely, everybody knows that the scenario, presented to the National Economic Summit Conference, which the Government embraces most warmly of all is scenario A. That is the one that has the fairly weak wages policy but it is, nonetheless, the scenario that the Government embraces and quite clearly is that on which the Government's economic statement tomorrow will be based. But interestingly enough, that scenario implies a growth in 1983-84 of no less than 2.7 per cent-in other words, about 2.2 per cent greater than the GDP forecast on which the $9.6 billion figure is based. If one looks at the sensitivity analysis presented to the Economic Summit, one finds that a 2 per cent rise in real GDP in 1983-84 would cut government outlays by about $260m and raise receipts by about $680m. In other words, we are looking at a difference, in that regard alone, of some $1,000m.

Even if one accepts all of the revenue and expenditure forecasts that make up that figure, on the Government's professed growth forecasts alone, $9.6 billion is a phoney figure. In reality, using the Government's own more recently professed parameters, the figure would be closer to about $8,000m. That will not , of course, stop the Treasurer coming into this House tomorrow night and saying : 'We had this terrible task. We had to start with this terrible figure of $9.6 billion and look how terrific we are. We have got it back to $8,500m'. Do honourable members suppose that he will concede to the House that if we apply the Government's more recent forecasts-the growth boasts of both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-that figure of $9.6 billion will be automatically reduced to somewhere between $8,000m and $8.500m?

Also the figure is based upon an inflation forecast of only 6 per cent in 1983- 84. I hope that in 1983-84 inflation is only 6 per cent. I think all of us will be very pleased if in fact it is. But I think it would be a fairly brave person who would make a forecast now that inflation through 1983-84 will be only about 6 per cent. If one looks at the consumer price index for the March quarter and bears in mind some of the cost pressures that are still in the system as a result of the wages explosion of the last 18 months, it would be a fairly brave person who would be prepared to come into this House and assert that inflation during that period would be only about 6 per cent.

Again, if one refers to the sensitivity analysis presented to the Economic Summit, one finds that a 2 per cent increase in the assumed consumer price index would chop the deficit by a further $500m or so, other things being equal, as a result of an increase in outlays of about $600m and an increase in receipts of about $1,120m. This shows once again that that figure of $9.6 billion was due in part to predictions about the success of the wages pause because, as the Treasurer said in his speech at the Summit, a successful lowering of inflation will, in the first instance, increase the size of the prospective deficit.

These projections indicate very clearly how wildly speculative that particular figure was and remains. They indicate that it is not a reliable bench-mark against which to measure the cost cutting nerve of the Hawke Government. It is not a reliable bench-mark against which to measure the fiscal resolve of the Hawke Government. It is nothing but a highly speculative figure that has had no substantive basis other than it is a figure with which to attempt to clobber and to criticise the actions of the former Government. Out of their own mouths, both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have, since the election, adopted growth forecasts and other forecasts about economic performance in the Australian economy which are quite inconsistent with the parameters upon which that figure has been based.

We cannot on the one hand say that the true starting point is $9.6 billion, which assumes a GDP next financial year of one half of one per cent and, on the other hand embrace for 1983-84 an economic scenario which assumes a growth in GDP of 2.7 per cent. The two things simply do not sit together. The honourable member for Hunter knows that and the honourable member for Burke knows that. We cannot in the one breath say that we are working on the basis of a deficit figure that assumes a growth of half of one per cent in GDP but in another breath say that we will have the benefit of claiming that there will be growth in GDP of about 2.7 per cent. I think that comparison in growth forecasts illustrates more accurately than any other comparison just how phoney that figure is and how reliable was the advice I received in each of the five years in which I received forecasts about prospective starting points for deficits at this time of the year that it was very unwise to rely on those estimates as a guide to the ultimate outcome. Of course, it once again illustrates the essential phoniness and hypocrisy of the position assumed by the Government in the economic debate at the present time. These people were the apostles of unrestrained deficit financing in the election campaign. The Prime Minister who ran around the country telling us to throw our calculators away, and who wanted a Budget deficit this year 50 per cent greater than has now been forecast and 50 per cent greater than his own Minister for Finance dared to criticise this morning, has no credit at all when it comes to Budget deficits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will no doubt be amused at the spirited attempts of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to try to convince the Australian people that he is a recent convert to the virtues of political integrity. As a defender of integrity he does not wear the mantle with any conviction at all. Following a period of seven years, marked by an unbroken sequence of broken promises, we can all be excused for becoming rather cynical. His tortuous attempts at justifying the use of shonky figures for the Budget deficit this year will always remain as a notorious example of the way that he and his previous Government attempted to deceive the Australian people. That is enough of that. I return to the debate on the Supply Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: There is hardly likely to be any avalanche of dissension, I would imagine, apart from the poor attempt by the Deputy Leader Opposition, about the necessity to ensure the passage of these Bills. They are basically procedural Bills that are required to be passed to ensure the maintenance of activity within government departments. The Government requires to be able to proceed with the activity laid out under continuing commitments and, where it is necessary, to commence the process of change. But, in rising to speak to these Bills I congratulate the Government for the responsible manner in which it has set about the task of examining the financial status of government departments. I recognise that this task was made even more difficult by the extent and the turbidity of the economic morass that was inherited by the Government as a result of the years of ideological myopia and incompetence of its Fraserite predecessor.

During those long dark days the economic emphasis was placed unsuccessfully upon the reduction of inflation. The unemployed whose ranks were burgeoning continuously were virtually ignored. I say 'virtually ignored' for, to its eternal shame, the Fraser Government contained and the Opposition still contains and tolerates individuals who treat unemployed Australians with opprobium. At no time during the course of the Fraser Government's divisive and contemptible reign did it demonstrate any real compassion for the hundreds of thousands of Australians eking out an existence in a state of poverty. It is therefore to the credit of the Government that, on assuming office, it acted swiftly to increase the unemployment benefit for unemployed adults to the rate of the single pension . This demonstrates the sincerity of the Government's intention to maintain its priority concern for the welfare of these unfortunate fellow Australians. It is to be hoped, of course, that some further relief will be given in the near future to the lot of those young unemployed people under the age of 18.

Not only are we all aware of the Government's concern for those most seriously burdened by the impact of Australia's economic depression but we also witnessed in the wake of the election the Government's willingness to meet its obligations to those who lost so much in the disastrous bushfires in South Australia and Victoria. I give credit to the previous Government for agreeing to the requests of Victoria and South Australia. Both the Federal and State authorities must be complimented for the haste with which they acted to help those unfortunate people. Only governments are able to do this and, I guess, are also expected to do this. They have the resources in personnel, expertise, money, plant and influence to assist and so they should. Nevertheless, their willingness to act quickly is to their credit.

It is remarkable that misery so dramatically evident as that caused by natural disasters stimulates immediate response from the public and government. The more insidious effects of economic depression and the inequitable distribution of the nation's resources leaves many thousands-indeed millions-of our fellow Australians in poverty. They look not for large scale measures to help them restore their lives to levels of affluence enjoyed by more fortunate Australians . Their lot is, at best, to receive basic benefits that ensure a life of relative poverty. Beyond that they depend upon the charity the community sees fit to dispense to them. It must be the experience of all honourable members, even those opposite, to have directed constituents to the offices of charitable organisations.

A different standard is adopted by the community and governments to the problems of chronic poverty and the victims of economic disaster to that which is evident at times of major natural disasters such as bushfires, floods cyclones, et cetera. This was clearly evident during the term of office of the Fraser Government. It exemplified perfectly the response of a conservative mentality to the plight of the poor. At best, the response of the conservative side of politics to the plight of the unemployed can only be described as paternalistic. During the period of office of the Liberal-National Party coalition the number of Australians living in poverty increased to approximately 2 1/2 million. For ideological reasons it is impossible for the poor, the unemployed and the oppressed to be given justice when conservative politics dominate in government. At best they can only be given handouts. If being accorded justice is interpreted as being assured an equitable share in the distribution of the nation's goods and services, a right to an equal share in the power over the decision making process, to be given equal treatment under the law and the right to being treated with dignity then the poor in Australia miss out. We live in a society which enshrines the value of self-interest.

As I indicated, this different standard is, generally speaking, observed only at times of dramatic and sudden crisis. At other times the prevailing social ethos-a conservative ethos-creates its victims and then blames them. The spoils of the conservative society go to the victors. They receive the plaudits as well as the benefits. At best the losers must be satisfied with the crumbs. This is the ideology of the present Opposition. As was so clearly demonstrated by the seven years of Fraserism it is an ideology of divisiveness and conflict. It is a sad commentary on such a system that its logic imposes limits upon the degree of consensus that is possible.

I applaud the recent efforts of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to provide representatives of the major competing decision makers in our system with the opportunity to sit down together and listen to the points of view of others in a non-confrontionist situation. This was a unique occasion. The challenge, as I see it, is for all those concerned with the future of this nation to try to achieve the very best for all in this, a grossly imperfect system. I draw the attention of the House to the serious effects of the current economic depression upon regional and provincial centres in this country.

I make specific reference to the state of manufacturing industry and the effects of the downturn in manufacturing industry in provincial centres. In my region of Ballarat the percentage of the work force employed in manufacturing industry fell from 27.9 per cent in 1971 to 20.3 per cent in 1981. I can only guess that today the percentage would be even lower. At the end of March 1981 the percentage of people in Ballarat registered for jobs with the Commonwealth Employment Service was 9.5 per cent. The figure released by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) at the National Economic Summit Conference was 15.05 per cent. In Maryborough, another centre in my electorate, the figure was 17.5 per cent. They are dramatic, horrendous figures in anyone's language.

The need for protection for manufacturing industry in these centres and those similar to them around Australia should be patently obvious. But it is also to be hoped that the necessary incentives for these centres to develop alternative industries such as those of high technology and tourism will be fostered. It certainly was not the interest of the previous Government. I place great value on the quality of life and the significance to Australia of these great centres outside metropolitan areas. There is a will to ensure that the quality of life in these centres is maintained. I am particularly proud of the people in my electorate, as I am sure others are in similar electorates, who are willing to gather facts about our communities, their problems and their great strengths, and to co-operate in a drive to build a sound future for all those who live there. Hopefully a government motivated by more genuine concern for all Australians will give substantial recognition to the needs of these regional areas so that the attainment of a sound basis for a prosperous future might be achieved.

These Bills before us tonight are necessary for the maintenance of Government activity. There is no great controversy in the House about their necessity and their immediate passage. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Supply Bills but tonight I think I should draw attention to one or two of the facts of economic life in Australia that have arisen in the past few months. We have become used to seeing a government composed of Ministers who, frankly, are inept, who do not know what they are about and who demonstrate it every day. To add to that, I point to the election campaign in which it seemed that the general theme of the Australian Labor Party was to wander around the nation and promise anything at all. It promised tax cuts and tomorrow we are to get tax rises. We were promised jobs and we get more unemployment. We were promised assistance to the iron and steel industry and nothing has happened. There is a continuing saga of disinterest and appalling administration. I say that to set the general parameters of what has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the newspapers, tomorrow we face a hard mini-Budget. During the election campaign all we heard about was expansionary budgets. We heard talk of Liberals being contractionists and nasty people who believe in management of the money supply and the like. We were urged by the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to throw away our pocket computers and spend it up with expansionary budgets. Inevitably that leads only to big deficits, and we have aheard a lot about the deficit. But what we have heard is nothing compared with the size of the deficit we will hear about in the Budget for 1983-84, not to mention the ones after that , if the Government is to accommodate anywhere near the number of programs that were put forward in the last election campaign speeches. It is because of that that I want to warn the House, and those who are interested in the debate, of the enormous difficulties that confront deficit financing in Australia. It is no good saying that $10 billion is neither here nor there-try $12 billion. Those are figures that we will hear not only this year but next year in the belief that such a deficit will work wonders and will be easily handled.

There is no doubt that from the current base the size of the deficit projected by the Government will produce a one per cent or 2 per cent growth in the coming year. But that growth will be without a doubt to the benefit of big government. It will be to the benefit of the public sector - the sector supported by a socialist program. But it is in the private sector where the jobs will be found. Three-quarters of all employment is in the private sector. If the Government aims now to stimulate the public sector--

TALK.START.PARA: —The private sector is not doing very well at the moment.
—It might be all right in the honourable member's area but I do not think it would be. If the Government aims now to stimulate the public sector-
—The private sector is not doing much good now, is it?

—It will do a darned sight worse if the Government listens to talk about massive deficits, high interest rates and stimulating the public sector at the cost of the private sector. If that happens we will hear nothing in the next 18 months about capital investment, job creation or the general development of the nation. Unless the private sector is healthy and encouraged with incentives, there is no way that investment will take place in this nation. Without incentives, without rewards, there is no way that capital will be invested. Without the investment of capital there will be no development in growth, in jobs or the nation as a whole. Because of that I warn the Government that reliance upon massive Government spending for the public sector will inevitably lead, in a period of 18 months, to a situation in which the Government will have to distort the economic system to add unnecessary rewards at that point to get the private sector going again. Of course, that in itself brings about some of the disliked aspects of reward and incentive that have been built into the system over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: I hear that the Government is to cut out rural concessions, industry concessions, investment allowances and the like. This inevitably will lead to less interest in those areas, less development and fewer jobs. There is no doubt that it will add to the problem of unemployment. That brings me to the question of wages policy. What will the Government do? Today in Question Time we heard a great amount of conflict between what the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and, indeed, what the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said. There seems to be conflict as to what catch-up means . There seems to be some conflict as to what real wages mean and what current cost wages mean. While that confusion continues we are unlikely to see the sort of atmosphere that is required for wage restraint and a cooling of costs to bring back industry in this nation to a competitive stance. Until we do that there is no way that industry can attempt to put its full strength to the wheel. Capital deserves its return.

I turn from that to one other aspect which I think has been completely overlooked in the past two weeks-the question of the management of currency and the management of the exchange rates in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—The honourable member probably has not heard of these things but they are vitally important to the development of the nation. Unless there is a sense of belief in the currency value and the exchange rates of this nation, we will not get the sort of capital investment or capital flow to this country that is required for its development. Indeed, anybody who looked at the balance of payments figures that came out only a matter of weeks ago would realise the enormous requirement to have a high level of foreign investment, particularly capital inflow, in the next 18 months if the Government is to achieve anywhere near the number of programs that it talks about and keep interest rates at reasonable levels.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me back to the question of what the Government said when it came to office. We will recall the Prime Minister's saying: 'We will not devaluate'. As a consequence of substantial capital movement, the Government inevitably did devalue. That was followed in the past few weeks by a very significant inflow of money back into Australia-so much so that the money markets in Australia today are flush. At least $2 billion to $3 billion is floating around the money markets, forcing down interest rates, which I heard one Minister claim this morning was totally a result of action by the Government. Probably he is not aware that yesterday and today there was a sizeable tightening in rates due to the fact that some of that money has already gone. The reason is that upward adjustment in currency and exchange rates has been too rapid.

The likelihood of the mini-Budget, the outcomes of which are still uncertain, and the devaluation has caused people to take the profits that are inevitably there. Not only that but also the very high differential in interest rates between Australia and other parts of the world are rewarding and consequently people have taken advantage of the devaluation which the Government initiated to take the profits in those situations. That leads to a fairly brittle relationship in the money market. I understand that situation is compounded by the calling of tenders tomorrow of something like $1,400m in government securities. I have no doubt that, in a market which has been flush and in which the demand for capital is substantially reduced, because of the level of economic activity, this can be achieved. It has to be achieved because in the month of March the money supply went over 12 per cent.

The Government does not have any regard these days for money supply problems, but that is neither here nor there. It is part of the easy growth factors which are combined with big deficits and an attempt by the Government to harvest the money at reasonable rates. The Government can be assured that the money system will not fall for that sort of play unless we have a creditable currency with a believable exchange rate tied in to a government policy which is consistent with and acting in a direction which encourages private investment, then we will not get the sort of money coming to the nation that we can spot up in government tenders. It will be there for the Government to take up in those huge deficits which it will be confronting not only this year but also in the following year. Because of that I urge that some consideration be given to the whole area of the management of exchange rates and the approach to foreign investment.

As I said earlier, the balance of payments is the critical factor for Australia in the next two years. If that is not believed in terms of Australia's performance, then the very substantial balance of trade deficit that is likely to be the case, with doubtful commodity prices, the very severe drought and a very severe case of non-competitive industries in this nation, will substantially lead to the undermining of the exchange rate. Non-belief in that will lead to the major suppliers of capital to this nation not coming to the party. As a consequence of that there will be an inevitable rise in interest rates and the inevitable fall-off in business interest leading to a total lack of interest from the private sector in the longer term.

I have addressed my remarks in contemporary terms. I have heard in the last two days and in Question Time today that the future looks bright. Predicting to 1984 is an extremely hazardous business. There is no doubt that the American economy is in a phase of uplift at the moment. Commodity prices are rising right across the board but there is no doubt also that the American Administration will do the best it can in 1984 to maintain business activity and try to restrain interest rates. While this is occurring the Government should look at the question of the enormous surplus capacity in the United States and in the European Economic Community. The Government should look at the ability of those companies and corporations in those areas to produce at a more competitive price level than we can compete against. This is the salient point to Australia. We must make our industries competitive in terms of costs. Undoubtedly the greatest component of cost in the Australian manufacturing sector is wages. This brings me to the question of how stable and how far one can believe in the current Government's ability to restrain wages and how far one can believe in any way in this alleged social contract between the Austraian Council of Trade Unions and the current Government. It is the competitiveness and the productivity that will carry the nation through 1984.

Failure to meet the criteria will inevitably plunge the Australian foreign investment scene into the sort of crisis which we had in 1974. We can all remember that. The banks of this nation ran to the Reserve Bank of Australia for vast amounts of money to bale them out. Interest rates in those areas went to over 25 per cent-sometimes to 100 per cent-just to fund the short term difficulties resulting from the huge imbalance in the balance of payments. These times will return without a doubt unless the Government is prepared to pay some attention to currency and the reserve accounts. As I said before, the Oppostion will be supporting the Supply Bills. We look forward to the delivery of an economic statement tomorrow which we hope will be in the best interests of Australia and not in the best interests of the left wing ideologists of the socialist parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had intended to say a few words about how the Government is planning its economic strategy and also something about the Supply Bills, but firstly I want to reply to some of the comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). He tried to claim that the accusations made against him regarding the dishonest behaviour of failing to announce the true extent of the deficit were not correct . In a very convoluted way he tried to tell us that we were going back on our policies, that our policies were not expansionary but contractionary, and that the savings that we are predicting will bring down the deficit from $9.6 billion to $8.5 billion would have occurred anyway. That is a contradiction to start with. On the one hand he is saying, 'Why are you not sticking to your policies and being expansionary?' And on the other hand he is saying, 'If you intend to reduce the deficit that is not a responsible action on your part'. That happens to be something that occurred as a result of his policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me illustrate the distinction between an expansionary Budget and a contractionary Budget because obviously the honourable member is not aware of that distinction. He seems to think that if one spends more money that automatically it is an expansionary Budget and that if one restricts money automatically that is a contractionary Budget. That is dogmatic, simple monetarism of the most simplistic kind. The fact is that a government can have a big deficit Budget and be contractionary and, conversely, a government can have a balanced Budget and be expansionary. It depends on how a government is prepared to balance its revenue income and expenditure. This is the point which seems to totally escape the logic of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He seems to think that we will fall for the most simplistic economic theories that he proposes and which he seems incapable of getting out of in terms of his economic framework.

It is very possible to have a deficit Budget that is contractionary if the spending in that Budget is such that it does not create employment and that it does not give money to people who spend that money in stimulating the economy; in other words, the persons who save that money, those who are already well off. The former Government increased expenditure in a desperate attempt to win an election after saying, of course, that it would have a very small deficit Budget . It increased the Budget deficit and threw money around and then tried to tell us that this was a clearly and genuinely expansionary Budget. Most of that money was thrown about in programs which did not benefit the poor people and the low income earners and which, in a majority of cases, did not benefit the middle class. That money in fact benefited its own friends, the wealthy who did not need it. In that context we had a situation in which more money was being spent but there was insufficient expansion of the economy to the point where we had negative growth-after a $4,000m deficit.

So what is the former Treasurer talking about? Can he not understand that a Budget can in fact have a deficit and be contractionary in this way? The former Treasurer tried to tell us that we are contradicting our policies because we are in fact going to stick within reasonable limits in relation to the Budget deficit. But as I have already mentioned, the converse also applies. An expansionary Budget deficit can be responsible. This can be achieved if we cut out the fat, expenditure that does not benefit people, create jobs or stimulate the economy. If we replace those expenditures with spending which will create jobs and stimulate the economy and consumption we will then have expansion without going overboard in terms of our deficit Budget. So much for the Opposition's claim that in fact we are not going to have an expansionary Budget. Our Budget and our mini-Budget will be expansionary in their impact because they will be sensible and responsible. It is not a matter of throwing about money desperately at the last moment when it looks like we will lose an election. That is not what is on here. We will be adopting a responsible program that is expansionary, will create jobs and at the same time is responsible in terms of the deficit.

The honourable member for Bennelong did not mention another matter which is crucial to our program. The honourable member tried to attack our program by using his totally discredited economic concepts. The honourable member did not mention our prices and incomes policy. This policy is designed in such a way that responsible expansion will give real growth to the economy rather than fuelling inflation. This was not even mentioned by the former Treasurer in his dishonest attempt to save himself from embarrassment by trying to tell us that he was not responsible for that figure.

Let me say something about his comments on that figure. The honourable member tried to tell us that in fact the estimate was based on a growth rate of half a per cent and that the revised estimate now puts the growth rate at 2.7 per cent. Therefore, according to him, there would be a saving and the figure would go down to $8.5 billion. But this does not exonerate him at all because the fact is that he gave the Australian people the figure of $6 billion. He knew at the time that the figure would be much more than that. The fact that the growth rate has changed and that the estimate can be changed does not exonerate the former Treasurer from the fact that he misled the Australian people and misled the Australian Labor Party when it was framing its policies in relation to the Budget deficit. This man came into this House and tried to justify what is unjustifiable; namely, that he misled the Parliament and the people in relation to these matters. He continues to attempt to justify his actions by trying to feed to us, as though we are all fools, simplistic economic theory based on monetarist concepts.

Let me say also that we believe in an expansionary program which is going to create jobs. Employment is our concern. Did the former Treasurer mention his concern about employment? Was there any concern? Has there ever been any concern from him about employment? During the time he was the Treasurer did he express any concern about employment? He got up to make speeches and we kept saying time after time that the monetarist strategy was not working, that is was creating more and more unemployment. What was he saying to this House? He was saying: 'Oh , no, it is not our intention to create unemployment'. But what was he saying privately to his advisers? He was saying privately-this is part of the monetarist theory-that unemployment had to rise and rise so that inflation could be brought under control. As a consequence of these policies, inflation was not brought under control and unemployment went through the roof. Now this honourable gentleman has the gall to try to tell us what are the proper prescriptions for a responsible economic strategy.

Look, we are going to have a huge task in turning around the unemployment situation. Nobody denies that. We are going to have a huge task because of what was done by the previous Government. But we are determined to do it and we are going to need assistance from all sectors of this society. What sort of response have we received from the Opposition? Members of the Opposition have tried completely to throw cold water on the achievements of the National Economic Summit Conference. In fact they have tried to divide the community after we made this enormous effort to bring it together and tried to achieve some kind of harmony and growth in the economy. These are the sorts of tactics to which they have resorted; they are the sorts of tactics in which they believe.

I put it to the House that our strategy can work. It is a coherent and responsible strategy, notwithstanding the remarks of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. In fact, there is a respected school of economic thought which has considered these questions in a clear way. I refer to the Keynesian expansionist model which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition does not seem to understand and fails to comprehend in any way. The honourable member seems to have simply studied one school of economic thought and assumed that that is the totality of what exists in terms of a macro economic strategy.

In conclusion, let me say that we will not allow the debate to be turned in the way in which the honourable gentleman has tried to turn it; that is, away from the real issues, away from the strategy that we are determined to pursue in order to create jobs and increase the standards of living of the Australian people. If these attempts persist it will be to his discredit because his policies and the policies of the previous Government, which we are determined to redress, have brought us to the chaotic situation that we are in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may borrow the current million dollar phrase, the Summit continues. Yesterday the Executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions met and made a few decisions that will ensure that, if nothing else, the National Economic Summit Conference is buried. Yesterday the union movement threw wide open whatever results might have come from the Economic Summit. That action brought to an abrupt and total end any semblance of consensus that there might have been.

SPEECH.PARA: The decisions that were made yesterday by the ACTU executive threatens even the prices and incomes accord itself. That is bad enough, but what the ACTU is now proposing is even worse. Yet we are being told in this million dollar campaign that the Summit continues. Government policy has advocated for this year a three to four per cent rise in incomes with no catch-up, and full indexation next year . We see now that the ACTU's policy is for full indexation from March of this year and that an immediate start be made on the 9.1 per cent catch-up. If that does not signal the end of the Summit, I do not know what does. The difference between the Government's policy and the ACTU's stance is more than enough to sink any fragile chance there may have been of economic recovery in this country .

At this stage it is probably a good thing to consider the scenarios that were presented by the Government at the Economic Summit. Such a consideration is very illuminating. The Government would have us believe that there is some broad agreement for the adoption of scenario A. As I have pointed out on earlier occasions, that scenario still leaves us with an unemployment rate of 9.7 per cent at the end of 1985-86. All the unemployed have to look forward to in this country under this Government in the life of this Parliament is an unemployment rate of 9.7 per cent.

I ask honourable members to consider scenario B. It has been described as the ACTU's ambit claim. I rather suspect that what the ACTU decided yesterday at its executive meeting goes beyond even the projections contained in scenario B. It provides for a 9.9 per cent wages movement in the 1982-83 financial year; 17.2 per cent in 1983-84; 15.6 per cent in 1984-85; and 16.6 per cent in 1985-86. What is the Government's own projection for the inflation rate under the sorts of policies which the ACTU would seek to follow? The Government projects inflation rates under those policies of 13 per cent in 1983-84; 13.8 per cent in 1984-85; and 13.4 per cent in 1985-86. The interesting thing that has emerged from the Summit is that the figures that the Government itself has made available to the Australian public and this Parliament-although I point out that they were not given to this Parliament-provide a basis that enables us to make the sorts of projections that might otherwise not have been possible.

The Government and the ACTU have condemned themselves out of their own mouths- from their own figures. I refer to the figures that have been released by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), which we can only assume have some credibility. The Government's position is in stark contrast to that of the Opposition, as is appropriate. It has been made clear in this House by Opposition spokesman over the course of the last few weeks that we much prefer the projections of scenario C. It would have allowed for inflation to fall to 2 per cent in 1984-85, 3.7 per cent in 1985-86, and for wage increases of 6 per cent and 8.2 per cent respectively in those years. It also projected an unemployment figure of 8.7 per cent by 1985-86, which is a somewhat better projection than that which will apply under the ACTU's demands as outlined in scenario B.

This Government came to power on the basis of offering a better deal. It came to power on the basis of consultation, as opposed to what it referred to as the confrontationist approach taken by the previous Government. It came to power on a platform of consensus. The Government tried that approach. It would be hard to find anything that has been so conspicuously unsuccessful and that has collapsed so quickly as has the consensus that this Government offered the Australian nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have only had 10 weeks. Give us a bit of time. You had seven years .

—It has collapsed already. The point I make is that despite the consensus-as the Government called it at the Summit-that was achieved, despite the agreement and the communique, within a month of the Summit the ACTU has walked away from it and totally rejected the communique. Where does the Government go from here? I repeat that million dollar phrase, the Summit continues. It continues, I suggest, into oblivion.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning we had the ignominious picture of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) trying hard to hold it all together. The reality is that he has no more control of, or influence over, the trade union movement than did the previous Government . In fact, if what emerged yesterday is any indication, he might have even less influence or control. Despite the different approach that he has been touting around the country over the last so many months, he has failed dismally. Out there in the real world-in the world of the Daily Mirror that the work force of this country reads-the dogs are barking that there will be a $30 wage rise this year. Where is the adherence to the Summit communique? Where is the consensus? I ask honourable members: Is the Summit continuing?

It has been made fairly clear to all those who are prepared to see that there is a very deliberate and positive nexus between wage rises and economic growth. It was put more than clearly by many at the Economic Summit. Yet it has been thrown onto the rocks of oblivion by the ACTU. That will obviously have to be accepted by the Government. I want to draw attention to the economic survey of Australia by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which was released in January. It highlighted the part that unrealistic wage rises have played in contributing to Australia's present economic recession. The survey pointed out that in the period between the last war and the early 1970s, there were no significant changes in real wages relative to productivity. However, in 1974-75 there was a marked increase in real unit labour costs and a drop in the share of profits to gross domestic product from over 16 per cent in 1973 to a little more than 12 per cent 12 months later. In the words of the former Leader of the Opposition, the present Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden), ' blind Freddy' knows what happened to the economy over that period as a result of those sorts of effects.

What does the ACTU's decision, signalling the collapse of the Summit, mean for economic management in this country? What I have already said to the House indicates what effect it will have on wages, the consumer price index and unemployment. I would like for a moment to consider what might happen to interest rates because interest rates are a fairly fundamental indicator in our economy. They affect not only business profitability and the capacity of business to create employment and to provide jobs but also the housing sector and a range of other areas.

It is clear that experience in recent years has shown over and over again that inflationary growth of money leads to higher interest rates. That lesson has been learnt yet again in the past 18 months in the United States. Beginning in January 1982 there was a very sharp slow-down in money-growth that lasted until July. During that time interest rates in the United States fell very sharply. A similar thing happened in this country. There is no doubt that rapid money growth leads to higher interest rates. A loose monetary policy, with its inflationary implications, leads to higher interest rates whereas a tight monetary policy brings about lower interest rates. One of the things that concerns me is that not only is this going on in the United States but it is also going on around the world. A monetary explosion is taking place, which will provide an inflationary economic boost to activity this year and probably next year. I do not believe it is soundly based; it is based on an improper and unjustified injection of funds into world economies. We face a situation where the world's major economies will be expanding simultaneously just as over the last couple of years they have all been contracting simultaneously.

Let us look at some of the money supply figures and, in the light of experience , try to understand what they might mean for the world economy and for us here in Australia. In the United States in the year ended March 1983 there was a 10.9 per cent growth in the money supply whereas in the 12-month period ended June 1982 it was only 5.3 per cent. In France in the year ended November 1982 it was 12 per cent as against 14 per cent in the year to June. It has been reduced in France as a result of the turnaround in the policies of the socialist Mitterrand Government. It realised, as this Government will be forced to realise, that wild and uncontrolled expansion of the economy, government sourced, is not the answer . In West Germany the growth in the money supply in the year ended February 1982 was 10 per cent whereas it was 4 per cent in the year to June 1982. In Italy it was 15.1 per cent as against 11 per cent; in Canada 11 per cent as against 2.5 per cent; and, even in Switzerland, it was 11 per cent as against 4.8 per cent. In Britain where, I suspect, a little pump priming might have been going on prior to the coming election, in the year to February 1983 growth in the money supply ran out to 11 per cent as compared with 6.5 per cent in the earlier period.

This Government would lead Australia down the same track of loose, irresponsible monetary policy. How will interest rates be contained in such circumstances? How will inflation be controlled under a policy of that type? I point out to the House-I think it is a pretty fundamental statement-that as a result of action taken by the Australian Council of Trade Unions over the last couple of days and as a result of the collapse of just about everything in this Government's control since the Summit, it is clear beyond any shadow of a doubt that by the time we get to the next election whenever that might be held-I say that deliberately-things economically in this country will be bad. The previous Government will be blamed whether the next election is held two or three years down the track. Honourable members opposite will walk around blaming the previous Government.

We need to be clear about a few things. What is happening in this economy is occurring under the direction of this Government. The 'accommodating' money supply policy that is being put in place now and which will lead to an expansion in inflation and an increase in interest rates in this country is the policy of the Hawke Government. It is the Keating Treasury line. It is not the line of the previous Government or the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) who is the previous Treasurer; it is the deliberate policy of this Government. If this country is in economic chaos two or three years down the track it will be as a result of the policies being put in place by this Government now-the sorts of policies that we will probably hear tomorrow night in the Government's economic statement. Who is in control of the economy now? Is it the Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are.

—I thank the honourable member for Canberra for her interjection. As a result of deliberative action by the Australian Council of Trade Unions yesterday concerning the wage push-wage explosion obviously will follow-it is clear that whoever is in control it is not the Government. But the Government is responsible. The Government has not delivered to the Australian people in line with the commitments and the promises that it made prior to 5 March. The Government will not be able to turn around and blame the Opposition for the economic chaos that will exist in 1985, 1986 or whenever it chooses to go to the polls. I notice that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) is making a brief return to the Opposition benches. I hope he will return here after the next election.
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair.

—We are in the process of finding out what are the Government's priorities. Tomorrow night will probably show us in clearer terms what are the Government's priorities. It is those priorities that will determine the shape of this economy two or three years down the track. It is on those priorities and policies that this Government will have to stand up and be counted when it faces the people next time around. There is no continuation of policies. There is a clear-cut break in policy decision making and in priorities in this country. I concluded simply by saying that what this Government is putting into place and the way in which it is allowing itself to be pushed around by the trade union movement is no recipe for the recovery in this economy. It is no recipe for growth. It is, in fact, a recipe for disaster for which this Government and this Government alone, will stand accountable to the people the next time we go to the polls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that offering from the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) I want to inject a positive note into this debate and to talk about hope rather than about the failures of the previous Government. In passing , I want to say what a depressing and miserable offering it was from the honourable member for Hume. He attacked the achievements of the National Economic Summit Conference and the policies of the new Government. For heaven's sake, this Government has been in office for only 10 weeks yet the honourable member for Hume talked down the economy and talked down every positive measure that the new Government is adopting in its efforts to bring national recovery to this country. It is no wonder that an Opposition so decimated in its ranks and so bereft of talent should promote such a person as the honourable member for Hume to its front benches.

SPEECH.PARA: I enter the debate this evening particularly to commend the new Government's determination to arrest the frightening growth in unemployment which has been particularly evident among young people. This new Government's commitment to provide jobs for young people, to youth training and community works programs deserves the full support of every Australian. As these new programs are being planned the Government will naturally be looking at experiences elsewhere in this field.

In this regard I bring to the attention of the House the successful record of the California Conservation Corps in the United States of America, or the CCC, which was created in July 1976 for a trial period of five years. It was modelled on Roosevelt's Civilian Construction Corps of the 1930s, with one major exception in that it involves women as well as men. In 1980 its life was extended until 1985. It could well serve as a model for Australia. In 1981 the Corps employed an average of 1,758 people aged between 18 years and 23 years in natural resource conservation and emergency service work. New members attend three weeks of intensive training at a central academy and then go on to work at one of 24 centres throughout the state. Twenty-two of these are residential. A typical day for the Corps starts at 6 a.m., with members arriving at project sites by 8 a.m. They usually work a 40-hour week, although these hours are extended during flood and fire emergencies. Members are also required to take part in planned evening activities which include career development courses and literacy classes.

The CCC undertakes projects that benefit the community and provide skills training for members. Typical projects under the program include developing parks, clearing trails and streams, restoring historic sites, protecting and improving wildlife habitats, constructing access areas for the disabled, fabricating and installing solar energy panels on State facilities and conducting energy conservation audits which result in the reduction of energy use at state facilities. Sponsors of projects, usually government agencies, provide technical supervision and materials for the projects while the CCC provides the labour. The term of service for members of the Corps is one year, although they are free to leave at any time. Members earn minimum wage rates and they pay $US35 a week for their keep.

In 1981 the Corps carried out 3.2 million hours of public service conservation work in the state of California. Its activities in 1981 included the Medfly operations in which over 1,000 members assisted in combating outbreaks of Mediterranean fruit fly in the citrus orchards in that state. The activities also included fire fighting, in which CCC crews, under expert supervision, fought over 100 forest and grass fires. They also dealt with an oil spill clean- up and contributed 5,000 hours to contain the pollution of a number of waterways . Members of the Corps also participated in reafforestation work, planting in that year 3 million trees, mostly of commercial species, and growing seedlings in their own nurseries. In addition the Corps cleared streams, opened up spawning areas for fish, restored rearing ponds and renovated fish hatcheries. They also planted natural vegetation on stream banks to prevent soil erosion. Over 400,000 hours were devoted to the conservation and development of parks and recreational areas across the state. During 1981, the International Year of Disabled Persons, the CCC was involved in projects providing access to parks for persons with disabilities.

Another activity in 1981 involved over 100,000 hours work on path and trail construction in national parks. Several environmental camping grounds, which afford campers a wilderness experience with little impact on the surrounding environment, were established by the Corps. In addition the Corps undertook a variety of soil and water conservation projects. It also runs an energy conservation program, providing specialised on-the-job training for its members. Through the program it designs, fabricates and installs solar water-heating systems. The Corps also carries out energy audits on state buildings to assess energy loss, and suggests remedial measures in those buildings.

In the same year over half a million hours were devoted to construction and restoration work at historic sites and various local communities. A variety of search and rescue missions were also performed in co-operation with state and local authorities. As I mentioned earlier, in 1981 the participants averaged 1, 758. Of that number 31 per cent were women. Of the total, 149-almost 8 per cent- were disabled persons. Because 39 per cent of the enrolment in the scheme had not completed high school the Corps placed particular emphasis on evening activities to improve literacy, with considerable success. In addition, it has developed its own career program, emphasising career information and vocational guidance, a system to advise members of jobs as they become available and a system which provides liaison between Corps members and potential employers. Again the career program has met with considerable success.

The California Conservation Corps clearly does not suit all young people and not all of its programs would suit Australian conditions. It is, however, a system which has operated successfully in California since 1976. The scheme has been extended by the Government of that state until 1985 because of that success . It has certainly done a great deal for the communities in that state. Most importantly, it has given many young people a start-people who otherwise would not have had a start. I commend the scheme as an example and as a possible model for the community works programs which I trust will be announced tomorrow evening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Dawkins) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 12 May, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Dawkins) read a third time.

That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
