DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this Bill which has a twofold purpose: Firstly, to remedy certain technical deficiencies in the original Act which has been identified by the Attorney-General's Department; and secondly, to take the opportunity, whilst that is being done, to include within the taxation base for the purposes of determining tax sharing and health grant entitlements, certain revenue measures which have added to the taxation collections of the Commonwealth which have been adopted by the Commonwealth since the original legislation was brought into being. It is my understanding that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has estimated that about $600m of income tax collections in 1981-82 might not be included under the existing definition, and in those circumstances, if there is any real risk of that occurring, there is a clear need for that possible deficiency to be put right.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking very briefly to this measure-because its being a non-contentious one, it is obviously in the interests of the business of the House that it be passed through the House speedily-I take the opportunity of saying that although it is a revenue sharing measure, it touches upon the new health arrangements that were brought into operation by the former Government in 1981. Those arrangements have been the subject of some considerable political debate and difference of opinion not only in this House but also around Australia. I take the opportunity of saying that the Liberal Party and the National Party for their part, believe very strongly that the changes that were made have brought to health administration around Australia a situation in which those who should be discharging responsibilities at a State level and discharging greater responsibilities in the health area, are in fact doing so. I believe that the policy that was brought in, and is given effect to by the principal Act now under discussion, has meant that State health administrations all around Australia have had to look to their real responsibilities. They have had to face the necessity for sensible rationalisation of health services, and this represents one of the more practical implementations of the policy of federalism , which is very much supported by the Opposition parties.

As regards the new Government and the attitude of the Australian Labor Party, this is one of those areas in which no doubt there will be very significant differences of view and differences in debate if it becomes the intention and the practice of the new Labor Administration to try to dismantle those arrangements which were brought in. I think that they are more efficient arrangements than the ones that they replaced. I do not believe that all wisdom in health administration can ever reside in Canberra. I do not believe that we should have a situation in which the differing health needs of different parts of Australia should be divorced from the decision making processes scattered around the country. I believe that the Government of New South Wales is far better able to decide the health priorities of New South Wales, provided that it , in turn, does that in an appropriately decentralised fashion.

Perhaps in saying that-as this is a Bill about revenue sharing and, therefore, about federalism-I should say that sometimes when we talk about decentralisation of government, we simply talk about transferring power from the central government to the State governments and we forget a very obvious fact of political life in Australia, whoever is in power at a State level, that some of the most centralist governments in Australia are State governments. One can find numerous examples all around Australia of where State governments, of both political persuasions, have failed over the years to decentralise administration and to decentralise services within their own States. I think that we should talk more about decentralisation of power so far as the whole of Australia is concerned, and not talk, in a rather naked term, of State rights versus federal rights. It is more the positive objective of achieving a greater decentralisation of power. People who have followed the education systems of the more populous States of Australia and those who have followed the health services of all of the States of Australia will know better than I just how centralised is the administration of many of those services in the different States of Australia.

So, the Fraser Government, in giving effect to its policy of devolving power and decision making responsibility to a much greater extent in the health care area, was giving effect to this belief that there should be, as far as practicable, the maximum amount of decentralisation of power, not only as between the national government and State governments but also within individual State areas. As I said, this is a necessary machinery measure. In the interests of proper despatch of the business of the House, there is no point in my saying anything further about it. The Opposition will support the measure and will co- operate in providing a very speedy passage for it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Dr Blewett) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three elements in this Bill. The first one about which I shall speak is the change in the authority to revoke domiciliary nursing care benefit to allow non-medical delegates of the Director- General of the Department of Health to act on non-medical matters. That is quite a sensible provision. A lot of cases of revocation of domiciliary nursing care benefit rely on non-medical issues and currently a medical practitioner is required to sign those instruments, and it is perfectly sensible that non- medical people should be allowed to sign them in cases in which the medical involvement is not necessary. It will still be necessary in the case of medical matters for a medical practitioner to sign them, and the Opposition supports this change.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area of change in the Bill is in the arrangements for the payments of nursing home benefits. With nursing home benefits-we are talking about the private nursing homes-we are talking about a system of price control that has gone on since 1973 and which is most unsatisfactory. I do not claim any particular merit on the part of either party in this. I think that the proposals were originally developed during the period of the McMahon Government; they were implemented originally by the Whitlam Government; they were continued during the period of the Fraser Government; and during my period as Minister for Health, I made it absolutely clear that the Government felt that they were most unsatisfactory and that something ought to be done about them.

The provisions in this Bill merely mean that there is a proper legal basis to be provided for the administration of this unsatisfactory policy following court cases that have thrown the legal support for the existing methods of the administration of the policy into doubt. If we are looking at the provisions as an interim measure which will make this very bad system work until it is fixed up, the Opposition supports them. We note that the principles to be applied by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in the application of this policy are to be gazetted and will be subjected to disallowance by Parliament. Given the anti- private enterprise bias of this Government, we will be watching very closely to see what principles are gazetted and to see that they are reasonable, because obviously the nature of the principles to be used will be the critical factor in the application of these amendments or the amended Bill. I give notice to the Government that I will be watching that area very closely to ensure that it follows the principles that have generally been followed in the past, that the general intention as stated by the Minister in this Bill is followed and that the principles are not used as some means of putting a squeeze on the private nursing home proprietors.

We also note the Minister's stated intention in the second reading speech to replace the deficit financing system of nursing homes-that is, for the voluntary nursing homes generally run by charitable organisations, and the nursing home benefits which are provided to the private for profit nursing homes-with program grants paid to the nursing homes. In other words, in the place of a deficit financing system for voluntary bodies, in the place of benefits provided on a patient basis to the private for profit nursing homes, we are told that in the future we will have a program grant system in which there will be a program grant paid to the nursing homes. Again, given the anti-private enterprise views of the Government, and its natural suspicion of private nursing homes-and also, incidentally, of private hospitals-we will be examining very closely the nature of this proposal when it is defined. But for the moment we are looking at something which is an interim measure to patch up a thoroughly bad system in the interim before something, we hope better, comes along. So the Opposition supports these proposals.

In the third area covered by the Bill we come to an area of some difficulty. We are talking here about the pharmaceutical benefits declaration and changes in the pharmaceutical benefits declaration. The origin of the pharmaceutical benefits declaration was a concession to health care card holders and pensioners without pensioner health benefit cards. Shortly after I became Minister for Health, after discussions with the pharmaceutical profession, in particular with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, the Government introduced in the Budget of last year a $2 medicine scheme for people with health care cards and pensioners without PHB cards, which enabled them to get medicines at $2 instead of the standard $4 for general patients. A distinction had to be made between those persons entitled to free medicines on PHB cards and those persons entitled to the $2 concession.

The first thing that we thought might occur was that the doctors might make this distinction for us because, after all, they put the numbers on the old PHB prescriptions and that was the obvious thing to do. But the trouble was that the doctors could not be required to do this. Indeed, doctors could not be required constitutionally to do anything. They could write football pool numbers on the prescription forms if they wished to and there was no redress on the part of the Government if they did. Also, there was another principle which was important- beneficiaries of a public benefit provided by the taxpayer ought to be asked to demonstrate their entitlement. In other words, if a person is to get a concession from the taxpayer of $4 or $2 each time that person fronted up for medicine at a concessional rate, that person ought to demonstrate his entitlement in the same way as that person would have to show his pension card if he wanted to get on a bus at a concession or free rate or get into a picture show more cheaply, or whatever. We introduced, therefore, this pharmaceutical benefits declaration. Thereafter ensued one of the most unhappy periods I had as Minister for Health. The administrative arrangements introduced for this procedure, although now a matter of history, are a matter of very painful history to me and the pharmaceutical profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not over that painful period yet.

—No. It is a matter of considerable pain to me because the administrative arrangements made were appallingly clumsy. They were very bad and they caused great pain to pharmacists and obviously they caused me very great distress, and I acknowledge that. Of course the pharmacists, supported by the Opposition, made known their displeasure. I agreed with the pharmacists that the administrative arrangements were clumsily and unnecessarily complex. I agreed with that view from the first moment that I saw the form that was provided for them. I designed an interim form which is simpler than the first form and indicated that I would simplify it further. In my letter to the Pharmacy Guild of Australia before the election I summarised my commitment as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government--
That is, the Fraser Government-

believes that anyone claiming a concession at the expense of the taxpayer should demonstrate their entitlement to that benefit in a manner that can be tested at law. It agrees that the mechanics of the patient declaration introduced on 1 January 1983 were unsatisfactory and has introduced a simplified interim declaration form that is currently being distributed.
That was during the period of the election campaign and before. The letter continues:

The Department of Health, under the Minister's close supervision, is examining options for reducing the pharmacist's workload. These include alternative systems submitted by the Guild, and the possible introduction of a plastic card 'Bankcard' type system (the most desired alternative) for implementation as soon as possible. The ultimate system will still require the beneficiary to substantiate the claim, something that did not occur under the previous system, but there is no reason why this cannot be accomplished in a simple manner. In addition the Government will review all other paperwork in the pharmacy to try to reduce and/or simplify it. Any changes would be discussed in advance with the profession.
I went on to say:

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal would of course be free to consider claims from pharmacists for additional remuneration based on additional work, in accordance with the existing terms of reference of the Tribunal.

That was my commitment to the Pharmacy Guild of Australia before the election. What did the then Opposition, the Australian Labor Party, say? I quote from the policy speech of the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):

One piece of wholly unnecessary red tape which we shall abolish immediately on coming to government is the pharmaceutical declaration form which has been imposed by the Fraser Government on pharmacists, pensioners and the poor.
That is from the Hawke policy speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he do about it?
—We will see. The present Minister for Health, then the shadow Minister, wrote a letter to the Pharmacy Guild stating:

SPEECH.PARA: The pharmaceutical benefits declaration is an unnecessary bureaucratic imposition which will be scrapped by a Labor government. Any required details for identifications purposes will be completed by doctors when they fill out the prescription form.

They are two clear-cut commitments-the first one from the now Prime Minister, the second one from the now Minister for Health. What has actually happened? In the first paragraph of the Mininster's second reading speech he claims to have met this firm and unequivocal election commitment. He said:

This Bill will, among other things, honour an important election commitment to abolish the declaration that pensioners and concessional beneficiaries must sign when they receive pharmaceutical benefits. As honouring this promise involves legislative change, the Government is taking one of the first opportunities in the new Parliament to honour its election pledge.
This is precisely what the Government has done; it has abolished the old declaration but replaced it with a new declaration. I quote again from the Minister's second reading speech:
The new prescription form, will simplify--
Not abolish-
the present complex declaration form in four ways. First, all the required information will be provided on one side of the form.
That is precisely what I said I would do. He continued:
There will be no requirements on the reverse side of the form.
That is also what I said I would do. The Minister continued:
Second, the information for beneficiary status will be simplified, making it easier for beneficiaries and pharmacists, yet still meeting the necessary demands for effective departmental monitoring.
That is what I said was necessary and is what I said I would do. The Minister continued:
Third, a single signature will indicate both receipt of the prescription and claim to free or concessional entitlement.

That is what I said I would do assuming I could get legal support for that from a higher level than I had previously received from the Department of the Attorney-General advisers. The Minister went on:
Fourth, doctors and, if need be, pharmacists, will be encouraged to assist beneficiaries in completing the form.

Note that they will not be required to, in the terms of the Minister's commitment to the Pharmacy Guild, but they will be encouraged to. Here I am talking about the doctors. Of course, in the Minister's commitment to the Pharmacy Guild, the pharmacists were not mentioned. There was no need for them to be encouraged to do anything because the declaration would be abolished. The Minister continued with the critical statement:
However, I would make it clear that responsibility for the accuracy of an entitlement claim rests, as it rightly should, with the beneficiary.

This is a clear breach of an election undertaking. It is one, of course, that is impressed indelibly upon me because one of the main thrusts that this Minister made against me as the then Minister for Health during the election campaign was that I was doing things which he would stop when in Government. He got his Prime Minister to make a commitment in the policy speech of the Labor Party which said that this would be totally abolished. Not only has he failed to abolish it because we still have a declaration-simplified admittedly but along the lines that I was going to do it anyway-we certainly have a breach of the undertaking that doctors would do it, which was his clear undertaking to the pharmacists. To underline that I seek leave to table a photocopy of the current declaration comparing it with the new declaration.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is also some doubt about the legal standing of the use of one signature for both the entitlement and the receipt. If one wants to put them on one side of the prescription form, and the beneficiary is made to sign once to indicate that he is entitled to, and has also received, the benefit a difficulty arises. That was pointed out to me by the Attorney-General's Department and was the basis of its objection to having a single signature. The Department said that two separate Acts were involved. The first was in claiming an entitlement and was done after providing the entitlement number and stating that one was the beneficiary or one's agent. The second, quite separate, act was that of receiving the medicine and stating that it had been received. If the beneficiary happened to be in the chemist shop at the time the medicine was passed over and signed saying that he had received it, at the same time indicating that he was entitled to the benefit, the single signature would fulfil both purposes. But I was advised that to have a form which catered only for that situation was a difficulty because there would be many situations where the person indicating the entitlement would not be present at the time of the receipt of the medicine. That presents a very difficult case.

SPEECH.PARA: But, in response to representations from the Pharmacy Guild, I said that I would go to senior counsel to get an opinion as to whether it was possible to have a single signature on one side of the form in order to simplify it and that I would press that to the ultimate against the original advice. I would certainly have wanted to have done that in order to simplify the task for the pharmacist. The present Minister has accepted the single signature. I question whether senior counsel's advice was obtained as to its being legally satisfactory in supporting the claim for a concessional benefit.

It is quite clear, on the evidence tabled, that the Minister has not met the election commitment that he made to the Pharmacy Guild, a commitment on which he fought a great deal of his election campaign. Members of his party in all marginal seats supported actions by pharmacists to make things uncomfortable for the then Government. That election commitment has not been met. All honourable members in this House who defeated Liberal members-that was part of the process of their defeat-bear a responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly was.

—The honourable member for Petrie, who was opposed in the election by somebody who was a professional pharmacist, has very good reason to remember that. May it be imprinted on his brain also that one of the reasons that he managed to get into this House was on a false commitment that has been dishonoured by this Minister and this Government. It is one of the--
—You ought to talk about telling a lie. You never stop. What are you talking about.
—You know nothing about me.
—I am talking to him over there. I am not talking to you.

—I note that. So honourable members will understand why I feel very strongly about this. I am very surprised indeed that the present Minister is party to this act of deception, because it is not only a breach of a commitment but also a wrapping up of the breach in a way which suggests that it is not a breach. In fact, the very words of the second reading speech are misleading. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will, among other things, honour an important election commitment . . . the Government is taking one of the first opportunities in the new Parliament to honour its election pledge.

All I say is that if this is honour in the lexicon of this Government then honour to it is dishonour. We will be very careful about the small print in anything that it does in the future. It is profoundly disappointing. I would have expected more from this Minister than that. I move as an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill-

That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: whilst not opposing the Bill, the House notes the failure of the Government to fulfill the Prime Minister's policy speech commitment to abolish the Pharmaceutical Benefits Declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with all pharmacists in Australia I welcome the announcement by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) that the complex patient declaration for pharmaceutical benefits is to be abolished. I congratulate the Minister on the speed with which he has moved to redeem the promise that the Australian Labor Party gave before the last election. The amendment made by the National Health Amendment Bill honours a commitment made to pensioners, the unemployed and pharmacists. It will become effective during the sitting-the earliest possible time for this to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: When the previous Minister for Health introduced the new declaration form he explained the introduction by saying that it was necessary to make sure no fraud was perpetrated in the pharmaceutical scheme. He said this despite the fact that there was no evidence of any substantial fraud by either the patients or pharmacists associated with the scheme. The previous Minister's action was a knee-jerk reaction because he had been left to carry the can for the total neglect by previous health Ministers with regard to medical benefits fraud. That is another story.

The pharmaceutical scheme, as the previous Minister well knows, is completely separate and functions in a way different from the medical benefits scheme. The introduction of the more complex patient declaration aroused understandable anger among professional and welfare agencies and pharmacists and their staffs. The declaration was complicated to complete and upset many elderly and migrant patients who had trouble reading it and even more trouble completing it. It carried a warning of a $1,000 fine for false information, which further frightened those unsure of the details required. Responsibility for explaining the declaration fell on the pharmacists or their staff and it was a pretty time consuming practice for them. In my electorate-and I am sure in many electorates throughout Australia-I received many complaints from bewildered patients and angry pharmacists. The pharmacists said that they took a lot of extra time helping patients and so did their staff. They did not mind the time so much, although they believed the form was unnecessary; they wanted to help their clients but what they did mind was soothing nervous people and losing counter sales as they were taking up so much of their time on what should have been a routine affair.

I visited many of the pharmacists in my electorate and I put out a petition requesting the then Government, in the interests of the frail, elderly and less articulate groups, to withdraw the declaration. I was amazed at the speed with which literally hundreds of signatures were collected. Most pharmacists requested multiple copies of the petition, which were then presented to the Parliament. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia wanted the form abolished and was very determined about it. The declaration on the back of the prescription form was impractical, intimidating and confusing. Now that the Minister has abolished that form, the only entitlement information required will be on the front of the new prescription form to allow the pharmacists to determine whether the patient should pay the $2 charge as a health care card or pharmaceutical benefits concession card holder or receive the medication free as a pensioner health benefits card holder.

Prior to the Liberal Government's bureaucratic imposition of the declaration on 1 January 1983, all entitlement information was filled in by the doctor. This Government hopes that all doctors will resume this role and in so doing help to allay the anxiety that the declaration engendered. Where they do not do so the pharmacist will be able to complete it. Many doctors and pharmacists have assured the Minister that they are willing to help in this way and the Government believes that the full support of pharmacists and doctors will be critical to the success of the new scheme. The introduction of the declaration on 1 January was both time consuming and wasteful. I am told that fairly early on, before the new prescription forms were available, every pharmacist had to be issued with a new stamp. That must have cost quite an amount of money. I do not know whether the story is true but it goes that the stamp was so big that it did not fit any of the available stamp pads, so stamp pads had to be made also. This is a promise that was made by the Australian Labor Party in opposition. It is redeemed by Labor at the earliest possible moment in government. That is a far cry from the record of the previous Government whose seven years in office was scattered with broken promises. I congratulate the Minister on the speed with which he has moved to redeem this promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is moving to hear the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) emerge from his time as Minister for Health to tell us of the pain he experienced during that period. To see him emerging from his finest hour professing such pain is indeed a moving experience. He has at least some compensation in knowing that he spread it around the rest of Australia, among pharmacists, pensioners and other beneficiaries. One of the greatest administrative blunders of the previous Government was the introduction, late in the life of that Government, of a pensioner and concessional beneficary declaration which had to be signed by those people when obtaining pharmaceuticals. It was such a complex form that merely to fill it in required almost the powers of endurance of someone who did not need pharmaceutials in the first place. Moreover, the form promised draconian penalties for those who filled it out falsely. This raised considerable fear in the minds of many elderly people. For example, I am aware of numerous cases of elderly ladies in my electorate, who have never done anything illegal in their lives, fearing that they would be comitting a criminal act if they happened to fill the form in wrongly. One of my elderly constituents whom I happened to visit while she was crocheting a doily, told me in all seriousness that she feared she would go to gaol because she thought she had filled in the form incorrectly.

SPEECH.PARA: Such incidents demonstrate what a travesty was this system that we are now to abolish. Quite apart from that, it was an insult to the honest citizens whose integrity was impugned by these forms. Of course, in practice many people were unable or unwilling to fill in the forms themselves. Their family pharmacist had to do it for them. Prior to the election, I was approached by many of my local pharmacists and one of their chief concerns was the patient declaration. Many hours of their working lives were consumed by this fruitless piece of red tape. One pharmacist in particular, who had a large dispensing practice, told me that nearly one quarter of his time was spent helping his clients with their forms and allaying their fears about them. The abolition of the penioner and concessional beneficiary declaration will be the removal of a insult and an inconvenience. I recommend the measure to honourable members.

The honourable member for Mackellar, in his apology for what he did, set out to explain to us the problem which he thought he faced in drawing up an appropriate form. He told us that a distinction had to be drawn between those people who were entitled to a concessional prescription and those who were not. He felt that either the doctors could make the distinction between those who were so entitled or the beneficiaries could be made to demonstrate their entitlement themselves. He said that he did not think that doctors would be suitable people to do this by virtue of the fact that there was not legal compulsion. He even suggested that the doctors could write the numbers of football doubles on prescription forms and there would be no legal redress.

This whole attitude, this whole dilemma which he set himself, indicates the siege mentality which he had. He never thought of the possibility of co- operation. All he thought of was compulsion. He was concerned to try to force these people to behave in a certain way when, with equal ease, he could have asked for co-operation. He was not dealing with a renegade element. He was dealing with responsible members of the Australian community. Having set himself this unreal dilemma, he then went on to explain its necessity. He said the necessity was to prevent pensioners from defrauding the Australian revenue. The possibility of the pensioners that I know in my electorate setting out to do such a thing would occur only to someone who had a siege mentality. It would occur only to an organisation as heartless as the previous Fraser Government. The honourable member then set out to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why have you kept the declaration in the new arrangements?

—I am coming to that. The honourable member for Mackellar will be satisfied in due course. His next idea to provide a means of enforcing this provision was to tell the pharmacists, whose time was wasted dealing with this matter, that they would be able to claim remuneration for the extra work involved. In his second infamous letter to the pharmacists, which has become known in the annals of medical history as the 'Carltonian rescript' he said that pharmacists could claim against the Remuneration Tribunal for the extra work involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar and the Government with which he worked had no better way of using the skills of professionals in Australia than turning pharmacists into clerks. It would have been much better to proceed on a basis of trust and confidence, as the new Bill does. There is a very great difference- this is the answer to the question just raised by the honourable member for Mackellar-between writing on the bottom of a form that there is a penalty of $1, 000 or six months in gaol--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which I took off the earlier form, and I agreed it was stupid.

—It was on the first form and the second form stated that severe penalties or something like that would follow. What will be written on the bottom of this form will be that the beneficiary will be responsible for the accuracy of the form, which is a perfectly reasonable thing to write on a form and not something which frightens old aged pensioners.
—I took the frightening thing off.

—The honourable member may have taken the frightening thing off but he allowed it to go on in the first place and he put another silly thing on. He has to admit that the second thing that he put on was silly also. There is a world of difference between saying that and writing on the bottom of a form that a beneficiary is responsible for its accuracy. There is also a world of difference between a form of such complexity that an aged person is troubled by it and sees it as a difficult task and a form of the simplicity of that which has been drawn up by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and which was tabled just recently. The new form and the new procedure alleviate the objections which pharmacists and pensioners raised with me. It is a new system, it is a healthier system and I commend it to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Goodluck) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal Welfare-Bankstown Airport-Australian Dried Fruit Industry-Rozelle Community Youth Support Scheme-Tasmania-Bovine Tuberculosis and Brucellosis-Wine and Brandy Industry

PROCTEXT.PARA: Aboriginal Welfare-Bankstown Airport-Australian Dried Fruit Industry-Rozelle Community Youth Support Scheme-Tasmania-Bovine Tuberculosis and Brucellosis-Wine and Brandy Industry

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I venture to say that among all the challenging problems confronting this nation today one that must rate highly is the question of affording the Aboriginal people of Australia common justice. Therefore it is terribly essential that there be a clear understanding of the nature of the problem within our society based on the facts of the matter. Whilst a referendum of yesteryear gained the unquestionable support of the Australian community for Federal Government intervention in this matter, it is equally true to say that today some Australians are concerned at what they believe to be rather excessive expenditure for that purpose from the revenue. To facilitate the discharge of the Federal Parliament's responsibility to the Aboriginal people it is essential that the public be confident about the propriety of the measures that are introduced. Therefore, I think it is rather regrettable that a number of people- perhaps many people-who are well motivated unfortunately display an irresponsibility, perhaps a cavalier attitude, to the preciseness of the expositioin they put before this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about a recent situation in which criticism was directed against the Queensland Government. I hasten to say that a situation could well exist where criticism could be properly directed towards that Government's activities in this field, but that is quite aside from what I want to say now. In recent times a report was promoted-it was given wide publicity by the media-which totally misrepresented the state of the situation in Queensland. I think it is unfortunate that it should be so because people naturally notice headlines and form opinions. As a consequence the problems confronting the Government are compounded because of attitudes that become deeply entrenched.

The matter that concerns me particularly relates to a conclusion about Lockhart River Mission. A figure as to the fatality rate there was given. The fatality rate was 300 times that which prevails in Queensland as a whole. The astonishing thing about that conclusion is that it was based on five deaths among the Aboriginal community over a period of five years. Those deaths were as follows: One at the age of 58 years as a result of chronic obstructive airway disease; one at 82 years as a result of pneumonia; one at 77 years as a result of cardiac failure and pneumonia; one at 65 years due to respiratory arrest; and, to give the conclusion some respectability, there was an instance of the death of a one- day old child due to streptococcal pneumonia. Any reasonable person will recognise that that, inescapably, is a misleading proposition.

I think I can most effectively put my point if I quote directly from a statement relating to an article entitled 'Mortality Rates in 14 Qld Aboriginal Communities' which appeared in the Medical Journal of Australia on 16 April 1983 . The article was titled as emanating from the Department of Social and Preventive Medicine in the University of Queensland. The acting head of that Department, Professor F. D. Schofield, commented as follows:

'It has now become evident that in deriving the figures in the article and in drawing conclusions, the authors' mathematics and their epidemiological understanding were both at fault. It is unfortunate that none of the authors has had epidemiological or medical training or experience and that no staff member of the Department of Social and Preventive Medicine who possesses these attributes was asked to comment on the article until after its publication.

Two of the authors of the paper are not members of the Department of Social and Preventive Medicine, despite the name of the Department appearing on the front page of the article. One of the authors, a Statistician in the Department, gave general advice on standardization, but took no part in handling the data or in drawing conclusions from them, and did not sign the article.
In the paper, the crude death rate for 'infections' in Queensland in 1978 was wrongly calculated and was too small by a factor of ten. Thus the figure for ' relative risk' is grossly erroneous--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to speak briefly on the present activities and proposed activities at Bankstown Airport consequential upon the need to lighten the air traffic load at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport as a result of the Government's decision to construct a new international airport for Sydney. I do so because I am very concerned with the safety and wellbeing of the 6,000 people who live within a short distance of the Bankstown Airport. The Bankstown Airport provisional master plan, which was prepared by the Commonwealth Department of Aviation in late 1982, proposes a substantial expansion of facilities and aircraft movements at Bankstown Airport. It is proposed that the airport be extensively upgraded to cater not only for more air traffic-an increase of up to 60 per cent-but also for larger and heavier aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the decision of the present Government to construct a new international airport away from the Sydney metropolitan area is to be applauded, the reorganisation of air traffic which will be necessary at Kingsford-Smith Airport in the period prior to the provision of the new international airport will mean that more and more air traffic will need to be diverted to other airports such as Bankstown. Bankstown Airport is currently the main facility for light aircraft maintenance, flying training, charter operations, private flying and helicopter operations in New South Wales. The airport caters for 60 per cent of all general aviation movements in the Sydney region. The airport has experienced considerable growth in air traffic in recent years. For instance, in 1970 aircraft movements totalled 217,000. This figure grew to 308,000 in 1976 and 336 ,000 in 1981. I would point out that most of these movements were associated with flying training.

The former Minister for Aviation, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife), stated in a Press release in October 1982 that Bankstown Airport was unsuitable for commuter services because many passengers change aircraft at Kingsford-Smith to travel elsewhere. Apart from this statement there would appear to have been little consideration given to the long term future of Bankstown Airport. This is not good enough for the residents in my electorate and those in the neighbouring electorate of Blaxland who are enduring the social and physical disturbance of having an airport near their homes. The dangers to those residents from aircraft mishaps and accidents, I believe, is very great indeed, even greater than at Kingsford-Smith Airport, because of the lack of professional flying experience of many of the operators and learners taking off and landing at Bankstown Airport.

As a matter of urgency I therefore call on the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) to reject the proposals contained in the Department's provisional master plan for Bankstown Airport which provide for an increase in traffic movements and instead investigate the possibility of transferring non-essential traffic, such as flying training activities, to other airports at Schofields and Pitt Town, with a preference being shown for Schofields because of the facilities and traffic capacity at that airport. On a longer term basis I would like to see Bankstown Airport phased out completely as the new international airport for Sydney comes on stream. This would increase the capacity of Kingsford-Smith Airport for general aviation traffic. Because of the increasing residential activity in the vicinity of Bankstown Airport I believe action is necessary now to relieve the airport of any increase in traffic movements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the March election the Australian dried fruit industry was engaged in negotiations with the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Department of Primary Industry in efforts to obtain Reserve Bank finance for the unsold stocks of sultanas from the 1982 season. These arrangements were being undertaken as a means of alleviating the serious cash flow difficulties of growers caused by low returns and this unsold stock. Such an arrangement was undoubtedly a complex issue both financially and legally. Despite the good intentions of the Department of Primary Industry, the then Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), and the endeavours of delegates of the Australian Dried Fruits Association and members of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, including representations from myself, the necessary legal documentation had not been satisfactorily completed before 5 March 1983. It is now 2 1/2 months since the election and I call on the Federal Government through the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to meet a commitment made to the industry during the election campaign that the Australian Labor Party would honour this request and guarantee this loan application to the Reserve Bank of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: A recent Countrywide program on the Australia Broadcasting Commission left the impression that this year there would be a vintage season for the dried fruit industry and that whilst other rural regions of Australia were beset with the difficulties of drought the Sunraysia, Robinvale, Mid Murray and other Australian regions producing dried fruit, would be flush with the incomes from a large crop. This was certainly not the case. It was a season of average to good production but two factors created enormous problems for producers. The first was consistent unseasonal rainfall which affected the quality of the crop and harvesting difficulties associated with these climatic conditions. The second was the overhang of unsold fruit from the previous season in Australia resulting from a world surplus of stocks which created extreme problems. This second factor particularly has resulted from the entry of Greece into the European Economic Community, followed by the implementation of a system of production aids in August 1981. This regime consists of a subsidy for storage, compensation for losses and subsidised sales. Existing low prices on world markets and for imports into the EEC meant that most of the 1981 Greek crop was placed in storage and much of it subsequently used for distillation. More importantly, however, this has depressed prices for dried fruit and increased competition on Third World markets.

I appreciate the fact that the Minister for Primary Industry has come into the House. I know that he understands these factors which impact so heavily on the Australian industry. I also know that he appreciates the importance of this industry to the viability and stability of communities in the Murray Valley region. I know he recognises the seriousness of the social and economic problems of individual growers. I acknowledge that in the past weeks there has been a slight firming of prices and Australia with its high quality fruit has obtained additional export sales. World supply and demand are now in better balance only because production in the United States of America, Iran and Afghanistan have fallen below earlier estimates. However, prices received by the growers are still inadequate and totally unsatisfactory in terms of production costs. I therefore ask the Minister for Primary Industry urgently to obtain approval for this application for Reserve Bank finance and to take the necessary steps to ensure that growers' obtain cash requirements and are assisted in this vital area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up the case of the Rise and Shine Rozelle Community Youth Support Scheme in my electorate. This centre is highly regarded in our local community and I believe that the value of the work it does with unemployed young people cannot be overestimated. If we are to avoid the high social costs associated with the unemployed which have arisen as a result of the policies of the previous Government-a huge increase in the number of unemployed took place under the previous Government-then programs like the Community Youth Support Scheme will require additional assistance. The overall CYSS Budget was kept at the same level for 16 months prior to March 1982 and then was given a 9.2 per cent increase to June 1982. The CYSS 1982-83 budget saw only a 6.9 per cent rise in funds to projects, taking into account the increase of 19 new projects. This means that in 1980-81 to 1982-83 in real terms projects received less than they were funded for in the previous year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Rise and Shine CYSS is on a grant level of $74,000 this year which is a 9 per cent increase over the previous grant. Before we even consider the financial pressures of the general inflationary increase and a wage bill increase of $3, 500 for the two full time and one half time project officers plus $6,500 for holiday relief staff, it is necessary to consider that over the past year there has been an increase of 40 per cent in the number of young people participating in Rise and Shine activities. This has obviously led to a forced increase in spending.

Despite careful budgeting by this group it estimates that by November this year it will have overrun its current grant of $74,000 by between $12,500 and $13,000 which would necessitate closure some time in September. The members of the group have already cut tutorials to 15 hours a week and cut publicity and materials expenditure by half. Staff have also agreed not to take back pay entitlements until money is received. The management committee is looking at a range of options for raising money, such as reapproaching businesses, service clubs and the community in general, and by sales of handicrafts and regular benefit concerts. However, any money raised privately by Rise and Shine should be available to provide extra benefits and services to the participants and not be earmarked to pay for the basic day-to-day expenses of the scheme. This is the responsibility of government. It is obvious that the desperate situation of Rise and Shine has come about, not because of profligate spending or mismanagement but because of the total inadequacy of the grant of $74,000 for running this scheme at any acceptable level. The present necessity for scrimping and saving to ensure that they are able to meet their running costs has denied them the flexibility that the CYSS guidelines, introduced in March 1982, intended. I would ask the Government to look carefully at the financial plight of the Rise and Shine CYSS in particular, and CYSS schemes in general, with a view to alleviating this plight. I would like to stress once again that it is vital that we should help these unemployed young people who are already either alienated from the mainstream of Australian life or are in danger of becoming so if they feel that their needs have been ignored. What better way of assisting them than by assisting the Community Youth Support Scheme projects which have already proved their value in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to resurrect the problems of Tasmania again in relation to the dam. However, I intend to do so. I do not want to drop a bucket tonight on the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania because he is quite a decent fellow. He was respected but he is beginning to lose a little bit of face because he is starting to try to walk on both sides. He is trying to support the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Incidentally, the five Tasmanian members of this place have been unable to have an audience with the Prime Minister to give him their side of the story in relation to Tasmania. I think that an article which appeared in today's Hobart Mercury indicates the point I want to make. The article is headed: 'ALP members given cold treatment'. Then, on the other hand, there are facts about the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) and what he said about Tasmania in his very smart way, if I may say so. It is not like the Minister to be smart. There is everything about the Minister, about the 16 industries and all the other things that he is going to do for Tasmania. The article carries two photographs, one of which shows a slogan with the words 'Dam Bob Hawke' and another a slogan with the words 'Bob Brown, stay out of our town you and your wilderness clowns'. All we want in Tasmania is to be left alone. I mentioned Ken Wriedt, the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania. I will not drop a bucket over him. I will not say anything about him that I would not say to his face, even though he is six inches taller than I am. But that is not a display of fortitude on my part.

SPEECH.PARA: Ken Wriedt stood against my esteemed friend, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), and lost. He lost because I think the people of Tasmania thought that when it gets a bit rough he does not have the tenacity to go in. He did not stand against me, even though he lives in the electorate of Franklin. If he had, the result would have been a foregone conclusion, but never mind, I put that aside. The people of Tasmania are starting to ask questions about Ken Wriedt. I feel very sorry because he is losing all the esteem in which he was held. He is a very good type of fellow. He is a good family man and so on. But we come to the critical point in that people are starting to ask questions about him. They are starting to say that he plays on two sides of the fence. However, he can play only on one side. He was a member of the Tasmanian Parliament which said that we should construct the dam in Tasmania, that we should look to hydro as our future power, and that we should have a works program in which men are employed. He was part of the Parliament that decided that. Yet, all of a sudden he feels it is necessary to side with Bob Hawke who has the albatross around his neck. He is like Dorian Gray. That is starting to show every day. He has the scar of the dam and he will have other scars before he is finished. This indicates what the people of Queenstown-the noddy doddies as the Minister called them, the ordinary working people that he is supposed to support-think of him. He can offer them all the other things that he suggested but what will he do to them in the meantime? Where will they get their livelihood? How will they support their families? The Minister talks about the poor; these people are the poor at the moment because they do not know what they will do in the future. Mr Wriedt had better be very careful because the people of Tasmania are funny people. I beat honourable members opposite to the draw that time; they have called them that before. We are funny. We remember. The people of Tasmania stick with those who stick with them, but if people start to side against them, those people are gone. I am afraid that Ken Wriedt is gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian cattle herd is now numbered at about 23 million. Bovine tuberculosis and brucellosis have been the scourge of the Australian cattle industry since the last century. Efforts to control tuberculosis were introduced in the 19th century, but it was not until early this century that specific investigations into brucellosis were commenced in Australia. Early control and eradication efforts for these two diseases were based on the need to protect human health. Tuberculosis eradication programs commenced in the late 1950s. Official testing was concentrated in dairying areas . The program was extended to beef areas as eradication of the disease in dairying areas progressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Schemes for the control of brucellosis were introduced in most States in the 1930s. In 1966 the Australian Agricultural Council made a recommendation to the then Federal Government that it adopt a national campaign to eradicate brucellosis and tuberculosis. The program was considered urgent and necessary because of the migration of cattle between the States and the very real prospects of overseas importers rejecting Australian beef and dairy products if evidence of brucellosis or tuberculosis was detected in these products.

The Federal Government formally introduced a brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign in 1970-a program to eradicate both diseases by 1992. Under the Labor Government in 1973 the eradication campaign was expanded. Since that time, the campaign has been supported by successive governments and two Industries Assistance Commission inquiries. The brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign is funded jointly by the Federal Government and cattle producers. Producers pay a $4 a head levy on cattle sold for slaughter and meet the on-farm costs of testing. Since 1970 over $280m has been spent by the cattle industry and $120m has been spent by government in the eradication campaign. The effect of the campaign to date is that the diseases have been reduced to extremely low levels. The industry is committed to total eradication of the diseases.

However, major problems exist across northern Australia, particularly in the Gulf and Peninsula, because of the rugged terrain, hundreds of thousands of feral cattle and buffalo, and the high cost to individual properties participating in the campaign. Our great trading partners-the United States, Canada and New Zealand-have introduced similar eradication campaigns. It should be noted that the total cost of the eradication campaign in these countries is met by their respective governments. The United States and Canadian beef markets accounted for 59.6 per cent of Australian beef exports in 1982-worth some $620m.

Brucellosis and tuberculosis can be communicated in meat exports. Clearly, the United States and Canada will not jeopardise the effectiveness of their eradication programs by continuing to import beef from countries where both these diseases exist. Therefore, it is essential that Australia complete its eradication campaign successfully. The Hawke Government is committed to the successful completion of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. This Government is aware of the special problems and high costs involved in completing the final stages of the eradication campaign in northern Australia. The Government is determined that Australia's export market to the United States and Canada will not be jeopardised by the presence of these diseases. The Australian Agricultural Council has endorsed a proposal seeking additional Federal assistance to ensure that the eradication campaign is not delayed. The Hawke Government is currently examining ways in which compensation and other additional funds can be found to support future eradication campaign operations. Furthermore, all recommendations made by the Australian Agricultural Council will be considered in the context of the 1983-84 Budget.

The cattle industry appreciates the disastrous economic situation inherited by the Hawke Government. The industry is aware that the Hawke Government, an authentic Australian Government, has been charged with the responsibility of salvaging the cattle industry and protecting it. For the first time in seven years the Australian cattle industry has a national government which is aware of the severe difficulties facing the industry. Cattlemen know that the Hawke Government will never abandon their industry. This Government is committed to the growth of the cattle industry and to the welfare of its producers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise during this adjournment debate because of two superficially reasonable statements that have come from the Government in the past two weeks. The first of them came only yesterday from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he addressed the National Farmers Federation. He said that the rural community, like all other parts of the Australian community, must accept its share of fiscal restraint. That is not unreasonable. But the second statement was made during the election campaign when the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) gave an assurance in an election promise that no tax on the wine industry would be levied during the term of this Government. In an effort to get some reassurance about that promise, I wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry on 2 May. I respect the fact that the Minister for Primary Industry has been overseas, but I have yet to have that promise underscored by him.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of his hesitation on that point, rumour is currently running in my electorate that tomorrow night's economic statement could well contain an impost on wine and brandy. I want to make two points. The first concerns the mistaken presumption we have that an impost on wine and brandy would be a tax on a rich man's beverage. The fact is that these industries are price elastic and work done by Tolakis, Reithmuller and Watts in a report to the Australian Agricultural Economics Society in New Zealand in 1981 indicated that an increase in shelf price of 15 per cent in either of these commodities would result in a fall in sales of 20 per cent. Such a fall would mean that an additional 80,000 tonnes of grapes would be left hanging in the South Australian grape growing areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be the same with brandy.

—Precisely. This impost would not, in fact, be borne by the people who buy the beverage but by the growers who could no longer sell that volume of product. This impost will be borne by the growers who have already borne the reality of drought, fire and flood, particularly in the Barossa Valley. That is simply not reasonable. These growers, after all, are committed to a long term industry. They plant vines that will not be bearing for seven years, and lay down spirits that will take eight or 10 years to reach maturation. Any impost in these areas must be exercised both gradually and reasonably.

SPEECH.PARA: The second myth that I want to lay to rest is that the industry is not already taxed. In 1979-80 Federal and State taxes levied against the wine industry totalled $22.24m. The tax on brandy totalled $53.1m. The total impost on these two industries was $75m. In 1981-82 this had risen to $89m. If the Government wishes to talk about tax equity and if people wish to talk about the beer industry we might consider that if an excise of so many dollars per litre of alcohol were applied equally to the beer industry as that which applies to the whisky industry we would generate $730m in revenue. If a sales tax were applied to the wine industry we would generate only $20m in revenue.

In the last address I gave in this House, I was reported in the Press as having located some point in my electorate for a particular Government action 200 miles north-west of Adelaide. In fact, that would be in the middle of Spencer Gulf. The 90 degree error that was reported by the Press and was not a part of my speech pales into insignificance beside the 180-degree error that this Government will make if it does an about-face on the wine and brandy industries.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 May 1983 (Hansard, page 415) Mr Spender asked me, in my capacity as Minister for Aviation, the following question without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Spender-My question is addressed to the Minister for Aviation. Are airlines using Sydney Airport incurring losses caused by traffic congestion and traffic delays at the airport? If so: Firstly, what is the current annual rate of those losses? Secondly, what decisions has his Government made-I emphasise the words decisions' and his Government'-to eliminate the causes of those losses?
In my reply I indicated that I would provide further information. That information is as follows:

At the peak of activity in 1981 before the current downturn in airline activity and, before the recent introduction of revised traffic management procedures, it was estimated that delays to the Airlines and commuters at Sydney was costing them in the order of $7 million annually in direct operating costs.
